Claim: False: Video of the current situation in Italy due to coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is of an Emergency Exercise at Blaise Diagne International Airport (Senegal) in November 2019. The mock drill was conducted to see if the crew can handle emergency situations at the airport.

Claim: FALSE: Bollywood Superstar Aamir Khan donated Rs.15000 each to poor slum dwellers in one kg wheat flour packets.
Explanation: The claim is made by a Tik Tok user who has not specified the source of the news. The mainstream media has not reported anything as such neither has Aamir Khan or anyone close to him has made an official statement regarding this.

Claim: FALSE: Joy Arakkal’, the owner of ‘Joyalukkas’ jewellery company, has died due to COVID-19 in the Middle East.
Explanation: The owner of 'Joy Alukkas' jewellery company is 'Joy Alukkas'; not 'Joy Arakkal'. Joy Arakkal is the managing director of UAE-based Innova group of companies. Arakkal has commited suicide in Dubai due to financial reasons.

Claim: False: An image shared on social media claims this Italian doctor couple worked day and night and saved the lives of 134 patients, but on the eighth day, they contracted the coronavirus and died after an hour.
Explanation: The couple in the picture is not Italian; they are from Spain. The photograph was taken at Barcelona Airport on 3/12/20.

Claim: False: Photos of Italian man committing suicide after he lost his entire family to COVID-19.
Explanation: The video was taken in Spain and is found to be in circulation on the internet at least since the last week of December 2019. The first COVID-19 death was reported only in the second week of January 2019 in China.

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 vaccine caused the new strain in the UK
Explanation: It is not true because the starin was first detected in September, much before the vaccine was approved and administered.

Claim: False: Gargling warm water with either salt or vinegar can eliminate coronavirus.
Explanation: The World Health Organisation (WHO) or Indian government has not mentioned anywhere that the gargling of warm water with salt or vinegar can eliminate coronavirus. Indian government’s Press Information Bureau (PIB) has also said that the message that was circulating on social media is fake.

Claim: False: After COVID-19 outbreak in europe Muslims and non-Muslims have come out in the streets shouting praises for Allah and reading Kalma.
Explanation: Fact Crescendo found the viral video to be unrelated. The video dates back before the outbreak of COVID-19 in Europe. This is a demonstration march by the citizens in Hamburg, Germany in solidarity with Uyghur Muslims.

Claim: FALSE: God has punished China in the form of floods after they spread coronavirus in the world
Explanation: No, China was not punished in the form of floods. This is from an old video of Japan’s tsunami.

Claim: FALSE: A Muslim police officer is beating up a temple priest for breaking lockdown orders in India.
Explanation: A police officer did beat up a temple priest for breaking lockdown orders, but the officer was not a Muslim. He was a Hindu.

Claim: FALSE: Three red tick marks on WhatsApp means the government is initiating action against you.
Explanation: There are no "Three Ticks" or "Red Ticks" in WhatsApp. It's a fake message.

Claim: False: Italy’s Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte broke down publicly due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The image on social media is of Brazilian President Bolsonaro and not Italy's PM Giuseppe Conte. The claim shared by several social media users and media outlets is false.

Claim: FALSE: The image of a boy with serious injuries is that of a Tablighi Jamat COVID-19 patient who was beaten up by police in India after he misbehaved with the nurses in the hospital where he was admitted.
Explanation: The image of the boy with severe injuries is from July 2019. It has been falsely linked to coronavirus and Tablighi Jamat.

Claim: FALSE: 28-year-old Dr Manisha Patil from Maharashtra died yesterday due to coronavirus. Manisha had examined 188 people and helped them recover, but she could not save herself from coronavirus.
Explanation: No female doctor had died in Maharashtra and the picture which is being shared with the claim is of Dr. Richa Rajput who is alive. She through a video called out this claim.

Claim: Misleading: Coronavirus does not settle in air but is grounded – UNICEF
Explanation: Neither UNICEF has issued any such advisory nor the information in the viral message is accurate.

Claim: False: Video of Canadian PM Justin Trudeau’s wife who is suffering from COVID-19.
Explanation: Woman in the video is not the wife of Justin Trudeau but a COVID-19 patient from London.

Claim: Mostly false: Brazilians observed Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s “lights out” call.
Explanation: The viral video was available on the internet even days before PM Modi's April 3 speech. The viral claim is misleading.

Claim: FALSE: Indian media outlets claimed that a man in Madhya Pradesh’s Khargone passed away from COVID-19.
Explanation: The claim that the man hid his travel history and died of coronavirus made by both ANI and Republic is false. The man, who did indeed test positive, was actually undergoing treatment at Indore’s Maharaja Hospital and had gotten himself tested after returning to Khargone. He has now been discharged from care as well, after having tested negative twice for the novel coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Clapping hands in during the Janata Curfew in India kills Coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim that clapping hands during Janata curfew will kill the virus is FALSE.

Claim: False: Images of the public beating police officers enforcing lockdown in the Indian state of U.P.
Explanation: The images are of a past incident from Kanpur, totally unrelated to the current lockdown.

Claim: False: Chinese police crack down on suspected coronavirus patients.
Explanation: Video is originally from the Hong Kong protests.

Claim: FALSE: Video from Pune shows COVID-19 patient collapsing on the streets and being taken away in an ambulance.
Explanation: The viral video, in fact, shows a mock drill conducted by Pune Municipal Corporation to check on response time in COVID-19 related emergencies.

Claim: False: Images shows how Indian police have beaten up migrant workers amid India’s lockdown for commuting
Explanation: All the images are old and unrelated to the ongoing COVID-19 lockdown.

Claim: FALSE: Coronavirus is losing potency, as per WHO
Explanation: WHO didnt say that coronavirus is losing potency, post falsely attributed to WHO. The fake post has resurfaced on social media.

Claim: FALSE: In order to save Pakistani people from the coronavirus, Prime minister Imran Khan has started prayers in Shiva temple in Ciyal Kota (Pakisthan) which had been closed for 72 years.
Explanation: The news video is an old one. The incident shown in the video was telecasted in July 2019 when Pakistan's prime minister, Imran Khan, reopened a Shavala Teej Singh (Shiva) temple which had been closed for 72 years.

Claim: FALSE: In India, Tamil Nadu’s BJP party workers distributed drugs along with COVID-19 relief goods.
Explanation: A doctored image has been used to make the false claim.

Claim: FALSE: India’s Prime Minister Narendra Modi said in his ‘Mann Ki Baat’ radio address that one crore COVID-19 patients have been treated for free in the country.
Explanation: The prime minister was talking about the beneficiaries of a national health policy Ayushman Bharat which was launched in September 2018, and not COVID-19 patients.

Claim: False: This video shows a seafood market in Wuhan, China.
Explanation: This video is of the Langowan market in Indonesia and not of the Wuhan seafood market.

Claim: FALSE: Grand Ayatollah Ali Sistani, a top Shiite leader in Iraq, met with a crowd of worshippers on an Islamic holiday despite the risk of coronavirus infection.
Explanation: The footage actually shows Grand Ayatollah Sayid Sadiq Shirazi, a Shiite leader in Iran, observing the Islamic holiday of Ashura in August 2020.

Claim: FALSE: Coronavirus can be avoided by eating nigella with honey as it contains 100% hydroxychloroquine. Hydroxychloroquine treats coronavirus.
Explanation: Hydroxychloroquine is not present in the substances found in nigella, but it contains thymoquinone. Hydroxychloroquine is also not yet proven as a cure coronavirus though many countries giving HCQ to COVID-19 patients.

Claim: FALSE: Nurse in Nashville claims to have suffered Bells Palsy after receiving the vaccine
Explanation: The woman in question is not a nurse and there is no health worker by her name who received the vaccine in the US

Claim: FALSE: WHO warned against consuming cabbage to prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: Post claiming WHO warned against consuming cabbage to prevent from COVID-19 is fake.

Claim: : Every Indian citizen to get Rs.5000 as COVID-19 relief by clicking on this link given in the viral Whatsapp message.
Misleading: Indian government is asking people to not wear masks
Explanation: A video from early March when wearing masks was not compulsary was circulated as recent

Claim: FALSE: Image claims that a family committed suicide in Jodhpur, India with its picture going viral during lockdown.
Explanation: The viral post shows the incident that happened in 2017. It is not related to lockdown.

Claim: FALSE: Gates Foundation planting microchips during COVID19 swab testing.
Explanation: No, Gates Foundation is not planting microchips during COVID-19 swab testing. This viral post is fake.

Claim: FALSE: People are falling on the streets due to lack of oxygen in hospitals in India
Explanation: The video was from a gas leak that occurred in Vizag in 2020 and is not linked to covid-19

Claim: FALSE: Tweet by Assam Health Minister Himanta Biswa Sarma regarding newly found COVID-19 positive cases.
Explanation: The tweet is manipulated. The health minister has not tweeted anything as such.

Claim: FALSE: Photo of a family which committed suicide due to hunger during the lockdown.
Explanation: It is an old photo. The same photo can be found in an article published by 'Sakshi' in June 2019. The lady killed her children and committed suicide due to problems with her husband. So, it is neither related to lockdown nor hunger.

Claim: False: Indian Social Activist Trupti Desai arrested for buying liquor during the COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: The video is old and unrelated to COVID-19.

Claim: False: Demon creature flying above a church in Italy.
Explanation: This is an old video created digitally using VFX created by an animation studio.

Claim: FALSE: When a police officer enforced lockdown orders on people in a temple in India, he was beaten up there.
Explanation: The video is taken from a 2019 YouTube show. It has no relation to the ongoing lockdown.

Claim: FALSE: A leopard was seen in Mumbai due to the lockdown and a lesser number of vehicles.
Explanation: The leopard was seen on the National Highway at Hyderabad and not in Mumbai due to the lockdown

Claim: FALSE: News and media outlet ABP Majha, on the basis of an internal memo of South Central Railway, reported that a special train has been announced to take the stranded migrant workers home.
Explanation: Indian Railways did not issue any circular that led to the gathering of stranded migrant workers in the state of Maharashtra but was just a proposal by the South Central Railway. Hence, it can be concluded that ABP Majha misrepresented the internal letter from the South Central Railway and reported the announcement of a special train for stranded migrant workers while Indian Railways did not make any such announcement but The New Indian Express journalist Sudhir Suryavanshi falsely accused the Indian Railways of issuing a circular regarding the announcement of a special train.

Claim: False: Prime Minister of China visited a mosque and realized the only protection from coronavirus is to bow before Allah.
Explanation: The Associated Press archive video was uploaded in 2015 and shows ex-Malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi visiting a mosque in China in 2004, not during the coronavirus outbreak.

Claim: False: Video of police strictly implementing a lockdown in Spain.
Explanation: The video is not related to a COVID-19 lockdown in any country. It shows Azerbaijan Police (not Spain) dispersing a protest in October 2019.

Claim: FALSE: Migrants traveling to their homes from Mumbai during lockdown.
Explanation: Video is from Delhi's Anandvihar and not from Mumbai.

Claim: False: Woman burned her hands while putting on the stove due to high alcohol content in hand sanitizer.
Explanation: This is a hoax. Alcohol in hand sanitizers evaporates completely once applied on the hands.

Claim: False: Video of Canada PM Justin Trudeau’s wife pleading for people to take COVID-19 seriously.
Explanation: The woman in the video is not Canada Prime Minister’s wife (Sophie Grégoire Trudeau). She is Tara Jane Langston, a waitress who contracted COVID-19 and is undergoing treatment at Hillingdon Hospital in London.

Claim: FALSE: An old man infected 300 people with coronavirus in Jaipur, India through tobacco smoke.
Explanation: Local authorities and PIB have denied this news. They termed it false.

Claim: FALSE: Black body bags being referred to as deaths in New York and the reason a lockdown is essential.
Explanation: The body bags are from Eucador and not New York.

Claim: MISLEADING: Matterhorn mountain in Swiss Alps lit up with the Indian Tricolour after PM Narendra Modi supplied Hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) tablets.
Explanation: While the photo and the incident is true and the Indian Tricolour was actually projected onto the Matterhorn, the claim shared with the photo is false. The gesture was meant to express solidarity with all Indians in the fight against COVID-19 and had nothing to do with HCQ supply at all.

Claim: MISLEADING: Police beating common people during lockdown in India.
Explanation: This is and old video of a protest that is not related to the lockdown.

Claim: FALSE: Coronavirus in poultry products has been confirmed by the Bihar Health Department.
Explanation: The Health Department of the Government of Bihar, through a Facebook post on April 15, 2020, has denied the claim that coronavirus is found in poultry products.

Claim: False: Government of an Indian state Madhya Pradesh ordered shoot-at-sight to enforce lockdown.
Explanation: Our research revealed that a screenshot of a news channel report is circulating without context. MP government has not given any such order. MP government and Jabalpur police clarified it on Twitter.

Claim: MISLEADING: Video representing the plight of migrant workers in India during the current lockdown, where a woman with infant had to travel while sitting on the coupler between train bogies.
Explanation: While it is true that the migrant workers are facing a lot of problems due to the current lockdown in the country, the video can be traced back to July 2016, and is likely from Bangladesh.

Claim: FALSE: Photo of a Hindu woman attacked by RSS members for offering Sehri to a Muslim Kashmiri girl during the Indian lockdown.
Explanation: The photo of the injured woman was found to exist on the internet at least since February 2020, while the image of a woman offering Sehri to a Muslim Kashmiri girl was claimed to be captured on 25 April 2020. Hence the events are not related to each other.

Claim: FALSE: Man seen in viral images was a COVID-19 patient who fell in love with his lady doctor. The two got engaged in the same hospital in Egypt.
Explanation: The pictures are part of a pre-wedding photo shoot. The couple has been engaged since 2018. Neither of them are infected with coronavirus.

Claim: False: Italian police are being brutal on people not following lockdowns; India should follow.
Explanation: The police apprehended a man who was brandishing a gun in Sao Paulo, Brazil.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows a policeman taking bribe from migrating workers in Surat.
Explanation: The video is from 2019 and shows a policeman taking bribe from women who were peddling illegal liquor. It has nothing to do with the current pandemic.

Claim: False: Sophie Trudeau is sharing her COVID-19 experience.
Explanation: Video is of a woman from London and not Sophie Trudeau.

Claim: FALSE: Video of Chinese people not being allowed into the supermarkets of Australia.
Explanation: The video shows an altercation between a couple and a staff member over the former’s attempt to purchase the ‘baby formula tins’ beyond the supermarket’s permissible limit

Claim: FALSE: Doctor from Delhi hospital prescribes a list of preventive medicines against COVID-19
Explanation: The hospital refuted the claim and said the doctor's signature was forged.

Claim: Misleading: pH level of coronavirus varies from 5.5 to 8.5 and to beat the virus, we should consume more alkaline food.
Explanation: Dr. Shaheed Jameel, a leading virologist, said that viruses do not have pH values.

Claim: False: Indian State of Kerala Opposition leader writes to Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan to adopt methods to save only those with stronger immunity from COVID-19 infection.
Explanation: FactCrescendo obtained the letter. The opposition leader has suggested only mitigation measures to be adopted by the state to stop the spread of coronavirus. The Facebook user has misinterpreted the term "mitigation methods" and built a false narrative around it. The opposition leader's office has condemned the post saying no politician occupying the post of the leader of the opposition would suggest such drastic measures.

Claim: False: In the video, the woman who is asking to take the coronavirus seriously is the wife of the Prime Minister of Canada.
Explanation: The woman in the video is not the Canadian prime minister’s wife, Sophie Grégoire Trudeau. She is Tara Jane Langston, a waitress who contracted the coronavirus and is undergoing treatment at Hillingdon Hospital in London. She made the video to tell people in her country that the coronavirus is serious.

Claim: FALSE: A poorly done PCR test has not pierced a patient’s brain
Explanation: The PCR was not poorly done, the woman who lost brain fluid had a previous skull base defect.

Claim: False: Photo posts claim a person is committing suicide by jumping from a building in Italy, a doctor couple in an Italian hospital a few hours before their death and chaos in an Italian hospital amid COVID-19.
Explanation: The first image is from Spain where a woman committed suicide in December 2019; the second image is of a couple at the Barcelona airport and the third image is from recent earthquake in Croatia.

Claim: Mostly false: Disaster management act has been implemented, no citizen is allowed to post any update on coronavirus.
Explanation: The message is misleading and the viral video two years old.

Claim: False: Video shows bat infestation under a tiled roof, the source of coronavirus in Hubei, China.
Explanation: The video is 8 years old and not from China.

Claim: FALSE: A COVID-19 vaccine will be on the market by August 15, 2020
Explanation: A COVID-19 vaccine will not be released by August 15th in India.

Claim: False: China is seeking court’s approval to kill all who tested positive with coronavirus.
Explanation: The National Health Commission of the People’s Republic of China makes no mention of any such case.

Claim: FALSE: Muslims are throwing currency notes on roads to spread coronavirus in Indore, a city in India.
Explanation: The currency notes in the streets of Indore was accidently dropped by a cooking gas delivery man while he was cycling.

Claim: False: Inhalation of hot steam can kill the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Inhalation of steam from hot water does not kill COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Government of Telangana in India has released a new schedule of SSC Class-X Examinations. As per it, exams will be scheduled from April 20 to April 28.
Explanation: As on 07 April 2020, SSC board hasn't announced any schedule of SSC Class-X examinations. Satyanarayana Reddy (Director of the Examination section of the Board) has clarified that the messages with schedule of the exams are fake.

Claim: FALSE: Film star Aamir Khan distributed 15 thousand rupees to the poor in flour bags.
Explanation: In our investigation, it came to light that the film star Aamir Khan neither distributed the flour to anyone nor kept 15,000 rupees in it. Several media reports contacted some local journalists to confirm the claim of money being distributed in Surat. But they were unaware of the incident. Talked to the police control room policemen about this, but they too have no information in this matter.

Claim: False: Reserve Bank of India (RBI) extended the year closing until 6/30/20.
Explanation: The normal financial year in India followed by the government and all other institutions including for taxation purpose is April 1 to March 31. However, RBI’s accounting/financial year is from July 1 to June 30. There is no change in the normal financial year.

Claim: False: Rubbing mustard oil on your nostrils can prevent coronavirus.
Explanation: Rubbing mustard oil cannot prevent coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Video from Pune, India shows COVID-19 patient collapsing on the streets.
Explanation: This is a mock drill video conducted by Pune Municipal Corporation for COVID-19 preparedness.

Claim: FALSE: Image of worn-out feet/sole of migrant workers walking on streets in India amis COVID-19 Lockdown.
Explanation: The image was captured in 2018 and is from Pakistan. The image is of Children from a poor family in the Sindh province who were suffering from a disease due to which their feet were worn-out.

Claim: False: Amitabh Bachchan gave 500 million rupees to the Mumbai government to fight the coronavirus.
Explanation: A part of an old video of Amitabh Bachchan and Narendra Modi is viral with false claims. Amitabh has not given a check of Rs. 500 crores to Bombay Municipal Corporation nor to Government of Maharashtra. He has not even met Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi recently.

Claim: FALSE: Photo of Kurnool MLA (Hafeez Khan) making a nurse to touch the feet of a religious head in Viswabharathi Medical College, who had to come to the COVID-19 quarantine facility.
Explanation: The nurse was not forced to touch the feet of a religious head. She is treating the Muslim old man whose leg is injured. Blood on the Muslim man's leg can be seen in a video shot during that time.

Claim: FALSE: Muslims came on the streets to disobey the lockdown and spread coronavirus.
Explanation: The crowd had assembled as there were rumours the imam of the mosque was arrested and that the mosque was being vandalised by the police.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows migrants staying in quarantine facilities in India refused to eat the food because it was cooked by a Dalit woman (low-caste group).
Explanation: Bihar Police clarified that women told migrants to eat separately maintaining social distance, upon which they created ruckus and kicked the food plates.

Claim: False: A drug made from cow urine or pigeon membrane can cure coronavirus.
Explanation: No evidence has been found which can prove that the pigeon membrane can cure the coronavirus. The WHO has not mentioned this, either.

Claim: FALSE: Indian Air Force showers petals on migrant workers walking home.
Explanation: The picture is photoshopped and merges two images. The Indian Air Force showered petals on hospitals and not migrant workers.

Claim: False: A WhatsApp forward attributed to CNN claims Dr. Li Wenliang, the whistleblower of the Chinese government’s propaganda about COVID-19, has documented a research report. According to this report, chemicals like Methylxanthine, Theobromine and Theophylline stimulate compounds that can ward off this virus in a human body with at least an average performing immune system.
Explanation: The WHO has mentioned that to date, there is no vaccine or treatment to prevent or cure COVID-19. Also, the Chinese doctor Li Wenliang did not mention any medication or vaccination to cure COVID-19 in his findings.

Claim: False: Rapper Eminem contacted coronavirus.
Explanation: The post is a hoax.

Claim: FALSE: Muslims in India are licking utensils to spread the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was uploaded in 2018. It shows a practice adopted by Bohra community Muslims to lick their utensils after eating so that not even a single grain of food is wasted.

Claim: FALSE: Businessman Ratan Tata has said that 2020 is the year to survive and not care about profil and losses.
Explanation: The message is fake and no such statement has been issued by the Chairman Emeritus of Tata Sons.

Claim: FALSE: A soldier hugged his coronavirus-positive daughter by covering her in plastic.
Explanation: The viral picture is not of India but of Malaysia. In the investigation we found that the soldier doing duty during the coronavirus is hugging his son in plastic due to fear of virus. The information found during the search shows that the child seen in the photograph is not coronavirus positive.

Claim: FALSE: An image claimed a family committed suicide by hanging to a tree due to hunger while migrating from Surat, India.
Explanation: The image was the cover picture of a video by DJ Pintu and it was uploaded on March 9, 2019. It is not related to coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Twitter users have shared a video of people collapsing on the road in the backdrop of India’s second COVID-19 wave.
Explanation: The video showing people collapsing on the road in the backdrop of India’s second COVID-19 wave is misleading. The visuals are from Visakhapatanam’s gas leak tragedy in Andhra Pradesh last year.

Claim: Mostly false: Clapping together at 5 p.m. will create a vibration which will destroy coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no proven evidence that vibration created by collectively clapping can destroy coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: A Tamil Nadu (India) DMK leader beat up a lady doctor who was on COVID-19 duty.
Explanation: This is a 2018 video of the DMK leader beating up a woman who was not a doctor and this is not linked to COVID-19. The leader was suspended from the party

Claim: FALSE: Due to COVID-19 outbreak, UPSC has cancelled examinations in India.
Explanation: No such decision has been taken by UPSC. UPSC conducts various examinations. It did not cancel any examination. Details regarding each examination can be seen in the press release issued by UPSC on 15 April 2020.

Claim: False: Indian Government has issued a guideline to monitor citizens’ activity; their call and social media handles will be under surveillance.
Explanation: A Twitter user shared the same claim on November 24, 2017. The viral forward is fake and the Indian government has not issued any guidelines to monitor the activities of its citizens on various social media and messaging platforms.

Claim: False: People in Italy are threw away their money after they lost their family members to coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim and the images are false. The images are old and are not related to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic in any way.

Claim: FALSE: Maharashtra (India) Governor Bhagat Singh Koshyari facilitated the travel of a model from Maharashtra to Dehradun during the COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: The letter to facilitate the travel was issued by Himachal Pradesh Governor's office. Maharashtra Governor has filed a complaint against the web portal for publishing fake news.

Claim: FALSE: Migrants in Mumbai robbed and killed a man for money due to the lockdown.
Explanation: This is a video of a robbery from Delhi in 2018 and is not related to the COVID-19 lockdown.

Claim: Misleading: Hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) can prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: The US FDA has approved the drug for treatment of COVID-19 as this anti-malarial drug might ease some symptoms. However, it is not proven to build resistance and prevent COVID-19 and its use without a doctor's prescription is not recommended.

Claim: half true: Passengers at Delhi airport got agitated Wednesday morning as their passports were withheld by airport authorities.
Explanation: This incident took place a few days back at IGIA in relation to mandatory coronavirus screening

Claim: FALSE: Inhaling steam of orange peels and sea salt will kill the coronavirus.
Explanation: Post claiming inhaling steam of orange peels and sea salt will kill coronavirus is fake.

Claim: FALSE: In the United Kingdom, the woman who was tried for the coronavrus vaccine has died.
Explanation: Vaccine trials have taken place in the United Kingdom, but the woman who has been tried is alive, not dead.

Claim: False: Photo of the prime minister of Italy crying and expressing his helplessness that he couldn’t save coronavirus patients in Italy.
Explanation: The person in the photo is not the PM of Italy. He is Jair Bolsonaro, the President of Brazil. The photo was taken when he cried at an ‘Evangelical Thanksgiving Service’. The PM of Italy has not expressed helplessness that he couldn't save coronavirus affected patients in Italy.

Claim: FALSE: Parrots eating from rice bag due to lockdown.
Explanation: Picture is old and has no relation with lockdown.

Claim: False: Justin Trudeau’s wife has released a video from her hospital bed.
Explanation: The woman in the video is not Sophie Trudeau but Tara Jane Langston, a 39-year-old who was diagnosed with pneumonia at the Hillingdon Hospital in West London. She recorded this video for her colleagues and the public to make them aware of the seriousness of COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Muslims in Malegaon, India, violated lockdown to read Namaz on a bridge.
Explanation: People in Malegaon gathered on the bridge asking for basic necessities during lockdown. There is no communal angle to the incident.

Claim: FALSE: No pig fat ingridients were found in Pfizer and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines
Explanation: There is no use of pig fat/pork gelatin in the Pfizer and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines, the same is reflected in the list of vaccine ingridients published by the respective companies

Claim: FALSE: An image showing that the Pfizer vaccine is being manufactured in China and is in the form of a vaporizing cartridge
Explanation: The packaging has three errors while the so- called vaccine is actually used for vaping tools

Claim: FALSE: US President Donald Trump wanted to ruin Americans using coronavirus as a weapon. Thousands of people are protesting on the streets against that.
Explanation: The picture is more than three years old and from Spain.

Claim: Misleading: Coronavirus fear in Germany results in large crowds outside a supermarket. People are pushing each other to get into the store first for necessary supplies.
Explanation: This video was uploaded on January 30, 2011 on YouTube, when many people went shopping at an Aldi mall.

Claim: FALSE: Video of People in Italy offering Namaz on the streets due to COVID-19.
Explanation: The video is from Peru and has nothing to do with COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows the first infected patient of COVID-19 at Dhanbad Hospital.
Explanation: This is a mock drill video from PMCH Hospital which shows how COVID-19 patients are tranferred from one place to another.

Claim: FALSE: A photo has been shared in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim it shows labourers stranded in the western Indian state of Gujarat during a nationwide COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: The claim is false; this photo has circulated online since November 2019, months before India imposed its lockdown; it has circulated in reports about Bangladeshi migrants at an immigration office in Malaysia.

Claim: Misleading: Dettol sanitizer kills coronavirus and the company knew about the existence of the virus before the outbreak in China.
Explanation: Dettol kills older strains of coronavirus but has not been tested on the new strain.

Claim: FALSE: Don’t take the vaccine before and after 5 days of your periods because immunity will be very less during periods. Dosage of vaccine first decreases immunity, later it builds immunity so, there is a high risk of attack for one who vaccinated during periods.
Explanation: Claims suggesting women not to take the COVID-19 vaccine 5 days before and after their periods due to its effect on one’s immunity is misleading. There’s no scientific evidence or data to support this claim. Additionally, medical experts have refuted the claim.

Claim: False: A 20-second clip shows a burqa-clad woman having difficulty breathing.
Explanation: The video is not from Islampur in India, but is from Pakistan. The woman does not have the coronavirus.

Claim: False: Most countries affected by COVID-19 are along the same 40-degree north latitude.
Explanation: The 40-degree north latitude passes through some of the countries most affected by COVID-19 but does not pass through half of the locations in the post. It does not touch Wuhan (Hubei Province – where around 60% of all the positive cases are reported), which is at around 30-degree north latitude.

Claim: False: Press Release on movement restriction for COVID-19 outbreak by National Security Council, PMO (India).
Explanation: The press release in the post was issued by the Malaysian Government, not by the Indian Government.

Claim: FALSE: The claim was that ginger powder cured coronavirus positive patients in Mumbai, advised ayurveda as cure
Explanation: WHO said there is no conclusive evidence of any form of cure to coronavirus and the ayurvedic doctor declined to give evidence.

Claim: FALSE: Video showing dead bodies of COVID-19 infected persons washed ashore as they were thrown in the seas by some countries.
Explanation: The video is five years old. It shows dead bodies of African migrants washing ashore as the boat they were travelling in sank off the Libyan coast on its way to Europe.

Claim: FALSE: Political leader from Andra Pradesh made a nurse touch his feet: Image.
Explanation: The nurse in the image is just trying to stop blood coming from the feet of a diabetic person.

Claim: FALSE: Viral quote on economic effects of lockdown attributed to Tata group chairman.
Explanation: Ratan Tata has clarified that he has not made any such statement.

Claim: False: Image of deers roaming in Pudukkottai, Tamil Nadu.
Explanation: The image is from Trincomalee, Sri Lanka.

Claim: FALSE: HOSPITALS ON LOCKDOWN AS FIRST COVID VACCINE PATIENTS START EATING OTHER PATIENTS
Explanation: The photo showing violence in hospital is old and unrelated to COVID vaccination. The viral post is fake.

Claim: FALSE: 100 nurses in Rajasthan’s Jhalawar (India) resigned because of Jamaatis who misbehaved with them.
Explanation: It is true that the nurses had resigned but not because of Jamaatis but alleging low wages, poor working conditions and no protective equipment for the ones working with COVID-19 patients.

Claim: FALSE: ICMR study claims COVID-19 cases to peak in mid November causing paucity of ICUs and Ventilators.
Explanation: ICMR has clarified that they have not conducted this study and also they find the study misleading.

Claim: False: The disaster management act in India prohibits posting messages regarding COVID-19 and would attract punishment to those who don’t obey.
Explanation: The government has clarified there is no such provision that prohibits people from posting about COVID-19 and also there is no provision to prosecute people who post informative content about COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Gilead Sciences announced on May 3 2020 that the new medicine for COVID-19 will be ready by next week.
Explanation: Gilead Sciences has not announced any new medicine for COVID-19. Gilead Sciences chairman and CEO Daniel O’Day said that they intend to get the Remdesivir drug to patients in the early part of this next week. It is mentioned on the Gilead website that Remdesivir is an investigational drug that has not been approved by the FDA for any use. It is not yet known if remdesivir is safe and effective for the treatment of COVID-19.

Claim: Misleading: Muslim youth is spreading COVID-19 by licking plates in Nizamuddin Markaz in India.
Explanation: The video is 2 years old and the people in it belong to Dawoodi Bohra society. In their tradition, dishes are washed only after eating and licking the utensils. This is done so that no food grains are wasted.

Claim: FALSE: Image of Muslims violating lockdown restrictions and praying in Purukathur, Tamil Nadu, India.
Explanation: The image is 5 years old and the superintendent of police of the district has clarified that no such incident has taken place.

Claim: FALSE: A claim was made that India found a cure to coronavirus
Explanation: The headline of the news article is misleading as India has not officially claimed any such cure for coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 vaccine will contain a chip which will help in tracking people
Explanation: We found that the RFID chips will be installed in the vaccine syringes to track the distribution of the vaccines.

Claim: False: President Donald Trump announced a vaccine by Roche Diagnostics.
Explanation: Roche Diagnostics received FDA approval for testing kits, not a vaccine.

Claim: False: Italians bidding goodbye to the world because of coronavirus.
Explanation: The video dates back to November 2019 and has nothing to do with the coronavirus pandemic. It is actually from an anti-fascist protest held in Italy.

Claim: FALSE: Harvard professor arrested for having ties with creating the coronavirus and leaking it.
Explanation: Lieber became a "Strategic Scientist" at Wuhan University of Technology (WUT) in China and was a contractual participant in China's Thousand Talents Plan from in or about 2012 to 2017," the statement said. It also mentioned that Lieber was paid $50,000 per month by WUT, along with a fund of $1.5 million to set up a research lab at Wuhan. He was arrested for fraud but this was not linked to the coronavirus.

Claim: False: Home Ministry of India has issued an order that sharing of any news related to coronavirus is a punishable offense under the IT Act.
Explanation: The viral order is fake and was not issued by the Home Ministry of India.

Claim: Misleading: Clorox Already Knew About coronavirus And coronavirus Isn’t A New Virus.
Explanation: The claim that the new coronavirus was known beforehand on a Clorox label shows that it kills human coronavirus is misleading.

Claim: FALSE: A video of a police officer being beaten up by few people as he opposed them to offer prayers in a temple during the current lockdown, implemented in India to handle COVID-19 spread.
Explanation: The video clip in the post is not a real incident. It's a clip from a web-series. The video was uploaded by a youtube channel called 'Continental Wrestling Entertainment' on 18 June 2019. It has not relating to the existing lockdown conditions in the country.

Claim: FALSE: Chinese eating octopus after surviving coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is unrelated to COVID-19. It is a year old video from Korea

Claim: Misleading: Prince Charles tested positive for COVID-19 after meeting Bollywood singer Kanika Kapoor.
Explanation: The viral picture is old and was taken in 2015 during a charity event by UK royalty Prince Charles and Camilla. The viral claim is misleading.

Claim: FALSE: Pragya Kathua, a comedian from Odia, has died.
Explanation: Pragya Kathua himself has clarified that he is alive.

Claim: FALSE: Spanish cops are beating people during lockdown.
Explanation: The video belongs to the Baku protests in Baku, Azerbaijan that took place in 2019.

Claim: False: Coronavirus patient arrested in Punjab
Explanation: This is a mock drill video from Mansa, Punjab.

Claim: False: A WhatsApp forward claims that the COVID-19 vaccine is ready, was announced by U.S. President Donald Trump, and will be launched next Sunday. It also claims that the vaccine discovered by the U.S. scientists can cure a COVID-19 infected patient within 3 hours. With the WhatsApp forward, the alleged image of the vaccine is also being shared.
Explanation: The image shows a COVID-19 test kit and not a vaccine that can cure the virus. We checked President Trump’s Twitter handle, Facebook page and Instagram profile but didn't find any such announcement by the U.S. president.

Claim: False: “THE CHINESE HAVE BEGUN TO USE THEIR HUMAN CORPSE TO PROCESS INTO PRODUCTS SUCH AS CORNED BEEF TO SHIP TO AFRICA. Please share with your contacts. Very important”
Explanation: The video might be of Tibet or China’s Sichuan as residents of both these territories perform such rituals. However, it is unknown if the visuals in this video belong to Sky Burial. The video is not related to the coronavirus outbreak.

Claim: False: Precautionary measures suggested by UNICEF.
Explanation: The viral message was not issued by UNICEF. Some measures suggested in the message contradict the WHO’S view on COVID-19 and have no scientific evidence.

Claim: FALSE: Pak PM Imran Khan’s wife tested positive for COVID-19.
Explanation: Morphed newscard of popular Indian news channel Aaj Tak was used to spread fake news.

Claim: False: Dettol can kill the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The company said coronavirus cannot be eliminated by using its liquid soap.

Claim: False: Gargling with warm salt water can cure from the coronavirus.
Explanation: Post claiming gargling with warm salt water can save from coronavirus is fake as per health organizations and experts.

Claim: FALSE: Poster allegedly containing guidelines on use of PPE kits for COVID-19 issued by Ministry Of Health and Family Welfare in India.
Explanation: Indian Government has clarified that it has not issued such advisory.

Claim: FALSE: Several people broke the rules of lockdown when they gathered to offer Namaaz (prayers in Muslims) in an area in the city of Delhi.
Explanation: The video of people offering Namaaz was recorded before the lockdown was imposed in India.

Claim: False: Cocaine kills the coronavirus.
Explanation: This post is fake.

Claim: FALSE: Doctor operated and took out the kidney of a covid patient
Explanation: The doctor shown in the video has no connection with coronavirus-infected patient

Claim: Misleading: Coronavirus patients are being caught on highways in China.
Explanation: The video is not about the coronavirus patients being caught, but of the training and mock drill given to the SWAT team in China.

Claim: FALSE: The President of the United States of America Donald Trump has been tested positive for COVID-19.
Explanation: A viral video on social media claimed that US President Donald Trump has been tested positive for coronavirus is misleading. The video has been edited to spread misinformation.

Claim: MISLEADING: 123 countries have ordered the COVID-19 vaccine from Bharath Biotech
Explanation: Bharat Biotech did not mention anywhere about 123 countries ordering their COVID-19 vaccine. It just mentions that it has been approached by several countries across the world for the procurement of COVAXIN. ‘123 countries’ mentioned in the post is about the reach of all of Bharath Biotech’s vaccines

Claim: False: PM Modi has announced the extension of the All-India Lockdown until 5/4/20.
Explanation: No such announcement has been made by Prime Minister Modi or the government. The posted India Today screenshot is a photoshopped version of the original telecast of Modi’s address to the nation on 3/24/20, where he announced the 21-day lockdown from 3/25/20.

Claim: FALSE: “Collective consciousness” on ACE-2 receptors kills Coronavirus.
Explanation: Scientists have appealed to the public to not believe any statements mentioning that ACE-2 receptors kills coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Video of Uttar Pradesh Police catching ‘Coronavirus jihadists’ at Chor Bazaar.
Explanation: The video is that of an ‘anti-terror attack’ mock drill conducted by the Bikapur Police in Ayodhya (Uttar Pradesh, India).

Claim: Misleading: Tonic water and zinc will kill COVID-19.
Explanation: Quinine needs to be given to a patient in a particular dose. It is only given under the doctor’s prescription. In tonic water, the required dose is not present to approach the similar effect of the drug. The claim that tonic water and zinc can kill COVID-19 is misleading.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows Coronavirus leaving the world thanks to clapping hands.
Explanation: There is no evidence that Clapping hands kills coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: TIME Magazine has recognised and applauded Yogi Adityanath’s COVID-19 management
Explanation: UP government had conducted a paid PR exercise

Claim: FALSE: Daniel Radcliffe is the first celebrity to test positive for Coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim was coming from a parody Twitter account. The imposter Twitter account has been suspended for spreading misinformation.

Claim: False: Inhalation of steam from hot water kills COVID-19
Explanation: Inhalation of steam from hot water does not kill coronavirus. There is no research conducted to support the same.

Claim: Misleading: Doctor died after she took diclofenac which reacted with the covid-19 vaccine
Explanation: The doctor received diclofenac as a pain stimulant a month after she was vaccinated

Claim: FALSE: A girl child who was just born in a village in the state of Rajasthan said immediately after the birth that to contain the coronavirus outbreak in India, every person in the country should apply turmeric paste on the toenail on their right foot. The baby died after saying this.
Explanation: The infant in the picture was stillborn. The doctor holding the child in the picture said that the baby was suffering from anencephaly - a serious birth defect - which results in the child being born without parts of brain, scalp and skull.

Claim: FALSE: The are no COVID-19 deaths in Israel as they found a cure for COVID-19, a mixture of lemon and baking soda.
Explanation: As of 20 April 2020, Israel reported 171 deaths due to COVID-19. Also, there is no scientific evidence to suggest that the mixture of lemon and baking soda can kill SARS-CoV-2 virus. As of today, there is no mixture/medicine to prevent or cure COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Video of people of Italy saying goodbye to the world by standing outside a masjid in Milan as they couldn’t control the spread of COVID-19 (SARS-COV-2) virus.
Explanation: The video has been online at least since 26 November 2019 and has no relation with COVID-19. The first COVID-19 case in the world was reported in China in December 2019.

Claim: False: Chicken infected from coronavirus found In Bangalore.
Explanation: The image is old and not related to the 2019 novel coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Overworked Frontline Workers In Sri Lanka
Explanation: The photo is a part of a themed photoshoot that took place in Kerala, India. These are not the frontline workers in South Africa

Claim: False: Russia has unleashed over 500 lions to ensure that people stay inside their homes amid the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The image of a bulletin viral on social media has nothing to do with Russia or the Russian president. The image is from South Africa’s Johannesburg, and the lion was for a film shooting by a production crew.

Claim: FALSE: Image shows the last moments of a mother and child suffering from COVID-19.
Explanation: This image is from Seattle captured in 1985 showing a mother suffering from cancer with her child.

Claim: False: Indian Singer Kanika Kapoor was treated in Mumbai Wockhardt Hospital for COVID-19; the hospital was shut down as staff got infected.
Explanation: Kanika Kapoor is being treated in Indian city of Lucknow's Hospital and not in Mumbai.

Claim: False: Vladimir Putin let lions loose in the streets of Russia to keep them indoors amid COVID-19.
Explanation: The image is from Johannesburg, South Africa, where a lion was released for a video shooting.

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 patinet in Kanpur, India left outside the hopsital without any treatment.
Explanation: The video was deliberately made to harm the reputation of the Hospital and the man in the video is having an epileptic attack. He is not a COVID-19 patient.

Claim: False: Last photo of Indonesian doctor Hadio Ali standing away from his family before he passed away from COVID-19
Explanation: The photo is of a Malaysian doctor not infected by COVID-19 but who is treating COVID-19 patients in Malaysia. This was him before he left for duty.

Claim: FALSE: The image is from Gujarat and shows the condition of migrant workers who are stuck due to the lockdown.
Explanation: The image is being circulated with a misleading claim. It does not show the plight of migrant workers or homeless people in Gujarat but shows Bangladeshi refugees in Malaysia waiting to go back home.

Claim: False: Seeing the rise of novel coronavirus in India, the WHO has recommended the government of India lockdown the country from 4/15/20 to 6/15/20.
Explanation: We reached out to one of the representatives in India, who dismissed the claim and clarified that WHO has not made any such recommendation.

Claim: FALSE: Maharashtra (India)’s CM Uddhav Thackeray announced reimplementation of lockdown.
Explanation: The viral video is an old one where Maharashtra's CM announced lockdown for the first time.

Claim: FALSE: Research by University of Queensland scientists has found that eating a banana daily can prevent coronavirus.
Explanation: Scientists at the University of Queensland have not done any research that proves that eating a banana daily can prevent coronavirus. The claim being made with the viral video is false.

Claim: False: An audio clip of Dr. Naresh Trehan cautioning people about the danger of COVID-19 in India.
Explanation: The audio is not of Dr. Trehan, nor has he said what is claimed in this audio recording.

Claim: MOSTLY FALSE: Coronavirus does not affect people with ‘O+’ blood type.
Explanation: The post claiming coronavirus does not affect people with ‘O+’ blood type is misleading.

Claim: FALSE: Newspaper clipping with a report of 40 students getting hospitalized after the COVID-19 vaccination in India
Explanation: It is an old article reported in 2018 with respect to the Measles-Rubella vaccine. The incident has no connection with the recent COVID-19 vaccination in the country.

Claim: Misleading: A message claimed that Angel Broking has gone bankrupt as oil prices went negative due to coronavirus lockdown around the world
Explanation: Angel Broking merely suspended trade in oil due to price decline and has not gone bankrupt as claimed.

Claim: FALSE: The new coronavirus can be killed from inhaling steam
Explanation: Post claiming coronavirus can be killed from steam therapy is fake. Neither WHO nor CDS have considered steam therapy as a treatment for curing coronavirus infection.

Claim: FALSE: A temple in Andhra Pradesh, India, was turned into a quarantine centre for Muslims.
Explanation: The quarantine centre is actually a lodge with a hindu deity on the entrance, not a temple.

Claim: False: COVID-19 Breeds Rapidly In Toilet Paper.
Explanation: The post is fake and is from an unauthentic website.

Claim: FALSE: Gujarat CM Vijay Rupani said that his government provided ration to 650 million people during the lockdown.
Explanation: The new channel misquoted Gujrati CM. Mr. Rupani, in reality, claimed that 50 million people have been provided ration during the lockdown.

Claim: MISLEADING: A COVID vaccine was developed in Naigaon, in the state of Assam (India).
Explanation: The headline of the article is misleading. A group of researchers are working to develop a vaccine for COVID-19, they haven't developed it yet.

Claim: False: Video of Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang visiting a mosque and offering prayers seeking protection to the country from coronavirus.
Explanation: The man in the video is not Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang. He is former Malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi. The video was taken in 2015 and shows Badawi visiting Nan Xia Po Mosque in Beijing for Friday prayers.

Claim: FALSE: Indian government has started ‘Rashtriya Sikshit Berojgar Yojana’ to provide relief package of Rs 50,000 to all ration cardholders, int he midst of COVID-19 crisis
Explanation: FACTLY has found that there is no such scheme started by the Government of India. Also, the Press Information Bureau (PIB) has clarified the same and termed the message to be fake.

Claim: False: Video showing a larva being extracted from a person’s lip and its relation to the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The viral video has no relation to the 2019 coronavirus. It is an old video, from October 2019.

Claim: FALSE: An article says that Britain has “pulled out” of a 5G contract with Chinese company Huawei because test kits were found to be contaminated with coronavirus.
Explanation: There were some delays in testing kits being delivered to laboratories in the UK, because of contamination, but these were from a Luxembourg-based company called Eurofin, not Huawei. None of the kits were delivered or used in the UK. Telecoms firm Huawei does not produce coronavirus test kits. The UK is going ahead with the development of 5G infrastructure.

Claim: FALSE: Dr. Manish Patil died due to coronavirus in Maharasthra.
Explanation: No, the doctor shown in the viral post did not in Maharastha. The viral photo is from Uttar Pradesh.

Claim: FALSE: US President Donald Trump tested positive for coronavirus.
Explanation: Donald Trump's valet has tested positive for COVID-19, not the President himself.

Claim: False: Video of Muslims being trained to sneeze purposefully to spread coronavirus.
Explanation: It is an old video. While the first COVID-19 positive case in India was reported on 1/30/20 in Kerala, the video was found on the internet at least since 1/29/20 and is being shared in the context of Pakistan. Also, the people in the video were not being trained to spread coronavirus. They are doing a type of Zikr, a Sufi ritual which involves body movement and heavy breathing.

Claim: FALSE: Image of peacocks gathered at Ooty-Coimbatore road in India amid Nationwide Lockdown.
Explanation: The image is from a zoo in Chandigarh.

Claim: FALSE: India Today Ticker that says PM Modi has stated that India has treated 1 crore (10 million) COVID-19 patients for free.
Explanation: PM Modi was speaking about the Ayushman Bharat health insurance scheme and not about COVID-19 patients. The channel apologised and issued a correction a day later

Claim: False: COVID-19 patients will not show symptoms for the first 14 days.
Explanation: According to the WHO website, the incubation period for COVID-19 ranges from 1-14 days. Most commonly COVID-19 patients show symptoms in around five days.

Claim: False: This image is related to the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The image has nothing to do with coronavirus.

Claim: Misleading: A WhatsApp forward claimed that a vaccine for coronavirus has been discovered. It also claims that the treatment for coronavirus is mentioned in India’s Intermediate Zoology book. The viral forward reads, “It is not a new disease as it is already mentioned in the Intermediate Zoology book along with its treatment. It happens sometimes that many great scientists and doctors do not focus on lesser-known books as they are mostly busy with famous books. (Book name: Zoology, Writer: Dr. Ramesh Gupta, Page No. 1072.) Friends, this is not fake news so I request you to kindly share it maximum so all coronavirus patients are treated in time.”
Explanation: The virus discussed in the viral claim is not the novel coronavirus but SARS. The WHO has clearly negated the discovery of any vaccine that can cure COVID-19. In an answer to the question, “Are there any medicines or therapies that can prevent or cure COVID-19?”, the WHO replies, “While some western, traditional or home remedies may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms of COVID-19, there is no evidence that current medicine can prevent or cure the disease."

Claim: Misleading: Sitting in the sunlight will help cure coronavirus.
Explanation: The answer to this statement, according to doctors, is more than just true or false. Professor Ramanan Laxminarayan, Director of Centre for Disease Dynamics, Economics and Policy (CDDEP) said that, “We do not know how heat will affect this coronavirus as of yet. Usually, respiratory pathogens disappear in the summer and in the heat, but we have seen many cases in tropical countries too.”
Originated from: Minister of State, Health, Ashwini Choubey

Claim: False: Oman is releasing a special chemical into the sky to eradicate coronavirus with military helicopters.
Explanation: The Oman health minister said that they had never conducted such operations with military helicopters. When the same message went viral in India, the Press Information Bureau has said that it is a fake message.

Claim: FALSE: Indian PM Narendra Modi has been selected as new chairmant of WHO.
Explanation: There is no such post as Chairman of WHO. Besides, the Indian health minister had been appointed as chair of the WHO executive board.

Claim: Mostly false: Vaccines to cure COVID-19 are ready.
Explanation: Viral image is of a COVID-19 testing kit. A cure is still being researched.

Claim: Misleading: Cow dung and cow urine can cure coronavirus.
Explanation: Dr Sumit Ray, a Senior Consultant, Critical Care Medicine, said that there are no scientific studies to support these claims.

Claim: False: Video of Al-Aqsa mosque after Israel allows photography inside it.
Explanation: The video is not of Al-Aqsa in Jerusalem but Cave of the Patriarchs in Hebron.

Claim: Misleading: An image shared by a Twitter user claims that pregnant cows are slaughtered to produce COVID-19 vaccine. This is done to extract Fetal Bovine Serum (FBS) which is used in the production of many vaccines, reads the image. Additionally, it claims that AIIMS used FBS (supplied by Himedia) in the isolation of SARS-CoV-2, and now ICMR in association with Bharat Biotech is using FBS to produce COVID-19 vaccine.
Explanation: While Fetal Bovine Serum has previously been used in the production of vaccines, the recent claim on ICMR in association with Bharat Biotech using it to produce COVID-19 vaccine is misleading.

Claim: False: Indian government deploying the army in Telangana to curb the coronavirus situation
Explanation: The Telangana Commissioner refuted the claims, there are no plans to deploy army in the Indian state of Telangana.

Claim: FALSE: Muslims flouting social distancing norms in Hyderabad.
Explanation: The video is not from India, but Pakistan.

Claim: FALSE: Indian ministry of Tourism orders closure of hotels, restaurants and resorts till Ocrober 15, 2020.
Explanation: Image of the notice is doctored.

Claim: FALSE: Russia released 500 lions, forcing people to stay indoors given the COVID-19 pandemic.
Explanation: The lion seen in the picture is from Johannesberg, South Africa.

Claim: FALSE: An American CEO drew the Indian map comparing the population of each Indian state to that of countries across the world, highlighting how India is indirectly handling the COVID-19 crisis of so many countries.
Explanation: This particular map has been floating on social media since 2016 and is only comparing the population of Indian states to that of various countries. This is not linked to the coronavirus and does not mention any American CEO.

Claim: False: In the backdrop of the lockdown, videos of wild animals taking over the roads are surfacing on the internet. Among them, a set of pictures of a herd of deer is doing the rounds on social media claiming that these pictures are from Lake Club, Chandigarh.
Explanation: The viral images are not from Chandigarh but from Sanjay Gandhi National Park in Borivali, Mumbai.

Claim: FALSE: Queen Elizabeth II thanks Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi for providing Britain with Covid-19 vaccines.
Explanation: The image has been digitally manipulated to include a fabricated quote from the Queen

Claim: FALSE: WHO Director-General Said He Was Identified As COVID-19 Positive
Explanation: It is not what Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus actually said. He tweeted to inform that he came in contact with someone who had tested positive. The viral post is fake.

Claim: FALSE: A photo of a queue of buses in India has been shared thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim they were organised by a leading opposition politician to transport migrant workers who were left stranded after a nationwide coronavirus lockdown.
Explanation: The claim is false; the photo has circulated in reports since February 2019 about a Hindu festival.

Claim: FALSE: Facebook is using your posts in lawsuits against it amid COVID-19 pandemic
Explanation: The post claiming amid coronavirus pandemic, Facebook has changed its privacy rules, allowing it to use pictures and posts shared by users in lawsuits against them is fake. The post has resurfaced on social media.

Claim: False: Tablik Jamaat Chief Maulana Saad: “If 70,000 people get coronavirus, India will be destroyed. The country will be in our possession.”
Explanation: The audio clip posted by Republic TV as the speech of Tablighi Jamaat Chief, Maulana Saad, doesn't mention that "If 70,000 people get coronavirus, India will be destroyed," as included in the post. Moreover, Republic TV said they are not sure if the person who spoke in the audio clip is Maulana Saad..

Claim: FALSE: A woman feeding her kid in a train is a migrant in a deplorable state caused due to the lockdown.
Explanation: The video is a 2016 video from Bangladesh and is not linked to migrant movement due to the lockdown in India.

Claim: Misleading: World Health Organisation (WHO) has taken a ‘U-turn’ and said that asymptomatic COVID-19 patients needn’t be isolated or quarantined as they cannot spread coronavirus.
Explanation: The WHO has said that asymptomatic spread of the novel coronavirus is rare, they didn’t say that asymptomatic people cannot spread the viral. They further clarified that there isn’t enough data about the asymptomatic spread of the disease, as more research is required to determine the extent of asymptomatic transmission and the research is ongoing. The viral post is misleading.

Claim: FALSE: Ratan Tata has said that human motivation and determined efforts will make experts’ predictions go wrong regarding the fall of the Indian economy during the COVID-19 crisis.
Explanation: Information from no credible source was found which suggested that the lines in the message were written by Ratan Tata. Also, talking to 'News Sense', Mr Debasis Ray (Tata Trust - Corporate Communication) has clarified that Ratan Tata had not written any such post.

Claim: FALSE: A police officer in Bihar’s Hajipur (India) station contracted coronavirus.
Explanation: The video being shared with the claim is a mock drill undertaken by the Hajipur police to train officials to tackle COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Indian Ruling Party BJP’s members burn Kolhapur airport on the night of candle light vigil organized to proclaim unity in fight against COVID-19.
Explanation: An old video was shared to make the false claim.

Claim: Mostly false: Coronavirus has killed 112,000 people and infected 2,800,000 in China.
Explanation: Currently, the coronavirus has killed more than 400 people and infected over 20,000 in China.

Claim: FALSE: Image of a doctor smoking while treating COVID patients in Gujarat, India.
Explanation: The image is not from Gujarat (India) but from Bangladesh and it is not related to COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan read the COVID-19 curve upside down and said that it is flattening.
Explanation: News agency IANS picked the article from a satire website The Dependent. There is no truth to this claim.

Claim: FALSE: A photo of a woman lying in a hospital bed with medical equipment attached to her body has been shared hundreds of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside claims that the woman was a doctor who died after being beaten by a Muslim mob while trying to administer novel coronavirus tests.
Explanation: The claim is false; the late woman's husband and local police told AFP the woman's death was not the result of pandemic-related violence.

Claim: FALSE: Omani princess Sayyida Mona bint Fahd al Said tweets against India.
Explanation: The Omani princess has clarified that a tweet from a fake account in her name is going viral and she has no association with the impersonator or the tweet.

Claim: FALSE: Indian business tycoon Ratan Tata said, the Year 2020 is the year of survival.
Explanation: Ratan Tata himself clarified that the fake quote is being attributed to his name. He did not such a statement.

Claim: FALSE: This is a recent picture where hospitals show dogs inside the ward
Explanation: Old picture from Bihar viral is now being related to the new coronavirus

Claim: False: Muslims intentionally licking the cutlery and plates to spread COVID-19.
Explanation: People shown in the video are of Dawoodi Bohra religion and people of this community do not waste food. That is why after eating, they lick all the utensils such as plates, spoons and bowls to insure no food wastage and then wash them.

Claim: FALSE: Cop is extorting money from migrant labourers who want to return home due to the lockdown.
Explanation: The video is from 2019 and it shows a railway protection force personnel accepting money from women bootleggers in Surat.

Claim: FALSE: People in USA march and call for the arrest of Bill Gates.
Explanation: According to our research on this video, we find that videos of protests against lockdown in the United States have been fabricated and shared with misleading claims including Bill Gates’s arrest.

Claim: FALSE: A video showing migrant laborers from Surat city, in India, are being sent back to Surat after their home states refused to take them back at the state border.
Explanation: The video, in reality, shows migrants being halted for testing at the border of Rajasthan. Local police have confirmed to us that they were not sent back.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows a bank manager being fined for not wearing a mask in Bihar, India.
Explanation: The video is not from Bihar. It is actually from Rajasthan. It is falsely shared with the wrong claim.

Claim: Misleading: Going near a fire or stove after applying hand sanitizers, causes more fire as it contains alcohol.
Explanation: Any genuine hand sanitizer applied on your hands will not cause any fire as it evaporates within seconds.

Claim: Misleading: Dettol sanitizer can kill tthe coronavirus. The company knew about the coronavirus back in 2019.
Explanation: The Dettol bottle refers to the previous strains of coronavirus, not COVID-19. The manufacturer cannot confirm levels of effectiveness against the new strain.

Claim: Misleading: Muslims are violating the ongoing lockdown norms which prohibits religious gatherings.
Explanation: A two month old video showing Muslims offering namaz in Delhi has been passed off on social media calling it as a recent one. The video was shot before the imposition of lockdown in the country.

Claim: Misleading: Applying mustard oil in your nostrils will kill coronavirus.
Explanation: We spoke to some doctors and medical experts who rubbished the claim and said there is no study to back this claim.

Claim: Misleading: Tea has ingredients to ward off any coronavirus infection.
Explanation: Tea does contain methylxanthine that is used in asthma drugs but no therapeutic evidence for coronavirus has been established.

Claim: Misleading: Coronil drops can help cure coronavirus.
Explanation: Leading homeopaths say little is known about the composition of this medicine and it is careless to recommend it for coronavirus

Claim: False: A video shows a truck dropping bodies covered with plastic into a ditch and claiming that this is the situation in Italy right now.
Explanation: The video which is being widely circulated on social media is not from Italy. It is a movie scene that had been taken from the 2007 U.S. television miniseries "Pandemic."

Claim: False: Gargling with warm salt water can cure from the coronavirus.
Explanation: Post claiming gargling with warm salt water can save from coronavirus is fake as per health organizations and experts.

Claim: FALSE: Video showing Manoj Tiwary, leader of the ruling party of India, voilated lockdown and distributing masks among crowd.
Explanation: The viral video is old and depicts an incident happened before the lockdown was implemented in India.

Claim: FALSE: Indian opposition leader Rahul Gandhi suggested that schools and colleges should reopen from 1st June on an odd-even basis.
Explanation: This is a fake tweet and Rahul Gandhi did not tweet any such news.

Claim: FALSE: Lockdown in South Africa has collapsed. People are out on the streets because due to hunger.
Explanation: Contrary to the claims, the video is from 2018 when a shop in Mitchells Plain was vandalised following violent protests in the area.

Claim: Mostly false: The WHO has released “protocols and procedures” of lockdown periods to fight COVID-19.
Explanation: The WHO has not released any such protocol for lockdown periods.

Claim: FALSE: A video of an overcrowded Shramik train claimed to be from Mumbai travelling to West Bengal.
Explanation: The video is from Bangladesh in 2018 when Bangladeshi migrants were travelling in the special Bishwa Ijtema train.

Claim: FALSE: RSS (a right-wing group in India) chief Mohan Bhagwat said that coronavirus has shaken his belief in religion.
Explanation: RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat has made no such statement.
Originated from: A morphed newspaper clipping on Facebook & Twitter

Claim: False: Indian Actor Kamal Hassan put under quarantine.
Explanation: Kamal Hassan and his party has issued an official statement saying there was a misunderstanding between officials as his daughter has self-isolated herself. It was presumed that Hassan had met his daughter in Mumbai. However, he did not meet his daughter and later the officials were also convinced about it and they removed a quarantine poster from his wall.

Claim: False: Bollywood actor Shahrukh Khan donated 45 Crore (450 million) rupees to Pakistan.
Explanation: The video is a clipped version of India TV’s fact-check video. In the original fact-check video, India TVdebunked the same claim and concluded that Shahrukh has not made any donation to Pakistan Oil tanker blast victims.

Claim: False: To defeat the coronavirus, China built a thousand-bed hospital in 10 days, while India has prepared a modern hospital of 6,370 beds overnight, at a very low cost.
Explanation: A close study on the viral claim revealed that a 6,370-bed hospital has not been constructed overnight in the country. Isolation wards have been made in some bogies of the country's first medical train Jeevan Rekha, which was run in 1991.

Claim: FALSE: Dr. Megha Vyas from Pune died of COVID-19.
Explanation: The woman claimed to be Dr. Megha Vyas is a housewife from Pune who died of severe Pneumonia and not COVID-19.

Claim: False: There are 59 positive coronavirus cases in Nagpur along with three doctors, one of whom is on ventilator.
Explanation: There are five coronavirus cases in Nagpur as of 3/26/20. None of them is a doctor.

Claim: FALSE: India is suing Microsoft founder Bill Gates because of his vaccine against coronavirus that killed 77,000 girls.
Explanation: The actual photo is not recent, but one taken in 2018 during a workshop between the NIH and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. And only seven girls died after participating in an HPV vaccine trial, though their deaths were also unrelated to the drug. It's not related to coronavirus.

Claim: False: Dr. Naresh Trehan has said that the Indian government is going to declare a national emergency.
Explanation: This is a hoax. Dr Trehan's office has not issued any such message.

Claim: FALSE: Mountain Matterhorn in Switzerland was lit in three colours of Indian flag as a token of gratitude to India for sending Hydroxychloroquine.
Explanation: The Indian national flag was projected on the mountain Matterhorn as an expression of solidarity in fight against COVID-19. Not just India but flags of other countries were also projected on various days on the Matterhorn mountain.

Claim: False: A video of a Muslim man spitting on police to spread coronavirus when he was being taken into custody.
Explanation: The person (Mohammed Sohail Shoukath Ali) in the video is under trial. He spat on police as they didn't allow him to eat the food brought by his family members. This has no relation to coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 patients in Gujarat are being segregated on the basis of religion at Ahmedabad Civil Hospital.
Explanation: On the basis of the statement of Dr. Rathod of Ahmedabad Civil Hospital and a clear denial of several government bodies, we reached the conclusion that the two outlets mentioned above, published a ‘False’ report which was later amplified by several verified Twitter handles.

Claim: False: A Facebook user uploaded a video showing a man inside a police van spitting on a cop. The post claimed that this video is a proof that Tablighi community is spreading coronavirus in India.
Explanation: The video viral on social media in the backdrop of the Nizamuddin Markaz incident is misleading. The video has no connection with the ongoing novel coronavirus pandemic. A 26-year-old under trial allegedly attacked a few policemen for not allowing him to have home-cooked food brought by his family.

Claim: FALSE: A video claimed a food packaging worker in a restaurant is viciously blowing air through mouth into plastic food bags as coronavirus continues to spread.
Explanation: This old video was denied by Singapore Food Authority one year ago. It resurfaced amid the coronavirus crisis.

Claim: FALSE: Lockdown is being boycotted in this way abroad and here lockdown is awaited, God is the owner
Explanation: The claim being made about the viral picture has turned out to be fake. The photo related to the protest against the then President in Algeria is being shared now with a false claim.

Claim: FALSE: Claim that Indian actor Jaaved Jaaferi tweeted that it is not necessary that the Muslim fruit vendors applying spit on fruits should be COVID-19 positive
Explanation: This is a doctored tweet and the actor has not made any such statement on Muslim vendors not spreading coronavirus

Claim: FALSE: Rahul Gandhi has suggested a possible way to reopen schools/colleges.
Explanation: The tweet is fake.

Claim: False: Pakistan’s PM Imran Khan tested COVID-19 positive.
Explanation: Pakistan's Senator Faisal Javed Khan clearing the air, denied the claim, further asked the news network to correct the report. The Pakistani politician said, "News regarding PM Imran Khan tested positive for COVID-19 is not true. Please refrain from spreading fake news."

Claim: FALSE: Viral Whatsapp message claiming to be a roadmap on easing lockdown restrictions in India.
Explanation: Press Information Bureau of India has clarified that this message is fake and not issued by the government.

Claim: FALSE: Hindus were not allowed to receive food being distributed in a mosque in India during the lockdown.
Explanation: The incident is from Bangladesh where Hindus were not allowed to collect food from the mosque and is not from India

Claim: False: Chinese prime minister visits a mosque following the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The man in the video is former Malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi. The video was shot during his visit to Beijing’s Nan Xia Po Mosque in July 2015.

Claim: Misleading: Telangana Ministry in India distributed homeopathic tablets claiming to prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence to support the claim that arsenicum album prevents coronavirus.

Claim: False: Images showing vaccines for coronavirus have already been discovered, were patented and will be readily available.
Explanation: Images of test kits and patents of other coronavirus strains are being falsely shared as COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Video of women jumping from a building after being locked by the Indian police for shopping during the lockdown in the country to contain COVID-19 spread.
Explanation: The video was found on YouTube and Facebook in 2015 with the title: ‘Sex workers fleeing after FIA raid at a brothel in Karachi’. It is an old video and is not related to the current lockdown.

Claim: FALSE: Overcrowded train carrying migrants from Mumbai to West Bengal, flouting lockdown norms in India.
Explanation: The video is as old as 2018 and is not from India but Bangladesh.

Claim: False: Image attributed to Italian Prime Minister suggesting Italy has lost control.
Explanation: Image of Brazilian Prime Minister Bolsonaro crying at an event was falsely shared as the Italian president.

Claim: Partially false: COVID-19 is not new and old textbook lists its treatment
Explanation: Post Claiming Old Textbook Mentions COVID-19 Cure is misleading and has resurfaced on social media.

Claim: FALSE: Israel has no deaths from COVID-19; tea made of lemon and bicarbonate can cure coronavirus.
Explanation: The post claiming Israel has no deaths from COVID-19 is false. And, hot tea made of lemon and bicarbonate is not a cure for the novel coronavirus.

Claim: False: WhatsApp group admins were detained for sharing coronavirus messages in Dadar, Mumbai.
Explanation: Mumbai Police spokesperson dismissed the claim that Mumbai police's cyber cell was registering cases against 52 WhatsApp group admins and called it fake.

Claim: False: Two audio clips stating that the Mumbai police commissioner is going to enforce strict actions during the 21-day lockdown in India and that there will be a spike in cases after March 27, 2020.
Explanation: Mumbai Police officials denied that this audio was of the city police commissioner. The voices in both the videos were different.

Claim: FALSE: An Image is being shared on social media claiming; this italian doctor couple in the picture worked day and night and saved the lives of 134 patients, but on the eighth day, they caught coronavirus and died after an hour.
Explanation: The couple in the picture is not Italian but a couple from Spain. The photograph was taken at Barcelona Airport on March 12, 2020.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows a huge crowd of migrant workers gathered in Maharashtra amid COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: The video is actually from Delhi. It is being shared falsely in the name of different cities of Maharashtra and Gujarat.

Claim: False: A photo shows dead people on the streets of China.
Explanation: Taken in 2014 in Frankfurt, Germany, the photo shows victims of a Nazi concentration camp and has nothing to do with the coronavirus pandemic.

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 Means ‘See A Sheep Surrender’ In Latin
Explanation: COVID-19 Doesn’t Mean ‘See A Sheep Surrender’ In Latin. Vishvas News spoke to Dr Jonathan Wallis, a Latinist and lecturer in Classics at Australia’s University of Tasmania, who said there are no latin language connections to COVID-19. The word for sheep in latin is "ovis" not "ovid."

Claim: False: As per Home Ministry of India, sharing information related to the coronavirus is now a punishable offense.
Explanation: We found that there is no official named Ravi Nayak in MHA, India, as claimed in the viral message. Also, there was no official notice on the website on MHA. It is evident from our fact check that the message viral on social media claiming to be from the Home Ministry of India is false.

Claim: False: China seeks court’s approval to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients.
Explanation: The claim is fake.

Claim: FALSE: Coronavirus-positive patients listening to Gurbani Kirtan in a hospital in Italy.
