Explanation: Video is one year old. It shows a program held in a Canadian retirement home.

Claim: False: An audio clip is circulating on Whatsapp claiming that Nagpur (Second Capital of Indian state Maharashtra) has tested 59 positive coronavirus cases including three doctors.
Explanation: We found there are only four positive coronavirus cases in Nagpur. The district administration and Nagpur Municipal Corporation have denied such rumors. Divisional Commissioner of Nagpur said the administration would take stern action against such rumor mongers. The Deputy Commissioner confirmed the same.

Claim: FALSE: An image of people sleeping in a lobby is being shared with a claim that this image is from Gujarat where the lockdown is not being followed.
Explanation: After closely studying the claim that has gone viral on social media platforms, we found that the picture of workers sleeping in the lobby is being shared with misleading claims. Our investigation revealed that the old picture of Malaysia is being shared as Gujarat.

Claim: FALSE: Brahma Kamal flowers bloom after many years due to less pollution during the lockdown in India to contain COVID-19 spread.
Explanation: The video used to make the claim is found to be on the internet at least since December 2017. Also, Brahma Kamal flowers usually bloom every year during June – September, and the flowers can be seen till mid-October. Hence there is no relation between the flower blooming and less pollution.

Claim: FALSE: IndianTelecommunication Department offering free internet services during lockdown to work from home.
Explanation: The link is a clickbait link to download apps on playstore. Indian government has made no such announcement.

Claim: False: A photo shows coronavirus victims in China.
Explanation: The photo taken in 2014 shows people lying down in a pedestrian zone in Frankfurt, Germany, as part of an art project remembering victims of the Katzbach concentration camp.

Claim: MISLEADING: Indian Prime Minister said world will be free from coronavirus in a month.
Explanation: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi told the people that with restraint and vigilance, there is 'hope' that the world will come out of the danger of coronavirus before Eid. PM Modi did not say anywhere that the world would be freed from Coronavius in a month. It became clear in our investigation that Dainik Jagran has published the news with a misleading title.

Claim: FALSE: A large Muslim crowd in the indian city of Haldwani stone pelted doctors when they tried to quarantine the Imam.
Explanation: People in Haldwani did not beat or stone pelt any doctors or policemen who came to quarantine the Imam.

Claim: False: Video of President Donald Trump announcing that Roche Medical Company will launch the vaccine for COVID-19 next Sunday.
Explanation: In the video, American President Donald Trump didn't say that Roche Medical Company will launch the vaccine for COVID-19. He announced the FDA’s approval of a coronavirus "test" developed by a company named Roche to accelerate the country’s capacity to test for the virus.

Claim: False: Coronavirus will be cured after a 14-hour curfew.
Explanation: The novel coronavirus has different life spans on different objects. However, it can live up to 2 to 3 days.

Claim: Mostly false: Novel coronavirus can be eliminated by drinking lots of water and gargling with warm water mixed with salt or vinegar.
Explanation: There is no evidence to support the claim.

Claim: FALSE: Indian Spritual Guru Mata Amrithanandamayi Charitable trust gifts India its first “Air Ambulance”.
Explanation: Mata Amritanandamayi charitable trust has clarified that they haven't donated an "Air ambulance" nor its hospital has "air ambulance" services.

Claim: FALSE: UV rays from the sun can cure COVID-19.
Explanation: No, UV Rays from the sun cannot cure COVID-19. Viral post is misleading.

Claim: FALSE: News anchor of Malayalam news channel Twenty Four News claims Congress leaders demonstrating at Walayar check post came in contact with the newly detected COVID patient from that area.
Explanation: The news anchor has clarified to us that he has not made any such claim. We also spoke to Congress MP Remya Haridas who was present at the time of demonstration and she also told us that no outsider was allowed in their demonstration.

Claim: FALSE: A young man in a van spit on a policeman to spread the coronavirus.
Explanation: The spitting incident has no relation with coronavirus. The incident took place with the Thane police on February 29. A prisoner had spit on a policeman.

Claim: FALSE: Dr. Manisha Patil died due to COVID-19 while treating coronavirus patients in Maharashtra, India.
Explanation: This is Dr. Richa Rajpoot from Kanpur who is healthy and alive. She is not a COVID-19 treating doctor.

Claim: False: People in Italy have thrown all of their money on the roads outside saying that this money is useless to save them from death.
Explanation: The images doing rounds on social media are not from Italy but from Venezuela when the country was facing economic collapse in 2018.

Claim: FALSE: Pakistan’s PM Imran Khan’s wife has been detected with coronavirus.
Explanation: Photoshopped image of Aaj Tak news channel is being shared to spread this false news. Pakistani officials have refuted such claims.

Claim: False: The WHO has issued an alert against buying holy colors from China
Explanation: The WHO hasn't issued an advisory against buying Holi colors from coronavirus-hit China. The claim is fake.

Claim: MIsleading: Family of deceased due to coronavirus will get Rs 2 Lakh under PMSBY
Explanation: No, family of deceased due to coronavirus will not get Rs 2 Lakh under PMSBY, viral post is misleading

Claim: Misleading: Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal is not wearing masks himself while he asks others to do so
Explanation: The picture is from 2019 when Kejriwal was distributing masks to protect against air pollution

Claim: Misleading: A WhatsApp forward claimed that a vaccine for coronavirus has been discovered and that the treatment for coronavirus is mentioned in an Intermediate Zoology book.
Explanation: The viral forward reads, “It is not a new disease as it is already mentioned in the Intermediate Zoology book along with its treatment. It happens sometimes that many great scientists and doctors do not focus on lesser-known books. (Book name: "Zoology," Writer: Dr. Ramesh Gupta, Page No. 1072.) Friends, this is not fake news so I request you to kindly share it maximum so all coronavirus patients are treated in time.” The treatments mentioned in the viral page of the book are not for coronavirus but for common cold caused by a coronavirus. The viral claim that there is pre-existing medication for coronavirus is misleading.

Claim: False: Image of dead bodies of coronavirus victims in Italy.
Explanation: The image shows coffins containing the dead bodies of Lampedusa shipwreck victims. In 2013, a boat packed with around 500 African migrants caught fire and sank around half a mile from the Italian island Lampedusa, causing the deaths of more than 300 people.

Claim: False: Ministry of Home Affairs in India has directed people to not post anything related to coronavirus.
Explanation: The message has been undersigned by the Principal Secretary to the Home Minister but in reality there is no such post by a person in the ministry.

Claim: False: Video of police strictly implementing lockdown in Spain.
Explanation: The video is not related to a COVID-19 lockdown in any country. The video shows Azerbaijan Police (not Spain) dispersing a protest in October 2019.

Claim: MISLEADING: The number of coronavirus patients in the country can reach close to 30 million by August 15. Central Indian government is warning states.
Explanation: During the search, it was revealed that Cabinet Secretary Rajiv Gaba has discussed further strategies on lockdown including basic problems like the country's economy, civil security, prevention on coronavirus. There is no doubt that coronavirus cases are increasing rapidly in many states of the country. But there is no evidence anywhere that the cabinet secretary has told the states that by August 15, the number of coronavirus patients in the country will be 30 million.

Claim: FALSE: A mosque in India that was distributing relief material to Muslims during the lockdown denied help to some needy Hindus who reached there, saying that there was no facility for Hindus.
Explanation: The mosque where the incident took place is in Bangladesh, not India.

Claim: FALSE: Eminent Indian Bengali Chemist Dr. Prafulla Chandra Roy invented hydroxychloroquine.
Explanation: The first known use of quinine is from 17th century Peru, where bark of the Cinchona tree was used for the treatment of fever. During WWII Germany developed Resochin followed by the US who developed Hydroxychloroquine in 1934.

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 testing patent was filed in 2015, thus covid19 is a scam
Explanation: Vishvas News investigated the post and found that the viral image is the screenshot of the child application that was filed in year 2020 following the submission of the parent patent application in 2015 that was not related to COVID-19. In fact, the parent application is generalized for a method of “acquiring and transmitting biometric data.” The post is viral with the fake claim.

Claim: FALSE: Indian nurses resigned due to COVID-19 infected Jamati patients misbehavior.
Explanation: The nurses resigned due to low wages, not because of patients behavior.

Claim: FALSE: There will be complete lockdown on June 15th in India.
Explanation: Zee News did not make any such claim regarding lockdown, this viral post is fake.

Claim: FALSE: Brahmins (a Higher Indian Caste) chopped off a girl’s tongue as an offering to God to prevent COVID-19 infection.
Explanation: The incident is not related with Brahmins or caste system . The girl herself chopped off her own tongue as an offering to prevent COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: A woman in Uttar Pradesh threw her five children into the river as they had no food to eat during the current lockdown.
Explanation: While it is true that a woman in Uttar Pradesh had thrown her five children into the river, it is not due to the unavailability of food. The Bhadohi Police has clarified that the woman took such a drastic step after she quarrelled with her husband, not because of hunger.

Claim: FALSE: Migrants are defying lockdown and have taken to Ahmedabad’s streets in India.
Explanation: The pictures are from Telangana of May 4 when many migrants had flocked Hyderabad once they heard about the shramik trains.

Claim: Misleading: Tea can cure coronavirus.
Explanation: Doctors and experts say that there is no scientific evidence to prove that tea can be used to cure coronavirus.

Claim: False: A post has been shared on Facebook, Twitter and Whatsapp claims a regional government in India has recommended that the juice of bitter gourd, a vegetable often used in traditional medicine, is an effective treatment for the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Indian authorities call it “absolutely false" and health experts said there is no evidence the vegetable is an effective remedy for COVID-19.

Claim: : Experts in China found that the coronavirus can be spread through houseflies.
FALSE: Japan’s Nobel Prize winning Professor of Medicine, Professor Dr Tasuku Honjo has claimed that the coronavirus is not natural and that China manufactured it.
Explanation: As the message went viral, Kyoto University has published a statement on behalf of Professor Tasuku Honjo. Tasuku Honjo in his statement said, ‘I am greatly saddened that my name and that of Kyoto University have been used to spread false accusations and misinformation’

Claim: FALSE: Ministry of AYUSH has removed Dr. Mujahid Hussain from service because he banned Baba Ramdev’s medicine Coronil.
Explanation: The ministry has clarified that it has not removed any doctor or medical officer from duty or service at any time in the recent past.

Claim: Misleading: COVID-19 is not new and an old textbook gives out its treatment.
Explanation: The textbook does mentions the details of coronavirus but it is not related to COVID-19. Other strains of coronavirus existed from before but COVID-19 is a new strain in the coronavirus family. Its vaccine is not created as of now but clinical trials are undergoing.

Claim: FALSE: Fit people are immune to novel coronavirus
Explanation: Fake post claims that novel coronavirus only affects people who do not do workout and people who exercise are immune from coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: A doctor at the SGRH hospital in New Delhi, India prescribed hydroxychloroquine tablet to prevent COVID-19 infection.
Explanation: The prescription is a fake one forging the handwriting, stamp and signature of the said doctor.

Claim: False: Precautionary measures suggested by UNICEF.
Explanation: The viral message was not issued by UNICEF. Some of the measures have no scientific evidence.

Claim: False: Indian Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) issued an order that sharing a post about coronavirus on social media groups is a punishable offense.
Explanation: Press Information Bureau (PIB) has clarified that the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) has not issued any order stating that posting anything related to coronavirus on social media is a punishable offense.

Claim: FALSE: A message of key takeaways from an interview of HDFC bank MD & CEO Aditya Puri, where he has said how India will survive the coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: A few points of the message have been taken from Aditya Puri's interview, but they are incorrectly associated with coronavirus. Most other points in the message are not said by Mr. Puri.

Claim: : Drinking lots of water and gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar eliminates the novel coronavirus. Spread the information as you can save someone.
False: European Health Organization (EHO) announced that eating beef can cure coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no official institution with the name European Health Organization (EHO). Also, no authority in the European Union has announced that eating beef will cure coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Italians threw away money because of COVID-19.
Explanation: The money seen on the streets was old currency thrown away by Venezualan citizens.

Claim: FALSE: Video of Migrant workers escaping from a train carrying them to Assam in Nagaon, India by stopping the train.
Explanation: The video being shared is from Jalpaiguri in West Bengal and has got nothing to do with Assam.

Claim: FALSE: World’s first COVID-19 vaccine developed by Russia was given to President Vladimir Putin’s daughter.
Explanation: The viral video shows Natalya, a medical student, who had taken part in the trials of Russian COVID-19 vaccine.

Claim: FALSE: A year ago, 14-year-old astrologer Abhigyan Anand had made a prediction about thecoronavirus.
Explanation: We listened to the said video which was uploaded on 22 august 2019 but the name of coronavirus was not mentioned anywhere in the 15 min long video.
Originated from: Many media outlets, Facebook, WhatsApp, Twitter

Claim: FALSE: Claim that India civic bodies have made COVID-19 testing mandatory for people above 50 years of age.
Explanation: False as COVID testing is not made mandatory by municipal corporations for people aged 50 and above

Claim: FALSE: Government of India will provide a relief package of Rs 50,000 to ration card-holders under its scheme ‘Rashtriya Sikhshit Berojgar Yojna’.
Explanation: The Indian central government has not launched any such scheme and the website is fraudulent.

Claim: Misleading: Gargling with hot water can prevent coronavirus infection.
Explanation: Experts and doctors say that there is no evidence to support this claim. Dr Suranjit Chatterjee, senior consultant with Indraprastha Apollo Hospitals, said drinking hot water can be beneficial for a sore throat and generally helps with fighting certain symptoms but is not a medical treatment.

Claim: Misleading: A video is being shared on various social media platforms and in WhatsApp groups in which a person allegedly infected with COVID-19 can be seen lying unconscious on the ground and shaking violently.
Explanation: According to the testimony of a doctor working in the hospital, the person shown in the video is not infected with COVID-19 but having an epilepsy attack. It can be concluded that the video is being shared with a misleading claim.

Claim: FALSE: ‘Dr. VK Srinivas, Vice-President of Bharath Biotech, He is taking first injection of COVID-19 vaccine. They have confidence in their product’
Explanation: The Vishvas News found in its investigation that this viral post is false. Dr. VK Srinivas was giving his blood sample for routine procedure when this photo was taken. He did not participate in COVID-19 clinical trial.

Claim: False: One can get free masks from the government to fight coronavirus by filling this form in the web link.
Explanation: These are dubious web links. The government is not making any such offer.

Claim: MISLEADING: A video puts forward measures to cure COVID-19.
Explanation: The video does not mention any cures. It does give tips to boost immunity, BUT not to cure the virus.

Claim: Misleading: Muslims are violating the ongoing lockdown norms which prohibits religious gatherings.
Explanation: A two month old video showing Muslims offering namaz in Delhi has been passed off on social media calling it as a recent one. The video was shot before the imposition of lockdown in the country.

Claim: FALSE: Coronavirus vaccine contains pig fat
Explanation: The key vaccines which have been granted approval so far do not contain pig fat in them.

Claim: FALSE: An American CEO drew the Indian map comparing the population of Indian states to those of countries across the world highlighting India’s brilliant response to tackle COVID-19.
Explanation: This particular map has been floating on social media since 2016 and is only comparing India's population. This is not linked to the coronavirus and does not mention any American CEO.

Claim: False: A video of fire is shared with the claim that a fire erupted at Solapur Airport in Maharashtra state due to firecrackers on 4/5/20 at 9p.m.
Explanation: Upon our investigation, we found that the viral video shows a two-months-old incident. It has nothing to do with the prime minister's call for a nationwide candlelight vigil on 4/5/20 at 9 p.m.

Claim: False: Amitabh Bachchan gave 500 million rupees to the Mumbai government to fight the coronavirus.
Explanation: A part of an old video of Amitabh Bachchan and Narendra Modi is viral with false claims. Amitabh has not given a check of Rs. 500 crores to Bombay Municipal Corporation nor to Government of Maharashtra. He has not even met Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi recently.

Claim: FALSE: Central government rejects Kerala government’s appeal to dispatch planes to retrieve Indian expats stuck in Gulf countries.
Explanation: The state government did make a request to MEA but the MEA didn't turn it down as claimed in the post. Since all flights have been suspended due to lock down, planes could not be dispatched but they are still in process to find a way to help lacs of Indians stuck in the Gulf countries. The state government also expressed satisfaction with the ministry's response.

Claim: FALSE: A poster stating Pakistan has asked for hydroxychloroquine instead of Kashmir.
Explanation: The image is originally a poster held by Kashmiris demanding Azaadi and is not related to the coronavirus.

Claim: False: A video of a woman reciting Sanskrit verses has been viewed thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that she was delivering sacred verses on a Spanish radio station during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The claim is false. The video was recorded by a London-based Sanskrit teacher who published the footage on her official social media accounts in November 2019, weeks before the novel coronavirus outbreak.

Claim: FALSE: Inhaling steam kills the coronavirus.
Explanation: Inhaling steam does not kill coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: A video allegedly showing a man spitting on the bread slices is being shared with a communal spin in India.
Explanation: This is an old video from the Philippines. The bread company has clarified that the video shows a delivery man taking slices of bread from loaf packs. The slices he took were from pulled out loaves from stores which will be returned to the plant for disposal, NOT from fresh stocks for delivery to stores.

Claim: FALSE: The video shows lockdown violation, Muslims offering namaz on roadside.
Explanation: Video of Muslims offering Namaz on the roadside is old. This happened before lockdown.

Claim: MISLEADING: Vaccine does not help the recipient in any way.
Explanation: The claims made in the viral message are manipulated and false. Research shows that vaccines will help in curbing the pandemic

Claim: FALSE: Muslims are hoarding food that is distributed in the lockdown.
Explanation: The video is of a leprosy shelter where food was given as donation. The food in the clip is leftover, unused food from the donation.

Claim: FALSE: Image showing a mother hugging her baby infected with COVID-19 inside a laminar airflow room.
Explanation: The image is 35 year old and has got nothing to do with COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Video of member of Indian parliament Rahul Gandhi stating that the red zones are green zones and green zones are red zones amidst the COVID-19 situation.
Explanation: This is a 6 second clipped video of a longer press conference shared out of context to mislead users.

Claim: False: Coronavirus dies at a temperature above 26-27 degrees Celsius as per UNICEF.
Explanation: The claim was not issued by UNICEF.

Claim: False: A line of coffins suggesting they are from Italy currently.
Explanation: This image from 2013 shows migrants dying in a shipwreck.

Claim: False: Japanese doctors claim drinking water every 15 minutes prevents COVID-19.
Explanation: No Japanese advisory has been issued regarding frequent consumption of water. The WHO has clarified that drinking water will not prevent a coronavirus infection.

Claim: FALSE: Doctor suggests that empty nebulisers can replace oxygen cylinders to help patients who need oxygen
Explanation: The hospital distanced itself from the doctor's claims and there is no scientific evidence supporting the same

Claim: False: Photo of meat (mutton) affected by coronavirus.
Explanation: The image is photoshopped. There is no proof that coronavirus is present in mutton.

Claim: FALSE: Muslim women were caught shopping in lockdown.
Explanation: After closely studying the claim that is going viral on social media, we found that this video is from Karachi, Pakistan. The building that shows men and women jumping from the balcony is a 2015 video. The viral video has nothing to do with the coronavirus or India.

Claim: False: India’s Minister of State for AYUSH Shripad Naik held a press conference claiming that Prince Charles followed the rules of Ayurveda, which is why he is recovering so soon.
Explanation: Ella Lynch, a spokesperson for the Royal House of England, told The India Express via gmail that false claims were being made in the media about Prince Charles recovering from a coronavirus infection.

Claim: FALSE: Riots in London due to the unavailability of food items. The United Kingdom will be locked down by tonight. Army soldiers take to the UK streets.
Explanation: The video is not related to coronavirus but with London riots that happened in 2011. The 2011 England riots, more widely known as the London Riots, were a series of riots between 6 and 11 August 2011, when thousands of people rioted in cities and towns across England, saw looting, arson, and mass deployment of police, and resulted in the deaths of five people.

Claim: False: Drinking alcohol kills the coronavirus.
Explanation: Drinking alcohol does not cure coronavirus. Alcohol in sanitizers does have an effect on the virus.

Claim: FALSE: A video purports to show a police officer being beaten has been viewed tens of thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that the assault at a temple in India was sparked by the officer’s attempt to enforce a nationwide novel coronavirus lockdown.
Explanation: The claim is false; the footage was taken from a video of a staged fight that was uploaded to a wrestling-themed YouTube channel in June 2019.

Claim: False: Chennai municipal corporation has asked all vegetable and fruit markets to shut down.
Explanation: No such order was issued. All vegetable and fruit markets are open in Chennai.

Claim: FALSE: Bill Gates tried to get a patent for N-95 masks.
Explanation: There is no patent for N-95 masks in Bill Gate's name.

Claim: False: A worker at the Prince hotel in Mehdipatnam (Hyderbad, India) has tested positive for coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is fake. In Telangana state, as of 3/12/20, only one confirmed case of coronavirus is reported and the person who tested positive is a software engineer.

Claim: FALSE: Image of a critically ill COVID-19 infected woman hugging her child for the last time before her death
Explanation: The woman in the image is not infected with COVID-19. The image is an old one and is not related to any recent incident. It was found to exist on the internet at least since 1997.

Claim: FALSE: Video of Byculla (Maharashtra) MLA Waris Pathan threatening Police to open a mosque during the existing lockdown impplemented to contain COVID-19 spread.
Explanation: The video used to claim that Byculla (Maharashtra) MLA Waris Pathan threatening Police to open a mosque is an old one and is not related to any recent incident. It is related to an argument erupted in November 2016, between Byculla MLA Waris Pathan and local Police over the volume of loudspeaker in a mosque.

Claim: FALSE: In India, BJP Leader Manoj Tiwari violating lockdown and moving on streets.
Explanation: This video dates back before nationwide lockdown was announced in India.

Claim: Misleading: Books predicted the coronavirus before it happened.
Explanation: One book does have a close enough accurate representation; the second is a work of fiction.

Claim: FALSE: Thrombosis is the main cause of death for COVID-19 patients. Antibiotics can treat coronavirus patients.
Explanation: Respiratory failure is the leading cause of death for COVID-19 patients. Antibiotics are not effective against coronavirus, but only against collateral bacterial infections.

Claim: FALSE: Photo of rickshaw puller who died due to lack of food during the current lockdown, which was imposed to curb the spread of COVID-19.
Explanation: The photo is an old one. It is not related to any recent incident. It was found to exist on the internet atleast since 2017. So, the photo is of an incident prior to the announcement of nationwide lockdown, which came into effect from 25 March 2020.

Claim: False: Indian City Bangalore Municipal Corp. requested people to stay at home and lock down houses as they will be spraying medicine to kill coronavirus.
Explanation: Municipal commissioner of the city said he has no such plans of spraying medicines to kill COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Following the coronavirus pandemic, film star Salman Khan has given 200 ambulances to the India.
Explanation: Searching through several tools, it was found that Salman Khan's Foundation has donated just one ambulance. The claim of Salman Khan giving 200 ambulances in the fight against coronavirus is misleading.

Claim: FALSE: A Facebook user shared a video that shows a flock of birds on a road in Chandigarh.
Explanation: The video of a flock of birds being shared on social media claiming that the video has been shot at Chandigarh is false, The video is actually from Ahmedabad and was shot at Riverfront on 12 Feb 2020.

Claim: False: Indian nurse in Jeddah (Saudi Arabia) has been detected with novel coronavirus(2019-nCOV).
Explanation: Official government handles have clarified that the Indian nurse is not suffering from the deadly 2019-Ncov.

Claim: False: Cristiano Ronaldo’s hotels to be turned into quarantine centres in Portugal.
Explanation: Footballer's hotel chains denied the claim.

Claim: FALSE: India is administering empty syringes in the name of vaccine
Explanation: The video is from Mexico and not India where the instance was reported and the health authorities apologised for the negligience

Claim: FALSE: The largest hole in the ozone layer over the Arctic region has healed due to the COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: The ozone layer healing has nothing to do with the lockdown and was driven by unusually strong and long-lived polar vortex.

Claim: FALSE: A video clip shows the hanging bodies of a mother and child who have committed suicide in Gujarat because they did not have food during the current COVID-19  lockdown.
Explanation: Gujarat Police have clarified that the video not from Gujarat. The video was also making rounds in Bangladesh a month before.

Claim: FALSE: Houseflies can transmit the COVID-19 virus.
Explanation: WHO has already debunked the myth and clarified that there is no evidence to suggest that the COVID-19 virus is transmitted through houseflies. Also, it has clarified that the virus may be present in feces in some cases but, to date, there have been no reports of faecal-oral transmission of COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Spanish singer Miguel Bosé accused Gates Foundation to be expelled from India for their vaccines.
Explanation: Gates Foundation still works in India. Bosé based in a IG publication of a critiziced study from 10 years ago

Claim: MISLEADING: Matterhorn mountain in Switzerland was lit up with Indian tricolour to convey gratitude to the country for sending the life-saving Hydroxychloroquine drugs in the fight against COVID-19.
Explanation: Matterhorn mountain in Switzerland was lit up with the Indian flag to express solidarity and give hope and strength to all Indians in the fight against COVID-19; not as a gratitude to the country for sending hydroxychloroquine. Hydroxychloroquine is still being tested. There is no known cure for the coronavirus. From many days, the Matterhorn mountain has been illuminated with flags of various countries.

Claim: FALSE: A woman killed her three children and committed suicide because of the problems she faced amidst the lockdown in India.
Explanation: The photo is from an incident that took place in June 2019. It has no relation to the lockdown imposed due to coronavirus.

Claim: MISLEADING: Indian scientists are researching whether there are cells in the Ganges river that can block the coronavirus.
Explanation: ICMR has mentioned to FACTLY that they have only received a proposal to see if Ganges river has cells that can block coronavirus, however, ICMR clarified that they are not undertaking any such research.

Claim: FALSE: Drinking water boiled with turmeric powder, ginger, carom seeds and coriander seeds can cure COVID-19.
Explanation: The claim has no scientific evidence and no approval from WHO or any other health organization. As per Ayurveda, turmeric, carom seeds, ginger, lukewarm water, etc. have medicinal properties and can be used as an immunity booster for all diseases. However, it is not proven that these ingredients can prevent or cure COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: In India, the Congress President’s approval is required to use funds from PMNRF.
Explanation: No such approval is required. On the PMNRF website, it can be read that the disbursement out of the fund is made at the discretion of the Prime Minister. Previously, the fund was managed by a committee (in which Congress President was a member), but in 1985, all the powers were transferred to the Prime Minister.

Claim: FALSE: In view of the COVID-19 pandemic, the Indian government has extended the financial year from April 1 to July 1.
Explanation: The Indian government has issued no such directive extending the financial year.

Claim: : A police commissioner from Mumbai has asked essential services to be available at certain hours.
FALSE: An image of an elderly Italian man who was asked to pay for the ventilator that he used for his recovery.
Explanation: The man is actually a war veteran from the US who had broken down while reading a letter he had written to his then fiance and is not linked to coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Video of an RPF Jawan (low ranking member of the Railway Protection Force) collecting bribe from the migrants walking home on the railway tracks during the lockdown in Gujarat, India.
Explanation: The video is an old one. It is not related to any recent incident during the lockdown. As per an article published in July 2019, the video shows an RPF Jawan in Surat taking bribe from bootlegger women.

Claim: : Samsung is giving free phones to students during coronavirus pandemic for online studies.
FALSE: An Air India flight deployed to bring stranded Indians back home is not following social distancing norms, even after charging a hefty amount for the flight.
Explanation: The video is of a Pakistani aircraft carrier, Pakistan International Airlines (PIA).

Claim: FALSE: An image of a man carrying his old mother on his back shows migrants travelling to their homes in India, amidst lockdown.
Explanation: The image shows a Rohingya Muslim entering Bangladesh. It was taken in 2017.

Claim: FALSE: RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat said he has lost faith in religion due to coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: RSS has denied Mohan Bhagwat made such a statement. The viral newspaper clipping is photoshopped.

Claim: False: Actor Vijay donated 3 billion (300 crore) rupees for coronavirus relief.
Explanation: It is fake news claimed by using a fake news card from the Dinamalar news channel. The channel has denied broadcasting such news.

Claim: False: Beware of food delivery apps in India as they blow into the food before packaging it.
Explanation: It is a 2019 video from another South East Asian country and not India.

Claim: False: FBI has arrested a US professor who has manufactured and sold coronavirus to Wuhan.
Explanation: Professor Charles Lieber, whose name is mentioned in the viral message, has indeed been arrested but not because he ‘manufactured and sold’ coronavirus to China but because he lied to the US authorities about his involvement with the Chinese government program to recruit scientific talent.

Claim: Misleading: The Asterix comic books and The Simpsons predicted the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: Coronavirus has been around since the 1960s. The Simpsons image was edited.

Claim: FALSE: Wearing Mask To Protect From COVID-19 Causes Fungal Lung Infection
Explanation: Wearing mask to protect from COVID-19 doesn’t cause fungal lung infection; viral post is fake.

Claim: MISLEADING: Dried ginger powder can cure COVID-19.
Explanation: According to WHO no drugs have yet been certified to treat the coronavirus. COVID-19 can be prevented through frequent hand wash.

Claim: Mostly false: A woman infected with the coronavirus was killed by Chinese police.
Explanation: The woman in the video was taken into custody for violating traffic restrictions in China’s Heilongjiang province.

Claim: False: Iranian girl Anahita Hashemzadeh has contracted the coronavirus.
Explanation: Anahita Hashemzadeh hasn’t contracted the coronavirus. In the comments section of her Instagram videos, her mother has clarified multiple times that she is "safe and healthy" and the news regarding Anahita getting infected with coronavirus is fake.

Claim: FALSE: This is the condition of hospitals amidst the COVID19 pandemic, in India’s Bihar state.
Explanation: One image of the flooded hospital is from India's state of Bihar, when the hospital was flooded in 2018. The other image is from the city of Hyderabad and was shot when the hospital was flooded in July 2020.

Claim: FALSE: Video of Byculla (Maharashtra, India) MLA Waris Pathan threatening police to open a mosque during the Indian lockdown.
Explanation: The video used to claim that Byculla (Maharashtra) MLA Waris Pathan is threatening Police to open a mosque is an old one and is not related to any recent incident. It is related to an argument which erupted in November 2016, between Byculla MLA Waris Pathan and local Police over the volume of loudspeaker in a mosque.

Claim: FALSE: Advisory issued by the state police of Telangana (India) instructing people to be vigilant about the possibility of increase in thefts, due to the COVID-19 crisis in the country.
Explanation: The Telangana state police through their official Twitter account clarified that no such safety advisory has been released from the authorities, and urged not to spread such panic-inducing content.

Claim: FALSE: The photo of lions in Srisailam forest, in India, during the time of lockdown in the country to contain COVID-19 spread.
Explanation: The photo doesn't have any relation to Srisailam. It was taken from a 2016 video which was shot in Crooger park in South Africa. The photo doesn't have any relation to lockdown in India.

Claim: MISLEADING: The women in video is Russian President Putin’s daughter who volunteered for COVID19 vaccine
Explanation: The women shown in the video is not the daughter of Russian President Vladimir Putin but a volunteer named Natalia.

Claim: Mostly false: Aajtak news channel claims that consuming the herbal plant Tulsi will cure coronavirus.
Explanation: The WHO has not confirmed the claim. Aajtak channel has not run this information. The viral photo with channel logo is fake.

Claim: FALSE: Indian Home Minister Amit Shah said that the government transferred financial aid of Rs 530 million into the bank accounts of 410 million people during the coronavirus pandemic, which means Rs 1.29 for each person.
Explanation: The news channel misquoted the Home Minister's statement. Actually Amit Shah said Rs 530 Billion aid was given to 410 million people.

Claim: Partially false: Image of Gulbarga car festival held during lockdown this year.
Explanation: Even though the claim that people violated lockdown restrictions and participated in Gulbarga car festival in Karnataka is true, the image shared is 2 years old when the crowd was much larger in comparison to the recent event.

Claim: MISLEADING: AstraZeneca, University of Oxford’s COVID-19 vaccine has failed
Explanation: Astrazeneca, University of Oxford vaccine did not fail but the trials were put on hold

Claim: FALSE: To express gratitude towards India for sending the Hydroxychloroquine to the US, a group of American youth sings the Indian national anthem.
Explanation: The viral video which is being shared as ‘American youth expressing their gratitude towards India for sending HCQ by singing the Indian national anthem’ was published to commemorate Indian Independence Day in 2017.

Claim: Mostly false: A video of a Doctor of Mumbai’s Kasturba hospital suggesting tea and hot water to cure COVID-19.
Explanation: The video is not of a doctor from the Kasturba hospital and there is no evidence that tea and hot water can cure COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Mumbai Police congratulated a couple for marrying inside their house amidst the coronavirus lockdown.
Explanation: The video is from Nashik (a city in the state of Maharashtra) and shows Nashik city's police congratulating the couple who married in their home.

Claim: : In an Ethiopian Airlines flight from Italy to Addis Ababa airport this evening, most of the passengers are infected with the virus, and there is no strength except in God.
False: There is science behind Indian Prime minister Modi’s 5 p.m. clapping initiative: Clapping generates vibration which can kill coronavirus. Also, 3/22/20 is Amavasya.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence to prove that vibration from clapping hands can kill coronavirus. The Press Information Bureau of India has clarified that the message is fake. Also, Amavasya is not on 3/22/20.

Claim: False: In a photo of Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan and Chinese President Xi Jinping, Imran Khan is wearing a mask.
Explanation: The image was edited.

Claim: FALSE: A lady police constable in Mumbai is suffering from coronavirus.
Explanation: The lady constable was not suffering from coronavirus but hypertension.

Claim: False: Indian PM Modi is providing free masks to people under Swachh Bharat Mission to protect them from the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The website in the post is dubious and there is no government scheme of PM Modi under which free masks are being provided to people. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) said there is no central government scheme that provides free masks to people to protect them from the coronavirus outbreak.

Claim: Misleading: In Karnataka all Hindus have decided to boycott Muslims because of their anti-national activities.
Explanation: We could trace the video back to November 2018, long before the outbreak of COVID-19. Secondly, it shows a speech delivered by a BJP leader MM Ravindra in context of a price war between traders over the price of pepper.

Claim: FALSE: Image of ideal social distancing being followed in a market in Aizwal, India.
Explanation: The image is from a market in Myanmar.

Claim: FALSE: Schools are distributing free laptops and tablets to the students amid coronavirus pandemic
Explanation: The post with the link claiming free laptops and tablets for students is fake.

Claim: FALSE: A message claimed that the Indian government plans to ease down the lockdown restrictions imposed in the country in five stages.
Explanation: The claim was copied from Ireland government's schedule and no such plan exists as per the Indian government statements.

Claim: False: Indian Army has constructed an advanced hospital with a capacity of 1,000 beds in Barmer, Rajasthan, to cope with COVID-19.
Explanation: The viral images claiming the Indian Army has constructed an advanced hospital with the capacity of 1,000 beds in Barmer, Rajasthan, to cope with COVID-19 are old and unrelated.

Claim: FALSE: A video clip of Indian Army personnel assaulting a man for violating quarantine curfew hours.
Explanation: Misbar investigated the video and found it is old, published in March 2019, a year before the COVID-19 pandemic and quarantine were imposed, during an attack by some Indian army soldiers on a man in Kashmir, North India.

Claim: FALSE: Dr Uma Kumar of AIIMS gave the interview as shown in the video on coronavirus.
Explanation: Dr Uma Kumar of AIIMS did not give this interview on coronavirus; the viral post is fake.

Claim: False: Celebrities spreading misinformation about coronavirus and the Janata curfew in India.
Explanation: The celebrities shared posts that were already debunked about the 12 hour curfew on 3/22/20 in India.

Claim: FALSE: Self-medicate COVID-19 using a home remedy with aspirin, lemon and honey.
Explanation: One should never consume medicine without doctors recommendation. The purporting home remedy is no cure or treatment for COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Allowances of Members of Parliament in India have been increased by 49 thousand rupees during the pandemic.
Explanation: Actually the allowances of MPs have been cut by 30 percent. Due to which now they will get 49 thousand rupees, instead of 70 thousand as earlier.

Claim: FALSE: A photo that claimed show the severity of Covid-19 in India so residents must wear oxygen mask on the streets
Explanation: Photos taken on April 7, 2018, when a woman wearing an oxygen mask waited for the Agra Medical College ambulance at Uttar Pradesh, India, with her son

Claim: Mostly False: Prolonged use of mask causes hypoxia, oxygen deficiency, fatigue and loss of reflexes.
Explanation: Prolonged use of masks is safe provided it is clean and of appropriate size. They should not be worn too tightly.

Claim: False: President of Italy crying because of the coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The man in the picture, Jair Bolsonaro, is not the president of Italy but that of Brazil. Further, the image is not recent and was taken at the Thanksgiving speech at the Palacio do Planalto in December 2019.

Claim: FALSE: Coronavirus medicine is in your body
Explanation: it becomes clear in our investigation that this cutting of newspaper claiming that the corona virus medicine is in your body has been made using digital tools. In which the claims being made are misleading.

Claim: Misleading: Coronavirus fear in Germany results in large crowds outside a supermarket. People are pushing each other to get into the store first for necessary supplies.
Explanation: This video was uploaded on January 30, 2011 on YouTube, when many people went shopping at an Aldi mall.

Claim: False: As per Home Ministry of India, sharing information related to the coronavirus is now a punishable offense.
Explanation: We found that there is no official named Ravi Nayak in MHA, India, as claimed in the viral message. Also, there was no official notice on the website on MHA. It is evident from our fact check that the message viral on social media claiming to be from the Home Ministry of India is false.

Claim: False: The bodies of people infected with coronavirus are lying on the road of Italy. No one is carrying them due to the risk of infection.
Explanation: The image is from Germany, where people lied down in a pedestrian zone as part of an art project in remembrance of 528 victims of the Katzbach Nazi concentration camp in Frankfurt.

Claim: FALSE: Internet sensation and the world’s cutest baby Anahita Hashemzadeh is suffering COVID-19.
Explanation: Anahita's mother has denied the rumors and informed that Anahita is healthy and she isnt the girl in the viral video.

Claim: FALSE: A couple committed suicide along with their daughter amid the COVID-19 lockdown in Gujarat.
Explanation: The viral video is from 2018. The couple had committed suicide after the husband lost his job and his father kicked him out of the house for it.

Claim: False: Image showing Indian Political party (DMK) workers demonstrating with Go Corona Back balloon.
Explanation: The image of the balloon is edited to add "Corona" instead of "P.M. Modi" and it is an old image.

Claim: FALSE: Film star Aamir Khan distributed 15 thousand rupees to the poor in flour bags.
Explanation: In our investigation, it came to light that the film star Aamir Khan neither distributed the flour to anyone nor kept 15,000 rupees in it. Several media reports contacted some local journalists to confirm the claim of money being distributed in Surat. But they were unaware of the incident. Talked to the police control room policemen about this, but they too have no information in this matter.

Claim: False: The WHO reported that coronavirus lasts up to 8 hours on cabbages; thus, cabbage consumption should be restricted.
Explanation: The WHO did not publish any such report.

Claim: Mostly false: Most of the passengers in an Ethiopian airlines flight from Italy are infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: The viral video is from a mock drill from Senegal.

Claim: False: A 9-minute viral video in which a woman claims India has entered stage-3 of COVID-19. She claims that her husband is employed with a major news channel and the information was passed to him by some Dr. Gyani who heads the Indian COVID-19 team and asks people to stock up on food, medicines and baby food for one month. She also cautions people about the Army being deployed to enforce a strict lockdown in the upcoming days.
Explanation: Our investigation revealed the claims made in the video are false and baseless. Dr. Gyani, an expert mentioned in the video as a source of the information, denied the claims and deemed the video as completely false. Also, the Indian government has already clarified that messages about Army deployment during the lockdown are false.

Claim: FALSE: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan’s wife has been tested positive for coronavirus
Explanation: The screenshot with this claim is doctored.

Claim: False: Bitter gourd juice can cure coronavirus.
Explanation: Bitter gourd juice cannot cure coronavirus. There is no cure for coronavirus as of this date.

Claim: FALSE: Muslim man in Dehradun spitting to spread coronavirus.
Explanation: This event is not related to any communal incident, the person was caught violating lockdown. A F.I.R has been registered against the guy who purposefully posted the video on internet linking it to a specific community with false claim.

Claim: False: People rioting on the streets of London due to economic crisis in the wake of coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The viral video is almost nine years old and from the London riots in 2011.

Claim: FALSE: Famous singer Sharda Sinha passes away due to coronavirus
Explanation: Sharda Sinha is alive and is recovering from COVID.

Claim: FALSE: Squeezing hot lemon water cures corona virus infection.
Explanation: The studies have proven that lemon water does not cure COVID-19 infection.

Claim: Partially false: The Indian health department has issued a notification advising people to drink only 50-80 ml of water, avoid spicy food, and not travel in crowded spaces till March 2020.
Explanation: There has been no notification suggesting drinking only a certain amount of water, avoiding spicy food and improving the intake of vitamin C prevent coronavirus. The "children-are-more-vulnerable theory" is also not scientifically backed. As of Jan. 27, there were no confirmed cases in India and the death toll had reached 106 in China.

Claim: FALSE: “These Helpless People are not Tablighis ,They are Poor Hindus Who are Stranded due to Lockdown .Has any TV Chanel discussed This?”
Explanation: The photo is from Malaysia when these Bangladeshis were waiting at immiration center to return home.

Claim: FALSE: Pomphlet claims Covid-19 was conspiracy and precautions unnecessary
Explanation: Website without evidence tried to belittle efforts of self-isolation or wearing mask and self-quarantine

Claim: FALSE: The Chinese authorities dumped dead bodies in the sea. These bodies were of patients who had died of coronavirus. The bodies are now washing up on the Hong Kong and Taiwan coasts.
Explanation: The video is from 2014 and shows the coast of Libya, Africa, where bodies had washed up after some people died in an accident.

Claim: False: The Twitter profile of a “Dr. Aisha” claims she died of COVID-19 in South Africa
Explanation: This was a catfishing attempt wherein images and videos of a medical student who had not tested positive for COVID-19 in South Africa were shared as Dr. Aisha

Claim: False: Indian Government has issued a guideline to monitor citizens’ activity; their call and social media handles will be under surveillance.
Explanation: A Twitter user shared the same claim on November 24, 2017. The viral forward is fake and the Indian government has not issued any guidelines to monitor the activities of its citizens on various social media and messaging platforms.

Claim: FALSE: Harvard university has praised Uttar Pradesh’s handling of the covid-19 migrant crisis
Explanation: The study conducted by an affiliate of the Harvard business school and is a case study of UP's way of handling the crisis but does not only laud its efforts

Claim: FALSE: Claim that Indian prime minister Modi said one crore (ten million) COVID-19 infected patients have been treated for free.
Explanation: Prime Minister Modi did not say one croreCOVID-19infected patients have been treated for free.

Claim: FALSE: An image of Arvind Kejriwal putting a mask on a young boy is being circulated on social media platforms. Deputy CM Manish Sisodia can be seen standing next to him. The catch here—both the leaders aren’t wearing masks themselves.
Explanation: An old image of Arvind Kejriwal and his Deputy Manish Sisodia shared amid ongoing pandemic to imply that their flouting COVID-19 appropriate norms.

Claim: False: An Indian social activist was arrested when she tried to buy liquor during the lockdown period.
Explanation: An older video of the said social activist was shared with a false narrative.

Claim: FALSE: A video is doing the rounds on social media which claims that policemen are now being tested positive for the COVID-19.
Explanation: The video is from Bihar's Hajipur jail. An official informed that mock drills are being practiced in almost every jail in Bihar to check the preparations for the fight against the COVID-19. Some social media users are sharing the video of mock drill with the claim that a cop was tested positive for the COVID-19, this is completely false.

Claim: False: Indian Army has built a 1,000-bed hospital in Rajasthan in eight days for the treatment of COVID-19.
Explanation: The news that it is building a thousand-bed hospital for the treatment of COVID-19 in Barmer (Rajasthan) is false. The photos in the post are old.

Claim: FALSE: NYT ranking shows Top 4 Covid-19 vaccines are Chinese-made
Explanation: No such news carried by NYT

Claim: FALSE: A viral pamphlet claims Herbal Mysore Pak (a south Indian sweet) can cure COVID-19.
Explanation: Herbal Mysore Pak cannot cure COVID-19, and a shop owner who claimed so in an advert had his product siezed by authorities for false advertizing.

Claim: Mostly false: UV rays and sunlight can kill the coronavirus.
Explanation: A concentrated form of UVC might kill the coronavirus but it is extremely harmful for human skin. Sunlight cannot kill the coronavirus.

Claim: False: Eating salt on the onion will eliminate the coronavirus.
Explanation: According to the WHO, eating onions increases the immune system but is not related to treatment of the coronavirus. A cure for this virus has not yet been discovered.

Claim: FALSE: Image ofa map of India redesigned by an American CEO praising the Government of India for its effective handling of the COVID-19 crisis.
Explanation: The image with the same map of India was found to be existing on the internet atleast since 2016. American CEO has designed it to show India's effective halndling of COVID-19 crisis.

Claim: FALSE: The Queen of England is thanking PM Modi for sending vaccines to the UK
Explanation: A 2020 bill board of the Queen of England at Picaddily Square providing solace to beat the virus has been morphed

Claim: False: Muslim League Bangladesh party leader’s son Janab Muhammed Abdul Alam donates 800 cr to CH charitable trust works under Muslim League.
Explanation: It is a fake news, probably posted as a prank but IUML followers mistook it for real and started sharing it in large numbers.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows fishes washed up to the Indian shores during the lockdown.
Explanation: The video is actually from Mexico. Thousands of dead fishes washed up on the Acapulco beach there.

Claim: False: Alcohol kills the coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is fake.

Claim: False: A video that claims to feature one of the victims of the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The same video was posted on YouTube on October 24th, 2019, before the first case of coronavirus was reported in China.

Claim: FALSE: A WhatsApp forward, along with a video, is doing the rounds in which it is claimed that a person who belongs to the Tablighi Jamaat was kept in an isolation ward where he started wandering naked. The viral forward also claims that the person who was wandering naked did this vulgar act intentionally.
Explanation: The video being circulated in the name of Tablighi Jamaat members’ misbehaving with the nurses treating them for the COVID-19 is old. Hence it is evident that the viral claim is ‘False’ and is being shared with a communal angle.

Claim: False: Alcohol kills the coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is fake.

Claim: FALSE: You can self test coronavirus by a 10-second self check test.
Explanation: Post claiming that a 10 second self test can help you detect coronavirus is fake. This false information has resurfaced after a couple of months.

Claim: False: Saddam Hussein talked about coronavirus to his cabinet and army in the nineties. He said that America has threatened him to spread this virus if he doesn’t follow their command.
Explanation: The viral video is a doctored version of the original video shared by Associated Press in 2015. The audios of both the videos are different not only in terms of their content but voice as well. In the original AP video, Saddam Hussein does not mention the word ‘virus’ or ‘coronavirus.’

Claim: False: UNICEF advises a certain set of steps to follow for coronavirus.
Explanation: UNICEF has not released this advisory and most of the claims are not scientifically proven.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows COVID-19 patients lying dead on the ground in India.
Explanation: The video shows visuals from the Vizag gas plant leak where few people suffocated to death. It has no link to COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: An American CEO draw a map to praise the Indian government’s COVID-19 response.
Explanation: The map has been online since 2016.

Claim: FALSE: Image of a market practising social distance claimed to be from a city Aizwal, in India.
Explanation: The image is from a market in a city called Kalaw in Myanmar.

Claim: Mostly false: WHO has said, do not eat cabbage as it will increase the chance of coronavirus infection.
Explanation: The WHO has not said anything that shows cabbage has any relation to coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows Gujarat Police asking money (bribe) from migrants walking on railway tracks amidst nationwide COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: This video is 1 year old and shows Gujarat Police extorting money from illegal liquor peddlers. The constable was then suspended from his duties.

Claim: FALSE: Lockdown violation in Chandni Chowk area of Delhi
Explanation: The post shows lockdown violation in Surat, not in Delhi.

Claim: MISLEADING: A video puts forward measures to cure COVID-19.
Explanation: The video does not mention any cures. It does give tips to boost immunity, BUT not to cure the virus.

Claim: FALSE: Bangalore (India) police commissioner has warned people to be careful as incidents of thefts and kidnappings will be on the rise once the nationwide lockdown lifts.
Explanation: Bangalore police confirmed that they had not shared any such messages.

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 patients in Gujarat are being segregated on the basis of religion at Ahmedabad Civil Hospital.
Explanation: On the basis of the statement of Dr. Rathod of Ahmedabad Civil Hospital and a clear denial of several government bodies, we reached the conclusion that the two outlets mentioned above, published a ‘False’ report which was later amplified by several verified Twitter handles.

Claim: FALSE: Indian migrants were not asked to pay for the shramik train and only BJP led states did not charge migrants to not travel during the lockdown.
Explanation: The government did ask migrants to pay for their travel back to their home states amid the lockdown and BJP led states were also charging migrants who wished to leave.

Claim: False: After husband tested positive for coronavirus, wife fled from Bangalore to Agra in India.
Explanation: The woman went to her parents' place in Agra on 3/9/20, while her husband was confirmed positive for coronavirus on 3/12/20. She did not enter Bangalore city. Karnataka government has clarified that the woman did not flee to her parents’ place.

Claim: Mostly false: Dr. Usman Riyaz from Delhi died from the coronavirus.
Explanation: Viral picture is of Dr. Riyaz Usman from UAE and he is alive.

Claim: False: Goats in Ajmer, Rajasthan were found to be COVID-19 positive.
Explanation: The video is old and unrelated to COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Chief Secretary of West Bengal was not following relaxing while the state was performing poorly as it fought COVID-19.
Explanation: This image is from 2013 and is being shared with a false context.

Claim: FALSE: Sikh Monk Baba Banta Singh infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: This viral claim is fake. Baba Banta singh denied this information.

Claim: False: Anti-Malaria Drug Chloroquine Is A Cure For coronavirus.
Explanation: This claim is false. There is no scientific evidence to prove that Chloroquine can cure COVID-19.

Claim: False: An image of Indian Home Minister Amit Shah visiting COVID-19 patients.
Explanation: A 2015 picture of the then BJP president visiting hospitals in Madhya Pradesh shared with a false narrative.

Claim: False: People of Italy throwing money on the streets as they felt that the money couldn’t save them from COVID-19.
Explanation: The photos are not related to the recent COVID-19 outbreak. They were taken in Venezuela, not in Italy. Some people threw the notes as they became valueless due to hyperinflation in the country.

Claim: FALSE: A Sadhu (Sage) in Jaipur, India infected around 300 people by sharing Chilam.
Explanation: The District Collector of Jaipur has clarified that the viral news is Fake.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows dead bodies lying on the beach, shared with the claim that bodies of coronavirus patients are being dumped in the sea.
Explanation: The video shows a 2014 incident that occurred at a Libyan beach where bodies of migrants have been washed ashore.

Claim: FALSE: According to a WHO report, not a single vegetarian person in the world has been found to suffer from coronavirus.
Explanation: We found that Gauden Galea's 3-month-old video is being shared with misleading claims. Galea did not speak of non-vegetarians having coronavirus. At the same time, we found that the World Health Organization has not issued any such report that vegetarians are safe from coronavirus.

Claim: False: China is planning to kill coronavirus patients.
Explanation: There is no information to prove that China plans to kill over 20,000 patients who have been infected by the coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: A student from Pondicherry University has found a home remedy for COVID-19 that has been accepted by World Health Organization (WHO)
Explanation: This post is fake. Pondicherry University refuted the claim made in the viral post. World Health Organization (WHO) has also not approved any medicine or vaccine as a cure for COVID-19, so far.

Claim: False: A video shows pigs buried in China because of the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is a year old; the pigs were buried after the outbreak of African swine flu.

Claim: False: A photo shows corpses strewn about in China due to the coronavirus.
Explanation: Taken in 2014 in Frankfurt, Germany, the photo shows people lying in a pedestrian zone for an art project remembering the Katzbach concentration camp victims.

Claim: Misleading: Anyone requiring injection Remdesivir can get @ Rs 899/- as against Rs.4000/- charged by medical shops. You can purchase it directly from Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Jan Aushadhi Kendra
Explanation: Remdesivir injection is not available on any of the Pradhan Mantri Jan Aushadhi Kendras. Also only one out of seven manufacturers of Remdesivir has reduced the price to Rs 899, however, the other six manufacturers have also slashed the price.

Claim: FALSE: Muslims scattered currency notes on a road in Indore to spread coronavirus.
Explanation: The currency notes shown in the video are not thrown on the road by anyone with the intention to spread coronavirus. When FACTLY contacted Indore police, they said these currency notes slipped from the pockets of a gas cylinder delivery boy. Also, the name of the person who lost money on the road is Ram Narendra Yadav. He is not Muslim

Claim: FALSE: Maharashtra Legislative Assembly member Jitendra Awhad tested positive with coronavirus.
Explanation: Jitendra Awhad has tweeted his lab report rubbishing all claims, the Lab report shows he does not have coronavirus.

Claim: False: Russia has unleashed over 500 lions to ensure that people stay inside their homes amid the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The image on social media has nothing to do with Russia or the Russian president. The image is from South Africa’s Johannesburg, and the lion seen in the viral image was brought for film shooting by a production crew.

Claim: FALSE: Baba Ramdev claims that COVID-19 can be self diagnosed by controlling breathing and that mustard oil kills the virus.
Explanation: Both the claims are false, controlling of breath is not a scientific way to test for COVID-19 and mustard oil's benefits for COVID-19 have not been studied.
Originated from: Baba Ramdev for a news channel

Claim: FALSE: By order of CM of Andhra Pradesh, school-colleges have been closed in the state from 01 March to 04 May.
Explanation: This claim being made about the corona virus and Andhra Pradesh has turned out to be false. The Andhra Pradesh government has not ordered closure of school-colleges from 01 March to 04 May.

Claim: False: UNICEF releases coronavirus prevention guidelines.
Explanation: UNICEF has not released an advisory; many of the claims are contrary to health experts' advice.

Claim: FALSE: Justin Trudeau promises to pay off Tamil Nadu (India) government’s debt.
Explanation: Canadian PM has not made any such promise. These posts have been there since the last 2 years circulating time to time.

Claim: FALSE: A WhatsApp forward, along with a video, is doing the rounds in which it is claimed that a person who belongs to the Tablighi Jamaat was kept in an isolation ward where he started wandering naked. The viral forward also claims that the person who was wandering naked did this vulgar act intentionally.
Explanation: The video being circulated in the name of Tablighi Jamaat members’ misbehaving with the nurses treating them for the COVID-19 is old. Hence it is evident that the viral claim is ‘False’ and is being shared with a communal angle.

Claim: False: Government of India has announced a “National Lockdown” in the country from 3/20/20.
Explanation: The Government of India has not announced a "National Lockdown" in the country from 3/20/20. PM Modi, in his recent address to the nation about the coronavirus outbreak, asked people to practice social distancing and to stay home as much as possible for the coming few weeks to combat COVID-19. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) said the message is fake.

Claim: False: Videos state that 25,000 Chinese are being killed.
Explanation: Three different videos -- two unrelated to the coronavirus and one with overlaid music -- are combined with false claims.

Claim: False: This is a picture of the old city in Hyderabad (India) today despite the lockdown.
Explanation: The video is an old one. It was not taken during the current lockdown. Also, today’s Friday prayer at Mecca Masjid was conducted with only a few members.

Claim: FALSE: A Muslim woman is shouting at doctors who have come for coronavirus inspection at one of the places in India.
Explanation: The video of a woman shouting at doctors is from Pakistan, not India.

Claim: FALSE: CNN claims that the COVID-19 vaccine is being given to men through their penis
Explanation: While the graphic was morphed to use the CNN logo, BOOM spoke to the doctor who said that his photo was used without his consent

Claim: False: Coronavirus is found in broiler chicken.
Explanation: There is no evidence to prove that coronavirus is found in the broiler chickens. The WHO has clarified that meat cooked properly can be consumed.

Claim: FALSE: A video of a Muslim fruit-vendor spitting on fruits to spread coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was shot in February 2020 by a man in Raisen district in the state of Madhya Pradesh (MP), but the first coronavirus case in Madhya Pradesh was detected on 20 March. The posted video was taken much earlier than the first coronavirus case in the state.

Claim: : A video of a Muslim fruit-vendor spitting on fruits to spread coronavirus.
False: A viral video purportedly from Italy shows a child crying for his mother who died due to coronavirus.
Explanation: Our investigation revealed that the video is not from Italy. It is from El Salvador and the mother of the child had died in a bus accident.

Claim: FALSE: Masks can be sanitized in microwave
Explanation: The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare recommends certain ways to sanitize homemade face coverings, and microwaving is not one of them. Some contain metal strips that are not safe to put in a microwave. Instead, they should be washed properly using soap and water. The viral post is fake.

Claim: False: Italians are throwing their money on the streets as it is useless to them now during the coronavirus scare.
Explanation: These are old images from Venezuela and have nothing to do with the COVID-19 pandemic

Claim: FALSE: Video shows women shopping in Delhi’s market during lockdown.
Explanation: This viral video is of Faisalabad in Pakistan, not of Delhi market.

Claim: FALSE: Some reporters visited the British Prime Minister Boris Johnson after he recovered from his illness. His home looks like an old abandoned military hut with very old brick walls. The living room was too small so brought out the tea tray for the reporters. All the cups are different. He met them with disheveled hair and casual clothes, but with the confident smile of a Prime Minister
Explanation: The video of UK's PM Boris Johnson doing rounds on social media is from 2018 when he was not even Prime Minister

Claim: FALSE: Message claiming that the city of Mumbai will be under the military lockdown for the next 10 days to contain the spread of COVID-19 virus, and that only milk and medicine will be available during this time.
Explanation: The Mumbai police have termed the message to be a 'rumour' and clarified that the army is not being called out to the city. Mumbai government has also debunked the claim and clarifired that no army/navy personnel is being deployed for maintianing law and order in the city.

Claim: FALSE: Photo showing coronavirus infected mother hugging her child.
Explanation: The picture is old, from 1985, and became viral alongside a wrong claim.

Claim: FALSE: In Hyderabad, India, dogs are roaming in Osmania Hospital wards amid COVID-19 crisis.
Explanation: The video was taken in 2018.

Claim: False: Images of patients treated in the open are from Italy as it has run out of hospital beds.
Explanation: The images are from Croatia after it was hit by an earthquake on March 22.

Claim: FALSE: Woman who attended a religious congregation in Delhi is claimed to not be cooperating with the medical professionals.
Explanation: This clip is originally from Sukkur province in Pakistan near the Iran-Pakistan border where people were kept in the isolation center and not from India.

Claim: False: Netflix and Amazon are offering free subscriptions amid the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: Contrary to the claims, the website does not belong to Netflix. The streaming platform is available only on netflix.com. The tab thumbnail, however, is identical to the genuine site and bears the red ‘N’ symbol.

Claim: False: Italian doctor couple diagnosed with coronavirus.
Explanation: The couple was spotted and clicked by Associated Press (AP) photographer Emilio Morenatti nearly two weeks ago.

Claim: FALSE: Claim that Indian Prime minister Modi said one crore (10 million) COVID-19 positive patients have been treated for free.
Explanation: Prime minister Narendra Modi hasn't made this statement. This is a false claim going viral.

Claim: False: Indian PM Modi announced a lockdown extension until 5/4/20 in India.
Explanation: No such announcement was made by PM Modi; the image is digitally edited.

Claim: False: Another new disease called “hantavirus” in China.
Explanation: Hantavirus has infected people in different countries for many years. It's not a new virus. In the U.S., between 1993 and 2017, approximately 728 people were infected with the virus, which can be seen on the CDC website.

Claim: FALSE: New Zealand Prime Minster Jacinda Ardern visited a temple after the country was declared COVID-19 free.
Explanation: Jacinda Ardern had visited the Radha Krishna Temple in New Zealand during her appearance at an event organised by a newspaper.

Claim: False: Pakistan’s leading scholar Mufti Naeem suffers from coronavirus. A few days ago, he refused to close madrasas and mosques.
Explanation: According to Pakistani media outlets, Mufti Naeem was admitted to the hospital due to heart disease.

Claim: Misleading: A video shows coronavirus patients at an airport in China and gauges how serious the situation is.
Explanation: The video is not of the coronavirus infected patients of China or Italy, but of the mock drill conducted at Blas Dian Airport in Decar, Senegal, last year.

Claim: False: Recent photo of PM Modi visiting a church and offering prayers to save the country from the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: It is an old photo. The photo was taken when Modi visited Sri Lanka in June 2019. He paid homage to those killed in the serial bombings at St Anthony's Shrine (Colombo, Sri Lanka).

Claim: FALSE: Man collapses and dies on the road due to the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is actually of a COVID-19 mock drill that was carried out in Colombia and is not actually an incident that happened in reality.

Claim: False: Andhra Pradesh Chief Minister YS Jagan Reddy has claimed that Paracetamol is the only medication for coronavirus.
Explanation: It is evident from our findings and Dr. Pandey’s testimony that Paracetamol can help with coronavirus symptoms but cannot entirely cure it. We also found there are many medications that can help with coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: An image with human body figurines in a bowl that claims China is serving human baby soup in its restaurants.
Explanation: The image is of an art installation to raise awareness about the rampant killing of sharks.

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 case in Bettiah Jail.
Explanation: Mock drill video was shared as related to a COVID-19 case in Bettiah Jail.

Claim: False: American scientists have developed a cure for the coronavirus.
Explanation: The viral image on social media is not a vaccine for coronavirus but a COVID-19 test kit recently developed by South Korea.

Claim: False: Pakistani doctor Osama Riaz’s last message for you (while taking his last breath).
Explanation: The video is not of the Pakistani doctor who died but of another doctor from the UK who tested positive and is going to be discharged soon.

Claim: FALSE: Inhalation of hot steam can kill Novel Coronavirus.
Explanation: Inhalation of steam from hot water does not kill COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: New nipah virus is deadlier than COVID-19 according to WHO.
Explanation: Virus Nipah killed 18 people in India in 2018 and was first identified in 1998.

Claim: Misleading: WHO changed its definition of herd immunity to boost vaccination
Explanation: The WHO changed its definition as it did not want to promote the spread of infection among the population as their earlier definition included terms that gave the impression that herd immunity was only achieved after being exposed to the virus

Claim: FALSE: A Doctors Alliance video is falsely shared as WHO Doctors taking a complete U-turn on COVID-19 pandemic
Explanation: The speakers in the video are not WHO doctors. It is a group of doctors alliance who are spreading false news about the COVID-19 pandemic on how social distancing, quarantine, or isolation are not required to combat the spread of COVID-19

Claim: FALSE: Legionnaires’ disease can be contracted from a face mask
Explanation: Post claiming Legionnaires’ disease can be contracted from a face mask is false.

Claim: False: A viral video showing some men assaulting a policeman is being shared with the claim that it is from Agripada, Mumbai (Indiaa).
Explanation: Our investigation revealed that the video is from Banglore, not Mumbai. Two men were arrested for attacking two constables after they were stopped for breaching a check post set up to implement the lockdown in Sanjay Nagar of Banglore.

Claim: FALSE: The Bombay High Court in Mumbai City has extended the lockdown in the state of Maharashtra till April 30, 2020.
Explanation: The Bombay High Court has not extended the lockdown in Maharashtra till April 30, 2020.

Claim: FALSE: The large migrant population that gathered in Mumbai belonged to the Muslim community
Explanation: The migrants had gathered due to rumours of trains having started to function and that food was being distributed in the vicinity and has not been linked to any religion.

Claim: FALSE: Assam Health Minister Himanta Biswa Sarma claims No COVID In Assam
Explanation: Health Minister Himanta Biswa Sarma’s claim on “no COVID in Assam” is misleading. Active case numbers on the Central and State (Assam) government websites suggests otherwise.

Claim: False: A video shows pigs buried in China because of the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is a year old; the pigs were buried after the outbreak of African swine flu.

Claim: False: Indian government will reduce employees’ pension by 30% and terminate pensions offered to those who are above 80 as a way to divert funds towards managing health services and tackling the adverse impact of the new coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: As of 4/9/20, the Indian government had not issued an order to reduce employees' pension by 30% and/or terminate elderly pensions.

Claim: FALSE: Unmarried women and those who do not have children are prohibited from having the vaccine (Coronavirus Vaccine) because it may lead to infertility.
Explanation: COVID-19 vaccine claims made in the viral pamphlet are misleading and false. No advisory by the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare nor any factsheets by the vaccine companies support the claims related to people with diabetes or those who smoke or virgins.

Claim: False: After husband tested positive for coronavirus, wife fled from Bangalore to Agra in India.
Explanation: The woman went to her parents' place in Agra on 3/9/20, and her husband tested positive for coronavirus on 3/12/20. She didn't enter Bangalore city. Karnataka government has also clarified that the woman didn't flee to her parents’ place.

Claim: FALSE: Kerala, India, minister K.T Jaleel still draws his salary as teacher even after quitting his job 14 years ago.
Explanation: The minister has clarified that he has not taken salary after retiring as a Professor to pursue politics and also provided the testimony of the principal of the college, where he was teaching.

Claim: FALSE: To express gratitude towards India for sending the Hydroxychloroquine to the US, a group of American youth sings the Indian national anthem.
Explanation: The viral video which is being shared as ‘American youth expressing their gratitude towards India for sending HCQ by singing the Indian national anthem’ was published to commemorate Indian Independence Day in 2017.

Claim: False: Consuming large doses of Vitamin C can stop the spread of coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no evidence that consuming large doses of Vitamin C cannot stop the spread of coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: People in Kerala, India violate lock down and flock markets to buy vegetables for Vishu celebrations.
Explanation: An old image from 2019 has been used to make the false claim.

Claim: FALSE: “Entire city of Mumbai will be under military lockdown for 10 days starting from Saturday. So please stock everything. Only milk and medicine will be available.”
Explanation: It was clear after reading several media reports, including a clarification made by the Mumbai Police on Twitter, about the viral claim that the state government has not fielded army personnel in Mumbai to follow the lockdown. The announcement in the Marathi language does not mention the army anywhere, but appeals to the people to stay in their homes. Also, No official announcement has been made by the state government for complete lockdown in the entire Mumbai for the next 10 days.
