Claim: FALSE: Videos showing American students singing the Indian national anthem to thank India for supplying hydroxychloroquine.
Explanation: It was a 2-year-old video. A YouTuber, Anisha Dixit, had made this video to celebrate global freedom and diversity on the occasion of 71st Independence Day of India.

Claim: FALSE: An old Whatsapp forward claiming that under the Disaster Management Act, no one apart from the government department is allowed to post, update or share any forward related to Coronavirus and that it is a punishable offence to do so.
Explanation: Our research makes it clear the viral Whatsapp message claiming that under the Disaster Management Act, no one apart from the government department is allowed to post, update or share any forward related to Coronavirus, is misleading. A Live Law report was shared with this claim to add credibility.

Claim: FALSE: Video of people thronging to a wine shop in Assam, India amid lockdown.
Explanation: The video is not from Assam but an old video from Kerala.

Claim: False: Rotis hailing PM Modi shared in Madhya Pradesh, India, during lockdown.
Explanation: The rotis were distributed in 2014 and are not related to the recent COVID-19 outbreak.

Claim: FALSE: Image of COVID-19 infected person’s throat.
Explanation: The image is an old one and is found on the internet atleast since May 2018. The first COVID-19 case was reported in the world in December 2019.

Claim: FALSE: People who arrived at Tirur, Kerala (India) from Mumbai in train, escaped from the sight of the authorities to avoid quarantine.
Explanation: The Tirur Municipality has refuted the news and have also filed a case against the perpetrators of this false information.

Claim: FALSE: A video showed that Kenya authority roped in the Maasai Tribe to enforce the lockdown.
Explanation: The video was a humoristic video published by a Kenya-based YouTuber, Arisa Nelson.

Claim: False: A positive COVID-19 patient recently met Narendra Modi.
Explanation: A 2018 picture is being shared with a false narrative.

Claim: FALSE: A soldier hugged his coronavirus-positive daughter by covering her in plastic.
Explanation: The viral picture is not of India but of Malaysia. In the investigation we found that the soldier doing duty during the coronavirus is hugging his son in plastic due to fear of virus. The information found during the search shows that the child seen in the photograph is not coronavirus positive.

Claim: False: Trupti Desai, a well known social activist from India, was arrested for illegally buying liquor during the COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: The video shown with the above claim is seven months old. Trupti Desai was detained by the Pune police after she threatened to offer a garland of liquor bottles to then CM Devendra Fadnavis.

Claim: FALSE: Video of an RPF Jawan (low ranking member of the Railway Protection Force) collecting bribe from the migrants walking home on the railway tracks during the lockdown in Gujarat, India.
Explanation: The video is an old one. It is not related to any recent incident during the lockdown. As per an article published in July 2019, the video shows an RPF Jawan in Surat taking bribe from bootlegger women.

Claim: FALSE: Politician Sebastian Paul called Modi haters demented.
Explanation: Sebastian Paul has clarified that these claims are baseless and he has not made any such statement.

Claim: False: Video of a girl dying of coronavirus in a shopping mall.
Explanation: The video is from Malaysia where the girl died due to a heart failure and not coronavirus. BOOM corroborated the theory with a family member of the deceased

Claim: FALSE: Amid coronavirus pandemic, government is giving free Rs 7500 relief funds by clicking on a link
Explanation: Amid coronavirus pandemic, government is not giving free Rs 7500 relief funds by clicking on a link, viral post is a scam

Claim: False: Video shows bats found under the tiles of many roofs in Hubei, China, that were the source of coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was not taken in China. It’s a 2011 video uploaded on 7/5/11 by Miami based Istueta Roofing. The bats were found under the tiles during the process of replacing a roof for a customer.

Claim: False: India TV telecasted news that Bollywood Actor Shahrukh Khan donated 450 million (45 Crore) Rupees to Pakistan Oil tanker blast victims.
Explanation: The video is a clipped version of India TV’s fact-check video. In the original fact-check video, India TV has debunked the same claim and concluded that Shahrukh has not made any donation to Pakistan Oil tanker blast victims.

Claim: FALSE: Cover photo of The Sovereign Independient newspaper proves the pandemic was planned by Bill Gates
Explanation: A photo of a newspaper cover has circulated on social media with a quote from Bill Gates to say that he planned the Covid-19 pandemic to reduce the population. The newspaper is known for spreading conspiracy theories and the Gates quote was manipulated and taken out of context to misinform.

Claim: Misleading: Coronavirus was created in a lab in Wuhan.
Explanation: No scientific evidence supports that the coronavirus was created in a lab. According to the WHO, “Both Chinese and external expert groups are working in trying to identify the animal source of this new virus.”

Claim: False: American citizens have placed a nude statue of President Donald Trump in New York City because he failed to handle the coronavirus situation in USA.
Explanation: The video is almost four years old and is unrelated to the current novel coronavirus situation.

Claim: FALSE: A nurse claims that Delhi govt has stopped funding for the hotel stay for doctors and nurses treating COVID-19.
Explanation: The lady in the video is not a nurse and the claims made by her are entirely false.

Claim: FALSE: A message claims that ingredients in coffee can cure COVID-19 and that the deceased whistleblower Li Wenliang found its cure
Explanation: As of June 11, there was no cure for COVID-19

Claim: Misleading: It was claimed that the BCG vaccine, given to all Indians mandatorily after birth, makes them immune to coronavirus.
Explanation: WHO said that there is no evidence that the BCG protects people from the coronavirus infection and tests are underway.

Claim: False: Ministry of health’s emergency notified the public about the new coronavirus outbreak. (Jan. 29)
Explanation: The advisory message has not been issued by the Health Ministry. Also, in the precautions released by the Ministry, there is nothing related to keeping the throat moist.

Claim: FALSE: 190 countries have pre-booked the Bharat Biotech COVID-19 vaccine, which is being developed in India
Explanation: The COVAX agreement is to facilitate vaccine distribution to the 190 participating countries in which Serum Institute is a signatory. This is being misconstrued as 190 countries have pre-booked the Bharat Biotech COVID-19 vaccine developed in India.

Claim: False: Video of a person infected with coronavirus committing suicide in New York.
Explanation: The video was taken in 2015. It shows a pregnant woman jumping off a building after finding that her husband was having an affair with her mother.

Claim: False: Photo of an Indonesian doctor, Hideo Ali, looking at his children and pregnant wife for the last time.
Explanation: The one in the photo is not Indonesian doctor, Hideo Ali. He is a doctor from Malaysia. A Malaysian man posted this picture on Facebook saying that the doctor is his cousin and because of the spread of COVID-19 across the country, he had to leave his family and work constantly. Since he doesn't have time, he is looking at his family from a distance, and the photo is related to that instance.

Claim: FALSE: Migrant labourers in the state of Gujarat are protesting amidst the lockdown.
Explanation: The video of migrant labourers protesting is from the state of Telangana and not Gujarat.

Claim: FALSE: Women of Shaheen Bagh, in Delhi, India caught red-handed carrying out a prostitution operation during the lockdown
Explanation: This is a 5 year old video from Karachi, in Pakistan, where women were seen running out a massage parlor that was raided. This is neither linked to the Shaheed Bagh incident nor to the lockdown in India.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows a huge crowd of women rushing in a mall in Saudi Arabia after the COVID-19 lockdown was lifted.
Explanation: The video is from 2019. This old video is being falsely shared as a recent incident.

Claim: False: Police in India lashed sticks at filmmaker Sudhir Mishra for not following the rules of lockdown.
Explanation: The viral video has been falsified based on the tweet made by Sudhir Mishra himself on the viral clip.

Claim: FALSE: Video of Rahul Gandhi and Priyanka Vadra breaking ‘lock down’ regulations.
Explanation: The video is three months old. In December 2019, UP Police stopped Rahul Gandhi and Priyanka Vadra Gandhi from entering Meerut when they tried to meet the families of the persons who died during the anti-CAA protests.

Claim: False: Brazilians lighting candles after PM Modi’s call to stand in solidarity against the coronavirus.
Explanation: This event took place in Brazil before PM Modi’s call to stand in solidarity against the coronavirus.

Claim: Mostly false: Air India is operating evacuation flights to bring back stranded Indians from London.
Explanation: The Indian High Commission in London has denied the claim. There is no such immediate plan of evacuation.

Claim: False: “Arsenic album-30 homeopathic medicine can prevent coronavirus. Information given by Ministry of AYUSH.”
Explanation: According to the WHO, there is no evidence that any medicine can stop or cure the coronavirus. The WHO does not recommend any medication, including antibiotics, as a prevention or treatment of COVID-19. The AYUSH Minister Mr. Padnaik never claimed that arsenic album 30 can cure coronavirus.

Claim: False: A photo of a man and woman embracing has been shared on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that it shows two Italian doctors who died from COVID-19 after contracting the disease from the patients they treated.
Explanation: The claim is false; this is an Associated Press photo of a couple kissing at an airport in Barcelona, Spain.

Claim: FALSE: The government of Telangana is distributing special gifts to Muslims during their festival of Ramzan, amidst the lockdown.
Explanation: The image of the gift from Telangana state government to Muslims during Ramzan, is very old, and not from 2020.
Originated from: Editor in chief of a popular news website on Twitter

Claim: FALSE: Video shows 106 dead bodies in Delhi’s Loknayak hospital, in India.
Explanation: The video which is going viral with the claim that it has been shot at the Lok Nayak Jayaprakash Narayan Hospital of New Delhi is actually of a hospital in Mumbai.

Claim: FALSE: Teen spitting in tea bottle to spread the coronavirus.
Explanation: In 2019, a teenage boy did this in a supermarket in Texas.

Claim: FALSE: “Entire city of Mumbai will be under military lockdown for 10 days starting from Saturday. So please stock everything. Only milk and medicine will be available.”
Explanation: It was clear after reading several media reports, including a clarification made by the Mumbai Police on Twitter, about the viral claim that the state government has not fielded army personnel in Mumbai to follow the lockdown. The announcement in the Marathi language does not mention the army anywhere, but appeals to the people to stay in their homes. Also, No official announcement has been made by the state government for complete lockdown in the entire Mumbai for the next 10 days.

Claim: FALSE: A video of a coronavirus suspect found in Hazipur (Bihar, India) prison.
Explanation: The incident shown in the video is a mock drill conducted by Hazipur police team and medical personnel.

Claim: False: Coronavirus patients in China are caught by officials on a highway.
Explanation: The video shows a mock drill. The China SWAT team in the video is "practicing" how to deal with coronavirus patients.

Claim: FALSE: Government providing free smartphones to students amid coronavirus
Explanation: No, Government is not providing free smartphones to students amid coronavirus

Claim: FALSE: India’s main opposition party (Congress) general secretary Priyanka Gandhi arranged 1000 buses to take home the migrants stuck in the state of Uttar Pradesh.
Explanation: The image of buses arranged in a line on the road was taken in February 2019 during a fair organised by the state of Uttar Pradesh.

Claim: False: A video has been viewed thousands of times on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube in March 2020 alongside a claim that it shows police in Spain detaining people during a lockdown due to the coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The claim is false. The video has circulated in reports about an anti-government protest in Azerbaijan in October 2019.

Claim: FALSE: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson met reporters after recovering from COVID-19.
Explanation: The video dates back to August 2018 when Boris Johnson, who was not the prime minister of UK, had offered tea to the reporters while avoiding questions about the then burqa row.

Claim: FALSE: RSS Chief Mohan Bhagwant’s said that COVID-19 shook his faith in religion.
Explanation: This is a false statement from Mohan Bhagwat. He did not make this statement.

Claim: False: The WHO declared COVID-19 is the abbreviation for China Outbreak Virus in December 2019.
Explanation: The WHO declared the official name of coronavirus as COVID-19, which stands for coronavirus disease.

Claim: FALSE: In Bawana, India, this man was preparing to spread the coronavirus by injecting spit into the fruit.
Explanation: After studying the video which has gone viral on social media, we found that there is no truth in the claims being made on Facebook and Twitter. The video is being shared with the communal angle to confuse people.

Claim: FALSE: Indiand entral government providing free scholarship and online tuition classes to school children.
Explanation: FactCrescendo spoke with the district education director for Alappuzha, Mrs. Dhanya R. Kumar who has clarified that this is a fake message and there is no such scheme from either the central government or state.

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 Means ‘Certificate Of Identification Of Vaccination With Artificial Intelligence’
Explanation: No, COVID-19 Doesn’t Mean ‘Certificate Of Identification Of Vaccination With Artificial Intelligence’, Viral Post Is Fake

Claim: FALSE: Mumbai’s KEM hospital prescribed list of medicines to self-medicate for COVID-19
Explanation: The dean of the hospital said that the hospital did not issue any such statement on treating COVID-19

Claim: Misleading: A video shows people screaming in Wuhan because they feared the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video shows Wuhan residents whistling and shouting to commemorate Dr. Li Wenliang, the whistleblower of the virus who died on 2/7/20 after getting infected.

Claim: FALSE: A video showcasing successful trials completed for COVID-19 vaccine developed by PGIMER, in India.
Explanation: Trials for the vaccine have not been initiated yet and as per PGIMER it's too soon to declare the efficacy of the vaccine.

Claim: False: According to a report by the WHO, coronavirus lives the longest in the cabbage layer. Elsewhere the virus lives for 9-12 hours, whereas in cabbage, this virus lives for more than 30 hours. People of all cities are requested not to eat cabbage.
Explanation: The WHO has not said cabbage is dangerous because the coronavirus can live longer on it than on any other surface.

Claim: False: Kerala has asked NABARD for a loan of Rs 20,000 crore to deal with COVID-19.
Explanation: While it is true that the Kerala Government has announced a financial package of Rs. 20,000 crore to fight the pandemic, they have not asked NABARD for a loan of Rs 20,000 crore. They have requested for a special line of credit of Rs 2000 crore from NABARD under RIDF.

Claim: MISLEADING: Actor Amitabh Bachchan praises doctors by recording this message after he tested positive for COVID19.
Explanation: Amitabh Bachchan's video was uploaded in April 2020, not in July 2020.

Claim: FALSE: Doctor extracted kidney of a patient claiming the patient was coronavirus positive
Explanation: This is an old video of kidney theft allegation that went viral.

Claim: FALSE: Delhi public school selling face mask to students.
Explanation: Viral claim is false. DPS management denied this claim.

Claim: Misleading: A video says weed kills coronavirus.
Explanation: The news clip was created through a meme generator. The WHO has stated there are no cures for the virus.

Claim: FALSE: Video of the Kenya Government using a Maasai tribe man to impose social distancing in Kenya.
Explanation: The video is made by an ‘Entertainment’ based YouTube channel ‘Mbuzi Seller’. It doesn’t show a real-life incident. Also, there are no reports about the Kenyan government roping in Maasai tribe men to carry out stricter actions in the wake of coronavirus infections in the country.

Claim: Misleading: All employees of PNB Loni branch found coronavirus positive.
Explanation: Not all employees were COVID-19 positive. All were sent to quarantine as a precaution.

Claim: FALSE: Japanese Nobel laureate Tasuku Honjo announced that coronavirus is man-made.
Explanation: There is no newspaper or magazine article stating that Honjo made any statement on the origin of coronavirus

Claim: False: Italian PM said that the country has surrendered to the COVID-19 pandemic
Explanation: The quote attributed to the Italian PM is fabricated.

Claim: FALSE: China Seeks courts approval to kill 20000 people
Explanation: No, China didnt Seek courts approval to kill 20000 people. Fake post has resurfaced on social media.

Claim: FALSE: The trucks shown in the video are carrying dead bodies of COVID-19 victims.
Explanation: These trucks aren’t carrying the bodies of COVID-19 victims; instead they are carrying beds for patients.

Claim: Misleading: Coronavirus does not float in air but is grounded – UNICEF
Explanation: Neither UNICEF has issued any such advisory nor the information in the viral message is accurate.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows Dean of Kasturba Hospital telling gargling with salt water kills coronavirus.
Explanation: This is a false video going viral, that doesn't show the dean of Kasturba Hospital.

Claim: False: Indian State of Kerala’s government is paying news channels to telecast CM’s interview.
Explanation: These claims are raised by using screenshots of sponsored posts on the Asianet News Facebook page and some photos of CM's press meet which is broadcast on different TV channels with a sponsored tag. But the fact is the sponsored program is not CM's press meet. That's a program called "Naam Munnottu" to raise awareness about the government's different projects and also to interact with the CM. The last episode was about Kerala's hard work to eradicate coronavirus and for that they used a one minute portion from CM's press meet video. That photo was used in the Facebook post claiming gov giving money to channels to retelecast the press meet.

Claim: Misleading: Weed (cannabis) cures coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is misleading.

Claim: False: A video shows the new hospital set up in China for coronavirus patients.
Explanation: The video is found to exist on the internet since at least 2018.

Claim: FALSE: Celebrities and politicians attended an event at the home of an Indian billionaire and breached social distancing regulations during the coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The video and similar footage has circulated since September 2019 in reports about celebrities attending a Hindu festival celebration.

Claim: False: Chinese politician Xi Jinping has said that Chinese scientists found a cure for the coronavirus in cow urine.
Explanation: Chinese politician Xi Jinping did not make the statements about cow urine.

Claim: FALSE: Image shows thousands of devotees gathered in religious fair in India amidst lockdown.
Explanation: The image is old and was taken back in 2017. It is being shared out of context.

Claim: FALSE: Indian actor Aamir Khan distributed money in wheat bags to the poor.
Explanation: Aamir Khan himself denied this rumor. False news went viral in his name.

Claim: Misleading: Wearing face masks causes hypercapnia and thus are ineffective against COVID-19
Explanation: Research suggests that masks are useful in reduing the spread of COVID-19

Claim: False: People washing hands from the same pond before the prayers at Hazrat Nizamuddin is the reason for the spread of coronavirus in India.
Explanation: While the first positive case of COVID-19 in India was detected on 1/30/20, the video is available on the internet since December 2020 and cannot to linked to the events at Hazrat Nizamuddin.

Claim: FALSE: Viral audio clip of a Kannur based neurosurgeon suggesting remedies for the coronavirus.
Explanation: The neurosurgeon who was supposed to be the author of the clip stepped forward and denied that this was coming from him.

Claim: FALSE: Central government has given permission for schools to re-open.
Explanation: The central government has refuted the claim via Twitter.

Claim: False: Russia has allegedly unleashed over 500 lions in order to ensure that people stay inside their houses.
Explanation: The bulletin has been created using a template caled "Break your own news." The image of the lion dates back to 2016 and was taken in South Africa’s Johannesburg.

Claim: False: The photos show Indians bathing in cow dung to prevent infection.
Explanation: The photos show participants at an annual cow dung festival held in the southern region of India in October 2019, several weeks before COVID-19 was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

Claim: Fake: WHO issued proposal for extending lockdowns to control COVID-19.
Explanation: WHO issued proposal for extending lockdowns to control COVID-19.
Originated from: FB Page: श्री राधा विजयते नमः

Claim: FALSE: Karnataka Chief Minister attended H.D. Kumaraswamy’s son’s wedding amid nationwide lockdown.
Explanation: Though the wedding took place amid lockdown restrictions, Karnataka CM didn't attend the wedding. The image being shared is of H.D. Kumaraswamy's son's engagement took place before lockdown and the CM had participated in the engagement.

Claim: FALSE: Mustard oil can kill coronavirus.
Explanation: No, mustard oil cannot cure coronavirus; however, it has certain health benefits. The viral post claiming that mustard oil can kill coronavirus is fake.

Claim: FALSE: COVID19 can be transmitted through mosquitoes.
Explanation: Experts dismiss the claim that COVID-19 can be transmitted by mosquitoes.

Claim: FALSE: Video of dead bodies being thrown into a mass grave in Italy.
Explanation: The video is not of a real-life incident and it is also not related to the current COVID-19 outbreak in Italy. It is a clip from a movie - 'The Flu'.

Claim: False: There is a COVID-19 case in east Indian state.
Explanation: The local health authority said there are no confirmed novel coronavirus patients in the area as of 2/17/20.

Claim: False: An image shared on social media claims this Italian doctor couple worked day and night and saved the lives of 134 patients, but on the eighth day, they contracted the coronavirus and died after an hour.
Explanation: The couple in the picture is not Italian; they are from Spain. The photograph was taken at Barcelona Airport on 3/12/20.

Claim: False: Gargling with hot water cures coronavirus, says a doctor from Mumbai’s COVID-19 hospital.
Explanation: Gargling with water does not cure or prevent coronavirus, and this is not the doctor from the Mumbai hospital but a Tik Tok video with a pre-recorded video clip.

Claim: Misleading: “Ministry of Health ITALY released a small video, HOW the virus spreads!!!… BEST VIDEO. Please see ..how innocently it spread. SOAP is the remedy CLEAN/ WASH ur Hands always”
Explanation: The viral video was not released by the health ministry of Italy in the wake of coronavirus but has been on YouTube for a long time. We reached the conclusion that the viral claim is ‘Misleading’.

Claim: False: Russia has unleashed over 500 lions to ensure that people stay inside their homes amid the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The image on social media has nothing to do with Russia or the Russian president. The image is from South Africa’s Johannesburg, and the lion seen in the viral image was brought for film shooting by a production crew.

Claim: False: Finally India got its coronavirus Dashboard. This is the official website for coronavirus updates. This website is updated every four hours. Scroll down for more details; you can know more about coronavirus outbreak in your state by placing your finger on your state on the map.
Explanation: The website is not official and the tweet by a Bollywood superstar is misleading.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows a large crowd in the marketplace at Muhammad Ali road, Mumbai, violating lockdown.
Explanation: The video is, in fact, from Pakistan. It is being falsely shared as being shot in various cities in India.

Claim: FALSE: In Indore, India, Police and doctors are injecting coronavirus positive blood in Muslims.
Explanation: Indore SP denied all the claims made in the viral post.

Claim: False: China is planning to kill coronavirus patients.
Explanation: There is no information to prove that China plans to kill over 20,000 patients who have been infected by the coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Amid a massive surge of COVID-19 active cases in India, an image of a woman sitting on a road with oxygen cylinder has gone viral on social media. Captioned, “This is where India is right now,” the image shows a woman using an oxygen cylinder seated on a road with vehicles parked around.
Explanation: While the COVID-19 situation remains tense in India, we found that image in context is not related to the ongoing pandemic. It is in fact from 2018 in Uttar Pradesh.

Claim: FALSE: Kalonji seeds (Nigella Seeds) contain hydroxychloroquine and can help cure COVID-19.
Explanation: The claim being made in the social media posts lacks medical evidence. Experts told The Quint that neither do Kalonji seeds contain hydroxychloroquine nor is there scientific data to prove that the seeds can cure COVID-19. Further, whether HCQ can cure coronavirus is not totally clear.

Claim: False: Video of police killing COVID-19 affected people in China.
Explanation: The video was edited with three unrelated clips. Yiwu Police have clarified that the armed police in the video were on duty to kill a rabid dog. The last clip is related to an accident.

Claim: FALSE: Hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) was developed by an Indian scientist named Prafulla Chandra Ray.
Explanation: Hydroxychloroquine ware first synthesized in the mid-1940s during World War Two. Ray had no direct connection with the discovery or manufacture of hydroxychloroquine.

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 Testing Patent Was Submitted In 2015
Explanation: Post Claiming COVID-19 Testing Patent Was Submitted In 2015 is fake and has resurfaced on social media.

Claim: FALSE: Ratan Tata has said that human motivation and determined efforts will make experts’ predictions go wrong regarding the fall of the Indian economy during the COVID-19 crisis.
Explanation: The message has nothing to do with Ratan Tata. He clarified on his Twitter account that he neither said nor written that message. He also said that if he wan to say anything he will say it on his official channels.

Claim: Misleading: The picture shown in the post is of Dr Sundar Tolani who died due to coronavirus
Explanation: This is not the photograph of Dr Sundar Tolani who died of coronavirus.

Claim: False: As per Aajtak news channel, PM Narendra Modi announced a shutdown of internet services for a week.
Explanation: Screenshot is fake. PM Modi has not announced a shutdown of internet services.

Claim: FALSE: Dr. Li Wenliang (the Chinese whistleblower doctor) has proposed that drinking tea can cure COVID-19.
Explanation: While it is true that tea contains methylxanthines, there is no scientific evidence to suggest that drinking tea can cure COVID-19. Also, none reported about Dr. Li Wenliang, an Ophthalmologist, suggesting any such cure for COVID-19.

Claim: False: Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced a 14-hour curfew as the virus lives for 12 hours on surfaces.
Explanation: Research shows the study found the new coronavirus can live in the air for several hours and on some surfaces for as long as 2-3 days. These studies are not peer reviewed.

Claim: False: The Disaster Management Act has been implemented across India. As per the act, apart from the government departments, no other citizen is allowed to post or share any forward related to the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: India's Ministry of Home Affairs issued a notification on 3/24/20, the day the lockdown was announced. The notification stated that the Disaster Management Act of 2005 is being invoked to deal with the novel coronavirus. However, nowhere was it mentioned that no other citizen can post or share any forward related to the epidemic.

Claim: FALSE: Multiple Facebook posts have shared a purported roadmap for the Indian government’s plans to ease a nationwide coronavirus lockdown alongside a claim that it shows an official government announcement.
Explanation: The claim is false; India’s official Press Information Bureau said the government had not release any such plan and labelled the posts “fake news”; the dates included in the purported roadmap corresponded with the Irish government's "roadmap for reopening society and business" during the coronavirus pandemic.

Claim: FALSE: An Air India flight deployed to bring stranded Indians back home is not following social distancing norms, even after charging a hefty amount for the flight.
Explanation: The video is of a Pakistani aircraft carrier, Pakistan International Airlines (PIA).

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 Testing Patent Was Submitted In 2015
Explanation: Post Claiming COVID-19 Testing Patent Was Submitted In 2015 is fake and has resurfaced on social media.

Claim: FALSE: Top officials put a mask on a boy’s face while they themselves are not wearing masks, despite rising Covid-19 cases.
Explanation: The original photo was taken in November 2019, when authorities distributed masks to students to protect them from air pollution. India declared its first coronavirus case in January 2020.

Claim: FALSE: In Tamil Nadu’s Vellore, Muslims are offering namaz during lockdown.
Explanation: The video is from 2018.

Claim: Misleading: Social activist Trupti Desai was caught illegally buying liquor during the lockdown and was detained by the police.
Explanation: The video is being circulated with a fake claim. It is actually an old video of Desai from September 2019 showing social activist Trupti Desai being detained by police officials in Pune, after she threatened to garland Fadnavis with a necklace of liquor bottles. The video has nothing to do with the lockdown.

Claim: FALSE: Self-medicate COVID-19 using a home remedy with aspirin, lemon and honey.
Explanation: One should never consume medicine without doctors recommendation. The purporting home remedy is no cure or treatment for COVID-19.

Claim: False: With self-checkup you can find out if you are infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: Neither the World Health Organization (WHO) nor the government of India has stated anywhere that the coronavirus infection can be evaluated by the breath test as mentioned in the post. Some doctors have also mentioned that breath test cannot help in finding out if the person is infected with coronavirus.

Claim: False: Video of police in China taking into custody suspected COVID-19 patients in the country.
Explanation: The video shows police in Hong Kong taking into custody demonstrators who were protesting against a controversial bill that would have allowed extraditions to mainland China.

Claim: Mostly false: Blowing hot air through a hairdryer will cure coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no proven evidence that applying hot air through a hairdryer will cure coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows muslim women spitting in plastic bags and throwing them into the houses to spread coronavirus.
Explanation: When FACTLY contacted Gaurav Yadav (Superintendent of Police, Kota City), he clarified that the women in the video are not Muslims. He said that they belong to Hindu Bawari caste and they are not trying to spread coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Image of a couple claimed as activists Peter DeMello and Siraj Bilsara shared in connection with Palghar lynching.
Explanation: The viral image is of TISS professors Anjali Monteiro and K P Jayasankar. Their photographs were put in a fake news post on social media on the Palghar lynching. They have complained to Mumbai police cyber cell.

Claim: FALSE: In India, Kerala High Court orders Kerala government to cease business with controversial data analytics company Sprinklr while hearing a Public interest litigation suite on April 21, 2020.
Explanation: erala HC just sought an explanation from the state government regarding possession ofCOVID-19related data with controversial American data analytics company Sprinklr by 22nd of April and further hearing would be conducted on 24th April. No orders were passed in the hearing on 21st April.

Claim: False: China is planning to kill coronavirus patients.
Explanation: There is no information to prove that China plans to kill over 20,000 patients who have been infected by the coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: A video shows a COVID-19 patient running away from an isolation ward in Hyderabad
Explanation: The person being chased is a Dubai returnee from Kerala, NOT Hyderabad.

Claim: FALSE: Nobel Laureate Dr. Honjo has claimed COVID-19 virus to be man made in Wuhan Laboratory.
Explanation: Dr. Honjo has denied the claims. The claims lack evidence and are baseless.

Claim: False: Coronavirus discovered In broiler chicken.
Explanation: Unrelated images of ailing chickens claim coronavirus has been discovered in broiler chicken.

Claim: FALSE: The vaccine for coronavirus is ready. US President Donald Trump has announced that Roche Medical Company will launch it.
Explanation: Few unrelated images and videos have been put together to make this false claim. A vaccine has not been developed for the novel coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Image of a Muslim boy, Rizwan, who had died after being beaten up by Tanda (UP) Police for violating the lockdown restrictions mandated due to COVID-19 spread.
Explanation: Ambedkarnagar district Police clarified that, in their investigation, they have found that Rizwan was not beaten by the Police. Also, the Police has said that, in the postmortem report, it was mentioned that the deceased had an infection in lungs & heart and injuries due to falling from a motorcycle, which was confirmed by a local doctor.

Claim: False: Scientists have found that drinking bitter gourd juice can cure coronavirus.
Explanation: The World Health Organization (WHO) or the Ministry for Health & Family Welfare (India) hasn't announced that drinking bitter gourd juice will cure coronavirus. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) has clarified that the message is ‘fake’.

Claim: False: Shopping malls crowded in Italy during the pandemic.
Explanation: Old video from Brazil shared with false context

Claim: FALSE: Video shows COVID-19 infected corpses into the seas.
Explanation: This is an image of a ship wreck off the coast of Libya in 2004.

Claim: Misleading: The timetable shown in post is the new coronavirus quarantine schedule
Explanation: In case someone has coronavirus symptoms they should always contact the medical experts rather than follow the quarantine schedule as mentioned in the post. The viral post is misleading.

Claim: FALSE: Former Chief Justice of India Ranjan Gogoi tweeted that to compensate the economic loss occured due to coronavirus, no elections should be held in the country for the next 10 years because elections cost a lot of money.
Explanation: Ranjan Gogoi does not have a Twitter handle. He has made no such statement.

Claim: False: Italian president said that Italy has surrendered to the coronavirus.
Explanation: Neither the Italian prime minister nor the president have stated that Italy has surrendered to the virus. We even cross checked with Italian fact checkers.

Claim: False: Picture shows clothes of those who have died of coronavirus in China. Beijing is now shipping these clothes to Africa.
Explanation: The picture is at least seven years old and has nothing to do with coronavirus.

Claim: False: If you can hold your breath for more than 10 seconds, you are not infected by coronavirus.
Explanation: Holding your breath for 10 seconds cannot confirm whether or not you are infected with the coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: It was claimed that Israelis discovered vaccine for Coronavirus and no more deaths will be there
Explanation: The Defense Ministry of Israel denied the claim as its team is still closing in on developing a vaccine for the coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Coronavirus is losing potency, as per WHO
Explanation: WHO didnt say that coronavirus is losing potency, post falsely attributed to WHO. The fake post has resurfaced on social media.

Claim: Mostly false: Fire triggered by gas tanker leak near Delhi’s Shahdara Mor.
Explanation: Video is not from Delhi but Lahore's Shahdara Mor in Pakistan.

Claim: FALSE: A video clip shows a doctor couple who died after treating 134 COVID-19 patients.
Explanation: The viral clip has been taken from a popular Mexican series “Triunfo del Amor” (2010). It is being shared with a false claim related to coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: A doctor who went to Uttar Pradesh (a state in India) to screen patients for coronavirus, was attacked with stones by Muslims. She succumbed to her injuries.
Explanation: The woman is a doctor from Madhya Pradesh (a state in India) who died of brain hemorrhage, and not because Muslims attacked her..

Claim: False: Indian Government and the WHO advised people not to purchase colors from China for Holi.
Explanation: No such advisory was shared by the government or the Ministry.

Claim: Mostly false: Inhaling the steam of sea salt and orange peelings can prevent coronavirus infection.
Explanation: There is no scientific proof of the claim; the WHO does not mention this remedy.

Claim: FALSE: In Nagpur’s Medical Hospital, the kidney of the patient was removed and the excuse was made that the patient had corona.
Explanation: A video of death at the Cooper Hospital in Mumbai has gone viral with the fake claim that the patient’s kidney was removed in the Nagpur-based hospital.

Claim: FALSE: The post shows dead bodies of COVID-19 patients lying in the LNJP Hospital, Delhi (India).
Explanation: Video is from Mumbai's hospital and not from a hospital in Delhi.

Claim: Misleading: Lemon and bicarbonate can cure coronavirus.
Explanation: Doctors and experts say there is no medical evidence to corroborate the claim.

Claim: FALSE: Thyroce lab in Thane, India is sealed over false positive covid-19 testing.
Explanation: This lab was not shut down over false positiveCOVID-19testing.

Claim: half true: Photo of an Italian doctor waving goodbye to co-doctors as he is about to die due to coronavirus.
Explanation: The viral photo was taken at a hospital in China's Wuhan when the team of doctors was treating a COVID-19 patient.

Claim: FALSE: Viral claims that holding your breath can test for COVID-19.
Explanation: The claims are false because the World Health Organization and other experts said there was no evidence to support these claims.

Claim: FALSE: Please note the differences: (1) dry cough + sneeze = air pollution (2) cough + mucus + sneeze + runny nose = common cold (3) Cough + mucus + sneeze + runny nose + body ache + weakness + light fever = flu (4) Dry cough + sneeze + body pain + weakness + high fever + difficulty breathing = coronavirus. Pathology department AIIMS, Delhi. Make this message available to as many people as possible!
Explanation: No, AIIMS has not released a statement explaining symptoms of coronavirus or other diseases. Also, COVID-19 affects different people differently. The viral post is fake. Fake post resurfaced on social media.

Claim: FALSE: Livfavir and Fabiflu are both medicines that can be used to treat COVID-19.
Explanation: The viral message regarding the medicine is fake. Livfavir is not certified to be sold in market as on now.

Claim: False: BBMP (Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike) will be spraying medicine in the air after 10 PM tonight in order to kill COVID-19.
Explanation: The BBMP Commissioner and the Mayor have clarified that the message is just a rumor and the BBMP has no such plans to spray any medicine for COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Coronavirus found in gutkha or chewing tobacco samples sold in Indian state of Maharashtra as raw material sourced from China.
Explanation: The image was photoshoped with an old TV channel screengrab with new text. No such broadcast made by the TV channel.

Claim: Misleading: Chickens cause coronavirus.
Explanation: There has been no confirmation of a link between chickens and the new coronavirus. The WHO has said that it is looking into animal sources.

Claim: Mostly false: An audio clip claiming to be of renowned heart surgeon Dr Devi Shetty is going viral on Facebook, Twitter, and WhatsApp.
Explanation: The viral clip has been falsely attributed to Dr Devi Shetty.

Claim: FALSE: India’s Home Ministry has given permission to reopen schools and educational institutions across India.
Explanation: The viral screenshot is digitally edited. No such permission has been given by the Home Ministry to reopen educational institutions.

Claim: FALSE: An image of a market carrying out social distancing passed off as Mizoram, India
Explanation: The image is from Myanmar and not Mizoram in India as claimed by social media users.

Claim: FALSE: A video of a 14-year-old Indian boy named Abhigya Anand who was alleged to have predicted the coronavirus in 2019.
Explanation: The 14-year-old Indian boy featured by some media not only failed to predict the coronavirus, but made other predictions of which none have come true, such as World War III.

Claim: False: Pakistan’s Dr. Usama Riaz, who contracted coronavirus while treating patients, had left a video message before he died.
Explanation: The various social media posts claiming that the person in the video is Dr. Usama Riaz are misleading. The man in the recording is Mubhasir Ahmed, who has been living in the United Kingdom.

Claim: False: Ratan Tata, Indian industrialist spoke about how the Indian economy would bounce back and that he did not believe experts predicting a slowdown.
Explanation: Ratan Tata refuted making any such claim. The statement was picked up from a random blog.

Claim: False: A picture claims that an Italian man committed suicide after his whole family succumbed to COVID-19
Explanation: The image is of a woman committing suicide in Spain in December 2019. BOOM could not establish what drove the woman to take such a step.

Claim: Misleading: Johns Hopkins states that Uttar Pradesh in India is the best performing state when ranked for handling the COVID-19 crisis
Explanation: Johns Hopkins university conducted a case study highlighting features of the COVID-19 management by the state of Uttar Pradesh without giving any rankings about the same

Claim: False: A purported advisory has been shared repeatedly in multiple Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp posts that claims a disinfectant will be sprayed into the air overnight in India in an effort to kill the novel coronavirus, COVID-19. The posts urge residents to remain indoors during the spraying.
Explanation: The claim is false; Indian authorities said the advisory was "fake" and that no such measure had been announced.

Claim: False: Video of Indian activist Tripti Desai’s arrest by police after selling bottles of liquor during lockdown.
Explanation: The video was taken in September 2019 when police took Trupti Desai into custody as part of preventive action before the visit of the then Chief Minister of Maharashtra, Devendra Fadnavis, in Pune.

Claim: FALSE: A COVID-19 patient was caught by the police in the Gorakhpur district in the state of Uttar Pradesh, India.
Explanation: The video is of a mock drill conducted by the district police to tackle coronavirus, and the person caught in the video is just a subject for the drill and not a COVID-19 patient.

Claim: FALSE: WHO Has Ranked Sri Lanka Fifth Best Country For Covid-19 Response
Explanation: The World Health Organization hasn’t ranked Sri Lanka fifth best country for Covid-19 response’. Fake post is going viral on social media.

Claim: False: People in Wuhan are locked inside their houses by the Chinese government.
Explanation: The video shows people in Wuhan offering their respects to the whistleblower, Dr. Li Wenliang.

Claim: FALSE: People are offering prayers in groups on rooftops despite lockdown. That too when cases of coronavirus in India are continuously increasing.
Explanation: The picture being shared is not of India but of Dubai. People in Arab countries have been called to follow the lockdown and offer prayers in their homes.

Claim: FALSE: The experts at Nanavati Hospital are giving four common treatments to all patients: Vitamin C, dry ginger, turmeric and steam.
Explanation: No doctor from Nanavati Hospital in Mumbai has recommended the four treatments mentioned in the viral message to COVID-19 positive patients. The claim in the Whatsapp message is fake.

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 testing patent was filed in 2015, thus covid19 is a scam
Explanation: Vishvas News investigated the post and found that the viral image is the screenshot of the child application that was filed in year 2020 following the submission of the parent patent application in 2015 that was not related to COVID-19. In fact, the parent application is generalized for a method of “acquiring and transmitting biometric data.” The post is viral with the fake claim.

Claim: False: Chinese intelligence officer reveals coronavirus is a bioweapon.
Explanation: The story originated from a Reddit thread which discusses horror stories inspired by true events.

Claim: Misleading: Thrombosis and not pneumonia is a leading cause of COVID-19 deaths and the disease has so far been wrongly diagnosed.
Explanation: Thrombosis is emerging as a significant cause but is still not the leading cause of COVID-19 deaths. The disease has not been wrongly diagnosed and is being actively researched upon.

Claim: FALSE: Photo of people following social distancing in a market in Manipur (India).
Explanation: The photo claiming to be that of people following social distancing in a market in Manipur (India) was actually captured at the Kalaw market in the Shan state of Myanmar.

Claim: Misleading: Many media outlets, through unnamed sources, published reports that Indian Railways has announced a new set of rules and guidelines for traveling after the lockdown ends.
Explanation: Indian Railway has denied this stating that Ministry of Railways has not issued any protocol regarding passenger travel during post lockdown period, as has been incorrectly reported in some media reports. As and when a decision is taken, all stakeholders would be intimated. Please do not be guided by any misleading report.

Claim: False: Chicken infected from coronavirus found In Bangalore.
Explanation: The image is old and not related to the 2019 novel coronavirus.

Claim: False: “WORLD HEALTH ORGANISATION PROTOCOL & PROCEDURE OF LOCKDOWN PERIODS FOR CONTROLLING  ON MOST DANGEROUS VIRUS: STEP 1-1 DAY. STEP 2-21 DAYS. AFTER 5 DAYS. STEP 3-28 DAYS. AFTER 5 DAYS. STEP 4-15 DAYS.”
Explanation: Nowhere has the WHO spoken of the process of phased lockdown to fight the coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Video of Muslims violating lockdown conditions in Old city (Hyderabad).
Explanation: The video was captured when migrant workers stuck in Telangana due to lockdown came onto the streets in Tolichowki asking the government to send them to their native places. It has nothing to so with Old City in Hyderabad where most of the Muslim population resides

Claim: FALSE: A Facebook user shared a video that shows dead bodies being washed ashore at some unidentified beach.
Explanation: The video doing rounds on social media has no connection with the coronavirus pandemic. The disturbing video doing rounds is of the bodies of African immigrants washing onto the shore of al-Qarbole, after a boat carrying 200 illegal immigrants from sub-Saharan Africa sunk off the Libyan capital.

Claim: FALSE: Dr Uma Kumar from AIIMS Delhi gave interview regarding immunity boosting tips.
Explanation: Dr Uma denied this claim; she has not given the interview as shown in the viral post.

Claim: FALSE: Indian’s Ruling party BJP-run state Manipur is India’s first coronavirus free state.
Explanation: The claim was made on the assumption that there was only oneCOVID-19patient in Manipur who got discharged. However, there was one more patient who is still receiving treatment in RIMS, Imphal. Besides that, there are hundreds kept in quarantine by the state government.

Claim: Misleading: Madhya Pradesh National Health Mission employees flouted COVID-19 guidelines to celebrate
Explanation: The video is from a women's day celebration where all precautions were undertaken

Claim: Misleading: A detailed message claiming that the vaccine is useless and futile
Explanation: The message dissuades people from signing up for the vaccine by misleading people with information about how vaccines are not 100% effective.

Claim: FALSE: Mouthwash kills and cures the new coronavirus
Explanation: Post claiming mouthwash can kill coronavirus or can cure it is fake.

Claim: False: Amid the coronavirus pandemic, Health Minister of India is playing Ludo.
Explanation: The picture is almost one year old.

Claim: FALSE: The woman shown in this photo holding a baby is COVID-19 positive.
Explanation: The photo is 35-years old and is falsely linked with coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Video of birds flocking together at Bangalore airport in india, during the lockdown in the country to contain COVID-19 spread.
Explanation: The video shows birds flocking together at a riverfront in Ahmedabad (Gujarat). Also, it is of an incident prior to the announcement of nationwide lockdown which came into effect from 25 March 2020.

Claim: FALSE: An audio message attributed to famous Bangalore doctor’s voice said people need not get tested for Coronavirus till the ninth day of showing symptoms and not to wear masks as the medical staff need them utmost.
Explanation: We found the voice, which belongs to a Chennai doctor who admitted that he had sent the message in his personal group in order to instill confidence in a friend.

Claim: False: Tamil Siddhas mentioned herbal medicine for COVID-19.
Explanation: It’s not coronavirus, it’s a herbal medicine named corajana. Someone edited the name from an old medicine guide and shared it on social media.

Claim: FALSE: Flower named Brahmkamal bloomed after decades due to the decrease of pollution caused by the lockdown.
Explanation: It is a 3 year old video. Botanists confirm that this flower blooms every year.

Claim: False: Office Memorandum of the Indian Ministry of Health and Family Welfare declaring holidays to the states of Maharashtra, Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh and Sikkim in the wake of COVID-19.
Explanation: The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare has not declared holidays in the states of Maharashtra, Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh and Sikkim. The Office Memorandum with such information is fake.

Claim: Misleading: The girl shown in a video is Russian President Putin’s daughter, who volunteered for the COVID-19 vaccine
Explanation: The girl shown in the video is not the daughter of Russian President Vladimir Putin but a volunteer named Natalia.

Claim: FALSE: Image of Pakistani youth protesting for hydroxychloroquine.
Explanation: The image is edited to make the false claim.

Claim: False: Coronavirus has gripped Italy and nobody is willing to carry corpses off Italy’s streets.
Explanation: The photo was taken on 3/24/14 in Frankfurt, Germany, and shows people lying down on a pedestrian area to remember victims who lost their lives in a Nazi concentration camp.

Claim: FALSE: Screenshots showing chyrons of two TV channels say that people belonging to the Brahmin and Rajput castes cannot get infected by COVID-19 because their blood is warm.
Explanation: The claim has no scientific basis. The TV channels have now shown any such news; the screenshots of channel templates are doctored to add the fake text.

Claim: False: Chinese court gave permission to kill 20,000 patients infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no evidence that the Chinese court had ordered to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients.

Claim: FALSE: Bill Gates and Anthony Fauci seen walking in close proximity without mask during the coronavirus pendemic.
Explanation: This picture of Bill Gates and Anthony Fauci was taken in 2018, viral with fake claim.

Claim: False: Indian cricketer Sachin Tendulkar asked for meat shops to be banned in lieu of COVID-19.
Explanation: Claim was falsely attributed to the cricketer.

Claim: Mostly false: WHO advisory asks people not to consume bakery items as they get contaminated by coronavirus easily.
Explanation: The WHO has not issued any such advisory. There is no evidence that bakery items get easily contaminated by coronavirus.

Claim: : The video shows Italians praying to get rid of the coronavirus.
FALSE: An Indian doctor who had gone to collect coronavirus samples in Uttar Pradesh was stoned to death.
Explanation: The picture is of a pharmacist from Madhya Pradesh who died due to brain haemorrhage and was not stoned to death.

Claim: FALSE: Nostradamus predicted Coronavirus pandemic 500 years ago.
Explanation: Nostradamus did not predict about COVID-19 500 years ago.

Claim: False: Drinking warm water with lemon protects against the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Health experts say there is no proof this is effective.
Factchecked on: 2020/03/08 Australia, India, South Africa, Ivory Coast

Claim: FALSE: A man in Italy commits suicide after losing his family to coronavirus.
Explanation: Video is from 2015 when a man jumped off a building in Philadelphia and is not linked to coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Fenugreek Seed Tape Can Cure Throat Infection During COVID-19
Explanation: Fake post claiming Fenugreek seed tape is a cure for throat infection during COVID-19 has resurfaced. Health experts have refuted the viral claim.

Claim: False: A video shows a truck dropping bodies covered with plastic into a ditch and claiming that this is the situation in Italy right now.
Explanation: The video which is being widely circulated on social media is not from Italy. It is a movie scene that had been taken from the 2007 U.S. television miniseries "Pandemic."

Claim: False: Indian Home ministry declares posting about COVID-19 on WhatsApp groups a punishable offence.
Explanation: Indian Home ministry has not issued any such message.

Claim: False: Coronavirus has been found in broiler chicken.
Explanation: The claim is fake.

Claim: FALSE: A TikTok video showing a woman buying liquor after the ease of the coronavirus lockdown in Mumbai claims that she is Bollywood actress Deepika Padukone.
Explanation: The woman in video is another actress, Rakul Preeth Singh and she was buying medicines, not liquor.

Claim: Misleading: A video has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim it shows New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern visiting a Hindu temple after declaring the country had reached its 100th consecutive day of no local coronavirus transmissions.
Explanation: The claim is misleading; the video shows Ardern visiting the temple on August 6, 2020, three days before the country hit its 100-day milestone; on August 11, New Zealand recorded four new locally transmitted COVID-19 infections after 102 consecutive days of no community infections.

Claim: FALSE: Patanjali CEO denies saying that Coronil can cure COVID-19
Explanation: The press release by Patanjali as well as the first press conference endorsed it as a cure

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 is fake and just a coverup for 5G technology.
Explanation: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), to date, there is no vaccine and no specific antiviral medicines against COVID-19. The claim that a "vaccine” contains a chip to give personal information to authorities is baseless and false.

Claim: MISLEADING: Photo representing the suffering of a migrant worker during the current lockdown in India.
Explanation: While it is true that the migrant workers are facing a lot of problems due to the current lockdown in the country, the photo is not related to India. The photo is an old one. It shows a Rohingya man walking into Bangladesh.

Claim: : Video of stone-pelting by people when health officials went to trace the Nizamuddin guys in Indore, MP.
FALSE: World Health Organization (WHO) approved Coronil, an Indian herbal medication, as a Covid-19 treatment.
Explanation: While Coronil was approved as a Covid-19 treatment by Indian government regulators, it has not been certified as a coronavirus treatment by the WHO as of February 26, 2021.

Claim: Misleading/False: A WhatsApp forward has gone viral which claimed that a vaccine for coronavirus has been discovered. The viral forward also claims that the treatment for coronavirus is mentioned in India’s Intermediate Zoology book. The viral forward reads, “It is not a new disease as it is already mentioned in the Intermediate zoology book along with its treatment. It happens sometimes that many great scientists and doctors do not focus on lesser-known books as they are mostly busy with famous books. Book name: Zoology, Writer: Dr. Ramesh Gupta, Page No. 1072.) Friends, this is not fake news so I request you to kindly share it maximum so all coronavirus patients are treated in time.”
Explanation: The virus being talked about in the viral claim is not the novel coronavirus(Covid-19) but SARS. WHO has clearly negated the discovery of any vaccine that can cure Covid-19. In an answer to the question, “Are there any medicines or therapies that can prevent or cure COVID-19?”, the WHO replies, “While some western, traditional or home remedies may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms of COVID-19, there is no evidence that current medicine can prevent or cure the disease.

Claim: Misleading: A viral photo displays a vial of the vaccine, with text along the top that says, “Now this was 2001 tell me why 19 years later they say there is no vaccine share before they take it down again.”
Explanation: Social media posts featuring a photo of a vial of canine coronavirus vaccine is legitimate, but the vaccine is for a gastrointestinal issue in dogs and has nothing to do with COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Photo of people following social distancing in a market in Manipur (India).
Explanation: The photo claiming to show people following social distancing in a market in Manipur (India) was actually captured at the Kalaw market in the Shan state of Myanmar.

Claim:
FALSE: 1. Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang visited a mosque and seek protection to the country from coronavirus. 
2. Chinese president Xi Jinping visited a mosque in China after realizing the fact that only Allah can save China from this epidemic.
Explanation: The first video is of former malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi who visited a mosque in China during his visit in 2015. The second video is also an old one, President Xi Jinping paid a visit to the Xincheng Mosque in Yinchuan city, capital of NW China's Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region on Tuesday, July 19, 2016.

Claim: False: Image of Kerala CM Pinarayi Vijayan following PM Modi’s appeal to light lamp on 5th April 2020.
Explanation: It is an old image from 2018 shared as a recent one.

Claim: FALSE: Viral pictures show organ trafficking of COVID-19 patients dead bodies.
Explanation: No these are not the pictures of organ trafficking of coronavirus patients dead bodies. This is a fake post going viral.

Claim: FALSE: Video of Asha workers being attacked by locals in Telangana when they went to screen people who attended Delhi Nizamuddin prayers and are suspects for having COVID-19.
Explanation: The incident in the video took place in Indore, not in Telangana. Some locals of Tatpatti Bakhal of Indore had pelted stones at health workers who went there to screen people in the wake of COVID-19 outbreak.

Claim: FALSE: Muslim women went out to shop despite the lockdown in India.
Explanation: The video is not from India but from Pakistan. Secondly, it is five years old.

Claim: FALSE: The owner of the Indian jewellry group Joyalukkas died due to COVID-19.
Explanation: The Joyalukkas founder is healthy. There was a confusion between the company and Joy Arakkal, a Dubai-based businessman who died of COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: A Muslim boy is spitting on bread slices to spread coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is from Philippines, recorded in September 2019. A delivery man of a bread-making company is recorded stealing slices of bread from the packets.

Claim: FALSE: A photo has been shared hundreds of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim it shows a nurse apologising to a Muslim man after she blamed the Muslim community for spreading COVID-19 in India. The posts claim the nurse was forced to apologise by a local politician.
Explanation: The claim is false; the nurse, the politician and local police all said the photo in fact shows a man receiving first aid after sustaining a laceration to his leg; additional photos and footage also show the man’s injury.

Claim: False: Coronavirus outbreak attributed to an advisory from India’s Health Ministry.
Explanation: The notification is falsely attributed to India's Health Ministry.

Claim: FALSE: Coronavirus does spreads through frozen food.
Explanation: Coronavirus does not spread through frozen food.

Claim: FALSE: Doctors in Bengaluru are killing COVID-19 patients instead of treating them
Explanation: Two unrelated videos have been spliced together to create this fake narrative about doctors killing patients

Claim: misleading: 100 nurses together in Rajasthan’s “Jhalawar” quit their jobs because Qurantined Muslims spat on them
Explanation: Our investigation revealed that the nursing staff of Jhalawar Medical College, Rajasthan, resigned because of lack of necessary safety equipment at the hospital to rescue patients of COVID-19 and salary.

Claim: Mostly false: Tokyo Olympics logo has been redesigned on the theme of social distancing.
Explanation: The Tokyo Olympics logo has not been redesigned.

Claim: FALSE: 48 coronavirus patients found in quarantine center in Sultanpuri, in Delhi, India and all those belong to Jamaat.
Explanation: Post claiming 48 people found coronavirus positive in quarantine center in Sultanpuri is fake.

Claim: FALSE: This coronavirus-infected patient reached to Dr. Vinod Kumar but he wasn’t given the treatment. He was later referred to Bhagalpur. It further states that one should avoid meat and fish for 3 months and wear mask to protect yourself from coronavirus.
Explanation: The post claiming that coronavirus infected patient reached Bihar and is not given treatment is fake. Health authorities dismiss the hoax report. Further, WHO has also not recommended to avoid fish and meat. It recommended thoroughly cooking meat and eggs. Wearing mask is, however, advisable.

Claim: FALSE: Image of an old man carrying his mother and walking claimed to be migrants walking home due to the lockdown.
Explanation: This image is of Rohingya Muslims from Bangladesh and not related to the lockdown in India.

Claim: Misleading: COVID-19 has its own pH value
Explanation: Coronavirus doesn’t have its own pH value. Alkaline diets are not a cure for COVID-19

Claim: FALSE: The Gandhi siblings- Priyanka and Rahul broke down the lockdown enforced in India and were roaming around.
Explanation: This video is from 2019 when the siblings had visited Meerut to meet the anti-CAA protestors.

Claim: False: A video is going viral on WhatsApp and Sharechat claiming that the man and woman in the video are doctors who treated 75 coronavirus patients and now they both are infected by it.
Explanation: The claim associated with the video is false and misleading. They are not Italian doctors who treated 75 coronavirus patients and got infected but are actors from a Mexican television series "Triunfo del Amor."

Claim: False: Gargling with lukewarm water mixed with salt/vinegar will remove coronavirus.
Explanation: Press Information Bureau (India) has clarified that coronavirus cannot be treated by gargling with warm water mixed with salt and vinegar.

Claim: False: Donald Trump said, “People are dying who have never died before”
Explanation: The quote has been on the internet for over a decade attributing it to different people at different times.

Claim: FALSE: Video of a Tablighi Jamaat member roaming naked and creating ruckus in the isolation ward.
Explanation: The video is an old one. It is related to Pakistan. It has no relation with any of the OCIVD-19 cases in the country.

Claim: Misleading: Video shows a parasite being removed for someone’s lips, sharing it in relation with coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was uploaded on YouTube on October 24, 2019 with the title “Amazing Botfly Removal on Lips”.

Claim: FALSE: The kidney of the deceased taken out in Nagpur hospital by claiming the patient had the new coronavirus
Explanation: Video of Cooper hospital Mumbai is going viral with false claim.

Claim: FALSE: Image of Kaziranga national park in Assam, India during lockdown.
Explanation: The images were taken 5 years back and has got nothing to do with the current lockdown.

Claim: FALSE: Following the coronavirus pandemic, film star Salman Khan has given 200 ambulances to the India.
Explanation: Searching through several tools, it was found that Salman Khan's Foundation has donated just one ambulance. The claim of Salman Khan giving 200 ambulances in the fight against coronavirus is misleading.

Claim: False: Look at the condition of a Karimnagar person who is infected with the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video in the post is not related to India. A doctor from Ecuador has posted in her Twitter account that the video was taken in Ecuador.

Claim: False: PM Modi announced internet suspension due to viral fake news related to COVID-19.
Explanation: The news bulletin image is digitally edited. No announcement of an internet ban was made by PM Modi.

Claim: FALSE: Senior officials of Rajasthan police visited Ajmer Sharif Dargah
Explanation: Ajmer Dargah is closed due to Corona, Rajasthan Police's presence here is false

Claim: misleading: A video has been shared repeatedly on Facebook and Twitter in April 2020 alongside a claim it shows corpses in body bags at an apartment that is home to a New York-based Islamic group. The posts claim the victims died in the apartment after contracting the novel coronavirus because they ignored social distancing rules.
Explanation: The claims are misleading; the footage in fact shows body bags at an Islamic funeral home in New York during the coronavirus pandemic; a spokesperson for the mortuary told AFP that the deceased were people of many faiths.

Claim: False: Coronavirus was found in meat (mutton).
Explanation: The photo in the post was edited. Also, the photo was taken five or six years ago. WHO and FSSAI have also mentioned that properly cooked meat can be consumed.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows a doctor from Breach Candy Hospital of Mumbai claiming that If you can hold your breath for a longer period without discomfort, you don’t have Coronavirus.
Explanation: Breach Candy Hospital has clarified to Fact Crescendo that the person in the video does not work for them. Experts have already debunked that being able to hold your breath for 10 seconds doesn't mean someone doesn't have coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: The Government of Andhra Pradesh has made Kanipakam temple a quarantine center for coronavirus suspects.
Explanation: The building in the video is not Kanipakam temple, it is a pilgrim lodge (‘Sri Ganesh Sadan’) in Kanipakam that is being used as a quarantine center by the Andhra Pradesh government.

Claim: FALSE: Lion walking in a road and is going to Vaishno Devi shrine during lockdown.
Explanation: This video is from Uttrakhand, not Vaishano Devi.

Claim: Misleading: Government of India recommends homeopathy and other alternative medicines for preventing coronavirus.
Explanation: THe World Health Organization has stated that there are no proved preventions and treatments for this virus. The mechanisms mentioned by the AYUSH ministry are not scientifically proven to help in tackling coronaviruses.

Claim: False: This video shows goats affected by the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is an old one. It was taken before the recent coronavirus outbreak. Also, the Minister for Animal Husbandry, Dairying and Fisheries has clarified that there is no evidence to show that eating mutton can transmit coronavirus.

Claim: False: News channels suggest drinking tulsi and noni juice will help prevent the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: A morphed screenshot of the news channel was used to support the false claim.

Claim: Misleading: UNICEF recommendations: coronavirus is large in size where the cell diameter is 400-500 micro and for this reason any mask prevents its entrance. There is no need for pharmacists to sell muzzles. The virus does not settle in the air but is grounded; it is not transmitted by air.
Explanation: The message is misleading and has the potential to cause fear in India.

Claim: FALSE: A student from Pondicherry University in India has found a home remedy for COVID-19 that has been accepted by World Health Organization (WHO).
Explanation: Post claiming a student from Pondicherry University has found a home remedy for COVID-19 that has been accepted by World Health Organization (WHO) is fake. Pondicherry University refuted the claim made in the viral post. World Health Organization (WHO) has also not approved any medicine or vaccine as a cure for COVID-19, as of publication.

Claim: False: China has sought to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients to control the spread of the virus.
Explanation: There is no evidence to support the claim, which originates from a suspicious website.

Claim: FALSE: A graphic video has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim it shows two Islamist extremists killing a Hindu man in the Indian state of Rajasthan during India’s COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: The claim is false; police in Pakistan and several media outlets report that the attack took place in Pakistan’s Punjab province in March 2020; people can be heard speaking in Punjabi in the video.

Claim: Misleading: Doctors in Tumkur hospital fake taking the vaccine for a photo-op but do not actually receive the vaccine
Explanation: The doctors had taken the vaccine earlier but sat again only for the sake of taking a photograph

Claim: Mostly false: Bats responsible for the outbreak of coronavirus originated from the rooftop of a house in Wuhan.
Explanation: The video is about nine years old and is from Miami, USA.

Claim: Mostly false: India has developed a treatment for coronavirus.
Explanation: India has not developed a treatment.

Claim: FALSE: Home remedies mentioned in the post can cure coronavirus
Explanation: No, home remedies mentioned in the post wont kill coronavirus

Claim: False: Coronavirus found in broiler chicken
Explanation: No evidence proves this claim. The WHO has clarified that meat cooked properly can be consumed.

Claim: False: Video shows a family that died from novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was found on the internet since the last week of December 2019. But the first death from the novel coronavirus was not reported until the second week of January 2020.

Claim: FALSE: A person who visited Badusha Hypermarket, Perambra was found COVID-19 positive and hence all those who have visited the hypermarket on 16th July 2020 are asked to report to Perambra Taluk Hospital.
Explanation: The Hospital has said that the message is fake

Claim: FALSE: In a mall in Saudi Arabia, there was a sale and as soon as the shutter was opened, many women entered together flouting social distancing norms.
Explanation: The video was uploaded on the internet in December 2019 and has no relation to the current lockdown. It was revived after Saudi Arabia eased lockdown restrictions from April 25, 2020.

Claim: FALSE: Applying mustard oil to the nostril will let the novel Coronavirus move to the stomach where it will be killed by the stomach acids.
Explanation: Applying mustard oil to the nostril does not make coronavirus move to the stomach.

Claim: FALSE: research by scientists at the University of Queensland, Australia has proven that bananas prevent coronavirus by boosting immunity due to their vitamin B6 source.
Explanation: As multiple vaccines have been authorised for emergency-use in various countries, a video circulating on Whatsapp falsely represents work being done by scientists at the University of Queensland, Australia claiming bananas prevent coronavirus.

Claim: Misleading: Garlic water can cure the new coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no proof that garlic water is a coronavirus cure.

Claim: FALSE: Amitabh Bacchan tests negative to COVID-19
Explanation: Amitabh denied this claim.

Claim: FALSE: Experts in China found that the coronavirus can be spread through houseflies.
Explanation: According to WHO, there is no evidence or information to suggest that the COVID-19 virus transmitted through houseflies. The virus that cause COVID-19 spreads primarily through droplets generated when an infected person coughs, sneezes or speaks

Claim: FALSE: Family of poor migrant commited suicide during lockdown in India.
Explanation: Old picture is falsely linked with lockdown; it is not recent.

Claim: FALSE: Indian Railways cancelled all regular trains until September 30th due to the new coronavirus
Explanation: The claim of cancelling all trains till September 30 has been proven wrong. Indian Railways has denied this claim by tweeting itself.

Claim: FALSE: Passengers complaining about over charging and no social distancing on Air India flight.
Explanation: Video of passengers complaining about over charging and no social distancing belongs to Pakistan airlines, not Air India.

Claim: FALSE: American students are siging the Indian national anthem, as a gesture of thanking India for supplying Hydroxychloroquine to USA.
Explanation: The video is three years old and has no relation to coronavirus or Hydroxycholoroquine.

Claim: FALSE: Old video of a Chinese man portrayed as a scared Thailand Health Minister while taking COVID-19 vaccine
Explanation: This video shows a Chinese man crying out of fear while taking the first injection of his life. This video exists on the internet since 2018. It has nothing to do with the Thailand Health Minister and the COVID-19 vaccine

Claim: FALSE: Video of a train claiming to be of Pakistan sending oxygen to India after the announcement by Imran Khan
Explanation: The video is of the Oxygen Express started by the railways for the smooth movement of oxygen tankers and containers across the country.

Claim: FALSE: Delhi Health Minister Satyendar Jain said that not a single one of the 30 thousand in Markaz was found coronavirus positive.
Explanation: The claim shared with the post is false. The post misquotes him and has clipped a part of a larger video.

Claim: FALSE: Muslim man is spitting on food in a restaurant in India.
Explanation: Muslim man spitting on food at Indian restaurant is from Malaysia, not from India.

Claim: FALSE: Samsung is giving free phones to students during coronavirus pandemic for online studies.
Explanation: No, Samsung is not offering free phones to students during coronavirus pandemic. The viral post is fake. Samsung has also asked to beware of such phishing scams.

Claim: False: Sick COVID-19 patients at the airport runway in Senegal.
Explanation: Video is old and not from Italy. It actually shows a mock drill carried out on 11/28/19 at Blaise Diagne Airport in Dakar, the capital of Senegal. It has nothing to do with coronavirus.

Claim: False: Italy has surrendered to the coronavirus pandemic as all the measures to control COVID-19 have been exhausted.
Explanation: Prime Minister of Italy Giuseppe Conte in his recent statement said: "We are giving up the most expensive habits, we do it because we love Italy, but we do not give up courage and hope in the future. United, we will do it." He did not talk about surrendering.

Claim: FALSE: The incident of lynching of two Indian monks in Palghar amid lockdown was communal.
Explanation: The Home minister of Maharashtra and Maharashtra Police have repeatedly denied any communal angle in the incident.

Claim: FALSE: Students in Karnataka test positive after appearing for the COMEDK exam
Explanation: News clippings were morphed to report that children tested positive when they had not

Claim: Misleading: A video is being shared on various social media platforms and in WhatsApp groups in which a person allegedly infected with COVID-19 can be seen lying unconscious on the ground and shaking violently.
Explanation: According to the testimony of a doctor working in the hospital, the person shown in the video is not infected with COVID-19 but having an epilepsy attack. It can be concluded that the video is being shared with a misleading claim.

Claim: False: Stones were hurled at police in Gomtipur, Ahmedabad (India), when they went to search for suspects who attended the Nizamuddin Markaz event in Delhi.
Explanation: The police commissioner of Ahmedabad has clarified that the police were attacked while they were enforcing lockdown. Police were not searching attendees of the Nizamuddin Markaz event.

Claim: Misleading: COVID-19 was known to humans before its outbreak in 2020.
Explanation: The new coronavirus (which causes COVID-19) was first reported in December 2019. All the old images and videos being shared on social media refer to the virus as coronavirus, not as SAR-CoV-2 (or COVID-19). coronaviruses were known to humans decades ago. All the references made on social media were about the coronaviruses, a general term for various viruses which cause diseases ranging from the common cold to Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).

Claim: False: Pigs mulled in China are blamed for coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is from the African swine flu outbreak in China in 2018-19.

Claim: FALSE: Any person arrested for violating lockdown in the night will not get bail until the lockdown is over in the state of Gujarat, in India.
Explanation: Gujarat Police have clarified that no such order has been issued. It is a hoax.

Claim: FALSE: WHO has taken a U-turn and now says that Coronavirus-infected patients neither need to be isolated, nor quarantined, nor needs social distancing. It further claims that the infected people cannot even transmit virus from one patient to another
Explanation: The viral post is falsely attributed to WHO and the claims are misleading.

Claim: False: WhatsApp group admins will be arrested if anyone shares any joke/information about the coronavirus.
