Explanation: The message quotes the Disaster Management Act to say that action will be taken. But the sections it mentions say nothing about disseminating information. The message is alarmist in nature and creating panic.

Claim: FALSE: Nurses resigned due to COVID-19 because Jamati patients misbehaved with them.
Explanation: The nurses resigned due to low wage, no Jamati has been admitted to the hospital.

Claim: FALSE: Muslims scattered currency notes on a road in Indore to spread coronavirus.
Explanation: The currency notes shown in the video are not thrown on the road by anyone with the intention to spread coronavirus. When FACTLY contacted Indore police, they said these currency notes slipped on the road from a gas cylinder delivery boy’s clothes. Also, the name of the person who lost money on the road is Ram Narendra Yadav. He is not Muslim.

Claim: False: Garlic soup can cure the coronavirus.
Explanation: According to the WHO, there is no cure for the new coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Video: Migrant labourers in Kerala gambling with huges stashes of cash amid lockdown.
Explanation: An old and unrelated video is used to make the claim.

Claim: Misleading: A video that shows dead bodies being taken away in a convoy of cars is from a hospital in Iran.
Explanation: The viral video doing rounds on social media claiming that this is a scene outside a hospital in Iran due to the novel coronavirus is false. The viral video is of a funeral procession for pilgrims who died during Hajj in 2019.

Claim: FALSE: DPS (Delhi Public School) is selling masks with its logo printed on it to students for Rs.400 each.
Explanation: The school authorities have clarified these masks have no association with them, some mask vendors have used the school branding on the masks without permission from the school authorities.

Claim: False: Photo of Kanika Kapoor meeting Prince Charles during her recent visit to the United Kingdom. Prince Charles tested positive for coronavirus just after the meeting.
Explanation: The photo was taken in 2015 when singer Kanika Kapoor attended the Elephant family charity, "Travels to my Elephant," hosted by Prince Charles and Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall.

Claim: False: A photo of a man and woman embracing has been shared on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that it shows two Italian doctors who died from COVID-19 after contracting the disease from the patients they treated.
Explanation: The claim is false; this is an Associated Press photo of a couple kissing at an airport in Barcelona, Spain.

Claim: False: Photos of coronavirus patients being treated on the road in Italy.
Explanation: The photos in the post are related to the earthquake in Croatia on March 22. Patients at the hospital were evacuated because of the earthquake.

Claim: FALSE: Qatar canceled all Air India Flights in their Vande Bharat Mission (Tto bring back Indian citizen from Qatar).
Explanation: The Embassy of India in Doha expressed that a few media channels were making a baseless claim about flight IX-374 from Doha to Thiruvananthapuram being canceled because of differences over landing and handling charges. None of it is true.

Claim: FALSE: Migrant workers travelling in special shramik trains are wasting food.
Explanation: The migrant workers were not wasting food. They were not eating as the food was of a very low quality.

Claim: Mostly false: China is supplying the Quran to people to read after the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: This seven-year-old video has no relation to coronavirus.

Claim: False: A video shows the effects of coronavirus and suggest people avoid ice cream and cold drinks for 90 days.
Explanation: Video shown in the viral post showing a person removing larvae from the lips using a pair of tweezers is old and unrelated to coronavirus. The claim in the viral post is also refuted by medical professionals.

Claim: False: Seven children died from coronavirus within one week in Karimganj (Assam, India).
Explanation: Public health officials have denied any coronavirus deaths. The children died in a span of two months due to fever and other illnesses.

Claim: FALSE: Images of a large funeral procession in Gujarat for an Indian politician who died after contracting Covid-19
Explanation: The video actually shows a procession for an Indian politician in the Indian state of Maharashtra after he was shot dead in November 2020.

Claim: False: Israel and USA have come up with a vaccine.
Explanation: Israel has found a vaccine with properties similar to COVID-19; San Diego had developed an algorithm.

Claim: FALSE: Muslim boy in Madhya Pradesh, India attacked by BJP workers for violating lockdown.
Explanation: There is no communal or political angle to the incident. Local boys attacked a man who was not Muslim but Hindu.

Claim: False: The WHO has issued an alert against buying holy colors from China
Explanation: The WHO hasn't issued an advisory against buying Holi colors from coronavirus-hit China. The claim is fake.

Claim: FALSE: WHO and UN will give 1.7 crore as COVID relief fund
Explanation: WHO and UN will not give 1.7 crore as COVID relief fund. Viral post is falsely attributed to the organizations

Claim: False: Amid COVID-19 lockdown, food is being distributed in the Indian State of Tamil Nadu.
Explanation: It's an old image from Gambia (West Africa)

Claim: FALSE: Claim that inhalation of steam for a week eliminates coronavirus
Explanation: Old claim resurfaced and debunked citing on WHO guidelines

Claim: FALSE: A message issued from India’s ministry of Home Affairs says that posting coronavirus-related messages will be punishable offence.
Explanation: The ministry of Home Affairs has issued no such message. The person in whose name the message is circulated does not exist in the office.

Claim: False: Russia released 500 lions to ensure people would stay inside houses.
Explanation: This photo is from 2016, showing movie production in South Africa.

Claim: FALSE: A video claimed that a fruit vendor was licking his fingers while arranging oranges.
Explanation: The claim that the fruit vendor was licking the fruits was true but the video was filmed before the coronavirus outbreak in the country.

Claim: Mostly false: Italian PM broke down over coronavirus deaths in his country.
Explanation: The man seen crying in the image is Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro and the incident has nothing to do with the coronavirus outbreak.

Claim: False: Video of American President Donald Trump announcing that Roche Medical Company will launch the vaccine for COVID-19.
Explanation: In the video, American President Donald Trump hasn't said that Roche Medical Company will launch the vaccine for COVID-19. He announced FDA’s approval of a coronavirus ‘test’ developed by a company ‘Roche’ to increase and accelerate the country’s capacity to test for the virus.

Claim: FALSE: it shows Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine (vaporizer cartridge), which is made in China.
Explanation: The Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine is given as a shot in the muscle of the upper arm, not inhaled as vapour. The ‘Pfizer’ company has clarified to Reuters that the vaporizer cartridge is fake

Claim: Misleading: A WhatsApp forward claims Prime Minister Narendra Modi called for a 14-hour long “Janta Curfew” on 3/22/20 from 7 a.m. to 9 p.m. because the lifespan of the coronavirus in one place is only 12 hours and if we all follow the Janta Curfew religiously, then the chain will be broken
Explanation: There is no clear information on the lifespan of the novel coronavirus. However, various studies have suggested a similar lifespan as that of other coronaviruses. PM Modi’s motive behind calling for a "Janta Curfew" was to curb the spread of novel coronavirus and the government has not claimed the Janta Curfew is called to kill the virus. The claim is misleading.

Claim: False: Picture of Sao Paulo graveyard, being prepared secretly for COVID-19 victims by Brazil government.
Explanation: This is an old image from Manaus in Brazil and is unrelated to recent events due to COVID-19.

Claim: Misleading: No more deaths from COVID-19 as Israeli scientists have discovered a vaccine.
Explanation: Various vaccines proposed by Israeli scientists and other researchers across the world are under development and are yet to be cleared for production and distribution. Israel’s MIGAL Research Institute is also in the process of producing a vaccine for COVID-19. According to the WHO, as of 3/11/20, there is no vaccine for COVID-19.

Claim: False: Over 500 years of Adhan (The Islamic Call to Prayer) ban lifted in Spain amid coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is false. There was no ban in Spain on Adhan (The Islamic Call to Prayer) for over 500 years.

Claim: FALSE: Mumbai municipal body asks people to drink boiled water as a remedy to coronavirus
Explanation: The clipping is from 2018 when the Municipal body asked people to consume boiled water as the available water was turbid

Claim: False: A video showing a police officer briefing about cases being registered against the WhatsApp group admins is shared in the context of coronavirus lockdown.
Explanation: Our research revealed that the viral video is of a two-year-old press conference. It is being shared with a misleading claim.

Claim: False: Indian Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) issued an order that sharing post about coronavirus on social media groups is a punishable offense.
Explanation: Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) has not declared that post related to coronavirus on social media is a punishable offense. Also, the Press Information Bureau (PIB) has clarified that the Ministry of Home Affairs has not issued any such order.

Claim: FALSE: Palm oil is a simple cure for the coronavirus.
Explanation: The post claiming palm oil is a simple solution for coronavirus is fake. There is no evidence to prove this. This has been falsely attributed to WHO.

Claim: FALSE: An image showing food supplies placed on an open ground for COVID-19 lockdown affected areas in Indonesia.
Explanation: It's an old image from the Gambia. It has nothing to do with coronavirus.

Claim: Mostly false: Coronavirus fears in Germany result in large crowds outside the supermarket.
Explanation: The viral video is 9 years old and has nothing to do with COVID-19.

Claim: False: Video of dead bodies being piled up in Italy due to COVID-19.
Explanation: The video is not of a real-life incident. It is a clip from the 2007 TV series "Pandemic".

Claim: FALSE: Video shows quarantined patients dancing in a COVID-19 center in Mumbai.
Explanation: The viral video is from the eastern state of Tripura. It is being falsely shared as being shot in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows a huge crowd of migrant workers gathered in Surat, India due to lockdown.
Explanation: The video is from Delhi and is falsely being attributed to different cities in India.

Claim: Mostly false: Pope Francis contacted coronavirus.
Explanation: The Vatican confirms Pope Francis has not contracted coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: A man who attended the Tablighi Jamaat event in Delhi, India, spit on cops intending to spread Corona virus.
Explanation: VIdeo shows someone spitting on Police personnel, not Tabligi Jamaat attendee.

Claim: FALSE: A senior police inspector is infected with COVID-19 in Bhagalpur Central Jail in India.
Explanation: This is a mock drill video from Bhagalpur Central Jail.

Claim: FALSE: Over 300 people in Jaipur contracted COVID-19 after coming in contact with a indian monk who was smoking chillum.
Explanation: No such event occurred in Jaipur and the newspaper clipping is fake.

Claim: FALSE: Deepika Padukone was buying liquor during the lockdown in India as soon as the shops opened.
Explanation: It was another Indian actress Rakul Preet Singh who had stepped out to buy medicines during the lockdown.

Claim: FALSE: Coronavirus (COVID-19) is large in size where the cell diameter is 400-500 micro and for this reason any mask may prevent its entry – UNICEF
Explanation: The viral message on Coronavirus (COVID-19) is neither from UNICEF nor accurate.

Claim: Misleading/False: A WhatsApp forward has gone viral which claimed that a vaccine for coronavirus has been discovered. The viral forward also claims that the treatment for coronavirus is mentioned in India’s Intermediate Zoology book.
Explanation: The viral forward reads, “It is not a new disease as it is already mentioned in the Intermediate zoology book along with its treatment. It happens sometimes that many great scientists and doctors do not focus on lesser-known books as they are mostly busy with famous books. Book name: Zoology, Writer: Dr. Ramesh Gupta, Page No. 1072.) Friends, this is not fake news so I request you to kindly share it maximum so all coronavirus patients are treated in time.” The virus being talked about in the viral claim is not the novel coronavirus(Covid-19) but SARS. WHO has clearly negated the discovery of any vaccine that can cure Covid-19. In an answer to the question, “Are there any medicines or therapies that can prevent or cure COVID-19?”, the WHO replies, “While some western, traditional or home remedies may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms of COVID-19, there is no evidence that current medicine can prevent or cure the disease.

Claim: False: A video of former Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein has been shared repeatedly on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram alongside a claim it shows him stating the U.S threatened to spread the novel coronavirus in Iraq during a meeting in the 1990s.
Explanation: The claim is false. The video's audio has been doctored. The original Associated Press archive footage does not include any reference to COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Viral message showing roadmap to ease restrictions during COVID-19 is from India.
Explanation: Viral Message Showing Roadmap To Ease Restriction’s During COVID-19 Is NOT From India but from Ireland.

Claim: False: Russian president using lions to ensure people stayed indoors in Russia.
Explanation: The lion is roaming on a Johannesburg street as part of a film production in 2016.

Claim: MOSTLY FALSE: Video of patients dancing in a COVID-19 quarantine centre is from Mumbai.
Explanation: Video of patients dancing at COVID-19 quarantine centre is not from Mumbai, but Tripura.

Claim: FALSE: An image of a train with the inscription “COVID-19”.
Explanation: The company that owns the wagon confirmed that it is misinformation.

Claim: FALSE: Migrant labourers are killing people in Delhi due to coronavirus lockdown.
Explanation: The men in the video are not migrants but two locals who have a criminal background. Cops told The Quint that the video was being shared with a misleading claim.

Claim: FALSE: Brahma Kamal flowers bloom after many years due to less pollution during the lockdown in India to contain COVID-19 spread.
Explanation: The video used to make the claim is found to be on the internet at least since December 2017. Also, Brahma Kamal flowers usually bloom every year during June – September, and the flowers can be seen till mid-October. Hence there is no relation between the flower blooming and less pollution.

Claim: FALSE: Dr.Charles Lieber, chair of Harvard University’s Chemistry and Chemical Biology Department was arrested for manufacturing and selling the coronavirus to China.
Explanation: Dr.Charles Lieber was arrested for making false, fictitious and fraudulent statements because he did not disclose details of the funds he received from China. His work has nothing to do with COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Boy washing apples in a sewer claimed to be from India and is linked to the coronavirus
Explanation: The video is not from India but is an old video from Pakistan.

Claim: False: Audio clip of a conversation claiming that Government of India will announce shutdown of the country in the coming days from 4/15/20 to 6/15/20 in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak
Explanation: PIB found the audio clip of the phone conversation discussing a "complete lockdown" of the country to be fake. WHO India has also confirmed the audio is fake.

Claim: Misleading: Video shows aid denied to Hindus shared in India.
Explanation: Relief aid distributed later to Hindus. The incident happened in Bangladesh.

Claim: FALSE: Member of Indian parliament Rahul Gandhi hired actors to act as migrants who he was helping during the COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: These were actual migrants walking from Delhi to UP and MP in India and this was not staged.

Claim: False: New confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Kolkatta reported by Press Trust of India.
Explanation: There are no confirmed coronavirus patients in Kolkata, as confirmed both by the airport authority of Kolkata and the Traveller.

Claim: FALSE: A video claims COVID-19 patients are sitting in the hospital corridor of Gandhi Hospital in Hyderabad
Explanation: It was the hospital staff sitting in the hospital corridor not the COVID-19 patients

Claim: FALSE: An unidentified virus that has affected the tomato crop in Maharashtra is a deadly form of coronavirus.
Explanation: The virus in the tomato seeds is being studied and there is so far no link to coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: A Facebook user shared a video that shows dead bodies being washed ashore at some unidentified beach.
Explanation: The video doing rounds on social media has no connection with the coronavirus pandemic. The disturbing video doing rounds is of the bodies of African immigrants washing onto the shore of al-Qarbole, after a boat carrying 200 illegal immigrants from sub-Saharan Africa sunk off the Libyan capital.

Claim: False: Coronavirus has infected broiler chicken.
Explanation: There is no evidence that broiler chicken has been infected with coronavirus.

Claim: Mostly false: Tea can cure COVID-19 patients, as suggested by China’s whistleblower doctor Li Wenliang. The news was published by CNN.
Explanation: No scientific proof suggests that tea can cure COVID-19 patients. CNN didn’t publish this news.

Claim: FALSE: Ramakrishna Hospital is sealed after its staff tested Covid-19 positive.
Explanation: Ramakrishna Hospital was not sealed after its staff tested COVID-19 positive. Hospital authorities clarified the rumours.

Claim: Misleading: Clorox Already Knew About coronavirus And coronavirus Isn’t A New Virus.
Explanation: The claim that the new coronavirus was known beforehand on a Clorox label shows that it kills human coronavirus is misleading.

Claim: FALSE: American students thank Indians for hydroxychloroquine by singing the Indian National Anthem.
Explanation: It's an old video created by an Indian YouTuber and has got nothing to do with hydroxychloroquine or COVID-19.

Claim: False: Video shows people behaving abnormally in China due to coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is old and does not show the recent coronavirus outbreak.

Claim: FALSE: Patients dancing in NSCI Quarantine center in Mumbai.
Explanation: Video is old and of a quarantine center in Tripura.

Claim: FALSE: A list of precautions issued by the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR-Delhi) to stay safe from the COVID-19 virus.
Explanation: ICMR has not issued the list of precautions mentioned in the post. Also few of the precautions mentioned in the list are scienfically unproven.

Claim: False: Multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter claim the WHO has warned against eating cabbage during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The claim is false. The WHO said it did not issue any such advisory against consuming cabbage. The U.S.-based CDC says there is "no evidence to support transmission of COVID-19 associated with food."

Claim: Misleading: Can cannabis cure coronavirus?
Explanation: There is no government mandate, research or WHO comments supporting cannabis as a cure for coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Alappuzha market in India closed due to discovery of COVID-19 positive patients in the area.
Explanation: The market was closed for heavy vehicles and no COVID-19 cases were reported in the area.

Claim: FALSE: ICMR issued a report claiming the number of people infected with thte coronavirus increased up to 8 Lakh if india did not announce a lockdown.
Explanation: ICMR did not publish any such report about the possible numbers of COVID-19 infected people.

Claim: False: In an Aaj Tak news report, the Chinese prime minister said, “Reading Quran and offering namaz is the only cure for COVID-19.”
Explanation: It is a clipped video of Aaj Tak’s fact-check. In the full version, Aaj Tak debunked the claim and concluded that no such statement was made by the Chinese PM.

Claim: FALSE: As per WHO’s ‘Protocol and Procedure of Lockdown Periods’, lockdown will be relaxed from April 15-19 and will be re-imposed from April 20 in India.
Explanation: No such WHO protocol or procedure exists for lockdowns.’ WHO South-East’ has tweeted that the message is baseless and fake.

Claim: FALSE: The Government of India has released a five-phase road map to ease COVID-19 restrictions in the country.
Explanation: The five-phase road map in the message was not issued by the Government of India. It was issued by the Government of Ireland to reopen the country's economy and society.

Claim: MISLEADING: Israeli scientists developed a vaccine for the novel Coronavirus.
Explanation: Israeli Scientists did not discover any vaccine for COVID-19.

Claim: False: Mustard oil prevents a person from getting infected with COVID-19.
Explanation: Neither the WHO nor the the Ministry for Health & Family Welfare (India) has announced that using mustard oil can prevent a person from getting infected with COVID-19. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) has clarified that the message is fake.

Claim: FALSE: Migrants are beating people up for money in Delhi.
Explanation: The video is of April 2020 and the accused are minors and not migrants.

Claim: FALSE: Image of poor family in Uttar Pradesh, India that committed suicide due to lockdown.
Explanation: The image was taken before the lockdown was enforced. The suicide has nothing to do with the current lockdown across the country.

Claim: False: Effects of the new coronavirus on an infected person’s lips.
Explanation: The video shared a effect of coronavirus on a patient lip is found to be on the internet at least since November-2019, before the recent epidemic broke out. So, it is not related to the recent coronavirus epidemic.

Claim: FALSE: The Indian Army in Rajasthan prepared a 1000-bed facility to keep Coronavirus patients. This facility has ICUs and ventilators as well.
Explanation: The images are three years old and have no relation to coronavirus. The Indian Army has prepared no such facility.

Claim: FALSE: Hotels to remain closed in India till 15 October 2020.
Explanation: Ministry of Tourism took to its official Twitter account to clarify, saying, “The MoT, GoI, requests your attention to kindly refrain from forwarding a certain fake message regarding the closure of hotels/restaurants. We assure you that we have not issued such a message.”

Claim: FALSE: Some reporters visited the British Prime Minister Boris Johnson after he recovered from his illness. His home looks like an old abandoned military hut with very old brick walls. The living room was too small so brought out the tea tray for the reporters. All the cups are different. He met them with disheveled hair and casual clothes, but with the confident smile of a Prime Minister
Explanation: The video of UK's PM Boris Johnson doing rounds on social media is from 2018 when he was not even Prime Minister

Claim: False: Audio claiming India would be put under a complete lockdown.
Explanation: The government dismissed claims of such a lockdown.

Claim: FALSE: Civil Services Examination in India has been cancelled due to coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: Indian Government has clarified that Exams have been postponed, not cancelled as claimed. Rescheduling will be notified on the website.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows the last COVID-19 patient exiting from the hospital in New Zealand.
Explanation: Video is, in fact, from Italy. It shows the closing down of a coronavirus ward in the town of Matera.

Claim: FALSE: A video showing a Muslim woman misbehaving with doctors in India.
Explanation: This video is from Pakistan. It is not from India.

Claim: FALSE: Trucks are carrying dead bodies of patients who passed away due to coronavirus.
Explanation: Trucks are carrying medical equipment and not the dead bodies of coronavirus patients.

Claim: FALSE: Telangana (India) Chief Minister violated lockdown norms and distributed gifts among Muslims to celebrate Ramzan.
Explanation: The picture used to make the claim is nearly five years old. Secondly, we found a sound bite of the chief minister where he himself said that no gifts will be distributed this year due to coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: The message claimed that under the Disaster Management Act (DMA), nobody except the Indian government can update and post coronavirus related information on social media.
Explanation: No such rules exist. The Indian government issued a clarification.

Claim: FALSE: Video of women fleeing from a quarantine center during the current lockdown in Shivaji nagar, Bangalore.
Explanation: The video was taken in Karachi (Pakistan) and it is not related to the current lockdown in India. The same video was found to be uploaded on YouTube and Facebook in 2015 with the title: ‘Sex workers fleeing after FIA raid at a brothel in Karachi’.

Claim: False: A video shows a bat-infested roof in Hubei, China, claiming to be the source of the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was shot in Miami, Florida, in 2011.

Claim: FALSE: Bill Gates faces trial in India for illegally testing vaccines.
Explanation: The recurrent hoax is that the co-founder of Microsoft and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation illegally tested drugs with "devastating results" in the health of 30,000 children. This is false. On the contrary, the Prime Minister of India publicly expressed his gratitude to that foundation for the work related to health in that country.

Claim: Mostly false: The viral video claims mass graves are in Italy.
Explanation: The viral video is part of a TV series called "Pandemic." The viral scene is not from Italy.

Claim: FALSE: “Dr. VK Srinivas, Vice-President of Bharath Biotech, He is taking first injection of COVID 19 vaccine. They have confidence in their product.”
Explanation: Dr. VK Srinivas was giving his blood sample for routine procedure when this photo was shot. He did not participate in a COVID19 clinical trial.

Claim: False: A video purporting that an attack on doctors was avenged by policemen.
Explanation: A set of doctors were attacked in India when they went about collecting samples for COVID-19. This video is not a revenge by policemen for the same and is not linked to coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: A news clipping attributed to Hindi daily Dainik Jagran stating that coronavirus was found in poultry in Bihar, India.
Explanation: Dainik Jagran did not report this, this is a photoshopped picture and the state ministry did not conduct any checks on poultry

Claim: FALSE: Sloth bear seen in a house garden in Sri Lanka during the COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: This is an old video of slothbear in a garden in Tamil Nadu, India. It has no relation with lockdown or Sri Lanka.

Claim: FALSE: Image of people participating in a ‘Chariot pulling’ festival in Kalabari district (Karnataka) despite the current lockdown in the country implemented to handle COVID-19 spread.
Explanation: The image is old and is that of a ‘Chariot pulling’ event in Koppal district (Karnataka). It was found to exist on the internet at least since 2017.

Claim: False: Bollywood superstar Aamir Khan donated Rs. 250 crore to tackle the novel coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The image on social media claiming that Bollywood star Aamir Khan has donated Rs 250 crore to fight the novel coronavirus is misleading as the actor has not donated anything yet. British boxer Amir Khan has offered his retail outlet to the NHS to help COVID-19 patients.

Claim: FALSE: CCTV footage shows a robbery happened in Mumbai amid COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: The CCTV footage is from Delhi and has no connection to Mumbai.

Claim: FALSE: Drinking pigeon membrane slurry can cure COVID-19.
Explanation: Drinking pigeon membrane slurry won’t cure coronavirus. The viral post is fake.

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 is a bacteria causing death due to thrombosis.
Explanation: COVID-19 is a virus and the theory is baseless and false without any proper source or credibility.

Claim: FALSE: Doctors of a hospital in New Zealand are cheering in this video after they cure the last COVID-19 patient of their country and shut the COVID-19 ward.
Explanation: The video is from a place in Italy's Madonna delle Grazie where doctors cheered after no more COVID-19 cases were registered.

Claim: FALSE: Gargling with warm salt water prevents Coronavirus.
Explanation: coronavirus cannot be cured by gargling with warm water, saltwater or vinegar.

Claim: FALSE: Homeless man in Punkunnam, Kerala, India, tested positive for COVID-19.
Explanation: The Thrissur District Medical Officer has refuted the claim.

Claim: FALSE: Gujarat (India) chief minister Vijay Rupani’s resignation is accepted by the BJP high command.
Explanation: BJP has refuted the rumor of CM VIjay Rupani's resignation during the pandemic. These are baseless messages that went viral.

Claim: False: China seeks court’s approval to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients.
Explanation: The post is false.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows migrant workers raising “long live Pakistan” slogans when returning their home state during lockdown.
Explanation: Migrant workers were, in fact, saying "Sajid Bhai Zindabad". Fact Crescendo spoke to Sajid Siddiqui, whose name they were chanting. He told us that his party has facilitated the free return journey of many migrants.

Claim: FALSE: Indian ayurvedic pharmaceutical Patanjali claimed that the ayurvedic ministry had now approved the sale of the COVID-19 ayurvedic medicine coronil produced by the company
Explanation: The AYUSH ministry had only acknowledged the receipt of the clinical trial documents from the company and did not approve the sale of the coronil COVID-19 medicine

Claim: FALSE: People have thrown currency notes on road to spread the COVID-19 infection.
Explanation: The currency notes in the streets of Indore was accidently dropped by a cooking gas delivery man while he was cycling.

Claim: False: A video shows monkeys attacking Gandhi Hospital in Hyderabad
Explanation: This is an old video of Monkeys attacking RK Khan hospital in Durban, South Africa

Claim: Mostly false: A photo of COVID-19 patients lying on beds in an isolation ward in Pakistan.
Explanation: The photo is two years old and has nothing to do with COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: As the AC in malls are shut due to Indian malls being shut due to COVID-19, leather of objects in showrooms has started moulding and people should not buy things from malls.
Explanation: The image is from Malaysia and not India.

Claim: False: Filmmaker Sudhir Mishra getting beaten up by police during the lockdown for stepping out of home.
Explanation: The man getting beaten up by police is not filmmaker Sudhir Mishra.

Claim: : Dr. Megha Vyas from Pune died of COVID-19.
False: Indian Ministry of Health and Family Welfare issued an office memorandum declaring compulsory holiday in four Indian states.
Explanation: Ministry of Health India has denied the notification.

Claim: FALSE: Dr. Devi Shetty released a controversial audio clip on COVID 19.
Explanation: VIral audio features the voice of Dr. Santosh Jacob, Not Dr. Devi Shetty of Bangalore.

Claim: False: The homeopathic drug Arsenicum Album 30 can prevent coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence to support the claim that Arsenicum Album 30 can prevent coronavirus. The WHO does not list any medications that can prevent infections.

Claim: Mostly false: Drinking bitter gourd juice cures the coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no proven evidence from any research so far which establishes that bitter gourd juice cures coronavirus.

Claim: False: The label on Dettol disinfectant spray claims it is proven to “kill coronavirus;” the company knew about the new strain since 2019.
Explanation: The recent outbreak in China is COVID-19. The source of infection, animal host and reservoir are currently unknown.

Claim: FALSE: A family (husband, wife, child) committed suicide because they could not bear hunger. They were migrants travelling to their hometown during the lockdown, from a city named Surat in India.
Explanation: The image of the family committing suicide is from 2018, and the incident had taken place in Maharashtra.

Claim: FALSE: Bollywood actor Aamir Khan is helping the needy during the COVID-19 crisis by sending flour bags with cash in them.
Explanation: Aamir Khan has clarified that he is not the person who is putting money in the wheat bags. He said that the story is either fake or some person who does not want to get revealed might be doing such donations.

Claim: FALSE: List of points from an interview of HDFC bank’s Managing Director Aditya Puri stating how India will survive and make it big post the current lockdown due to COVID-19.
Explanation: Neeraj Jha, Head of Corporate Communication for HDFC Bank, has clarified that while few of the points in that message were from Puri's recent interviews, the bulk of the points were wrongly attributed to him.

Claim: False: This is the video of Congress leaders Rahul and Priyanka Gandhi breaking coronavirus lockdown by stepping out.
Explanation: The viral video is four months old and has no connection to the coronavirus.

Claim: misleading: A photo of a handwritten letter which shows an Indian hospital’s letterhead has been shared in multiple Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp posts alongside a claim that it is a genuine prescription issued by a doctor at the hospital for a COVID-19 patient.
Explanation: The claim is misleading; the hospital denied that the prescription was issued by one of their doctors and said the signature was forged.

Claim: FALSE: A TV news screenshot says the home ministry of India has indicated that the country will be under lockdown after 15 June.
Explanation: The government of India has clarified this is false news. There is no such decision has been taken.

Claim: FALSE: People in the city of Mumbai, India are not following social distancing, and have gone outside their homes to shop for the festival of Eid.
Explanation: The video is from a market in Pakistan, not India. The market was opened after the Pakistan government relaxed some lockdown restrictions.

Claim: FALSE: White House is selling commemorative COVID-19 coins for $100.
Explanation: A private company called “White House Gift Shop” is selling commemorative coronavirus coins. These are not sanctioned by the US government or White House.

Claim: FALSE: Japan’s Nobel Prize winning Professor of Medicine, Professor Dr Tasuku Honjo has claimed that the coronavirus is not natural and that China manufactured it.
Explanation: As the message went viral, Kyoto University has published a statement on behalf of Professor Tasuku Honjo. Tasuku Honjo in his statement said, ‘I am greatly saddened that my name and that of Kyoto University have been used to spread false accusations and misinformation’

Claim: FALSE: A photograph of a woman hugging her young child before she died of COVID-19 in Italy.
Explanation: The photograph is related to a stem cell transplant captured in 1985 and is not related to the coronavirus.

Claim: False: The new coronavirus pH varies from 5.5 to 8.5. To defeat it, we need to consume more alkaline food.
Explanation: The new coronavirus does not have its own pH. It is pointless to assume that alkaline food could prevent an infection.

Claim: FALSE: An Ayurveda practitioner Devender Sharma gave false COVID-19 positive reports to 125 patients who had not contracted the virus, and then killed them for their kidneys.
Explanation: Devender Sharma was convicted of a series of murders from 1994-2004 but there are no recent charges linking him to COVID-19.

Claim: False: In a video, the Chinese prime minister offers namaz (prayer) during the coronavirus scare.
Explanation: The 2015 Associated Press video shows the former Malaysian prime minister taking part in Friday prayers in Beijing’s Nan Xia Po Mosque during a five-day trip to China.

Claim: FALSE: A woman died in few seconds after taking COVID vaccine
Explanation: The woman who fainted after taking the jab is alive.

Claim: FALSE: Fenugreek seed tape is a COVID-19 Cure
Explanation: No it's not. Health experts refute this viral claim

Claim: False: All fruit and vegetable markets in the Indian city of Chennai and across the state of Tamil Nadu have been ordered to close in an effort to curb the spread of the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is false. Chennai’s municipal authority called the social media posts “fake” and Tamil Nadu chief minister said stores selling “essential items” such as groceries are allowed to operate as normal despite a nationwide lockdown.

Claim: False: Bill Gates wrote a letter that says coronavirus has a “spiritual purpose” and is “a great corrector”.
Explanation: The viral letter is a hoax and has been falsely attributed to Bill Gates.

Claim: False: An image with human body figurines in a bowl that claims China is serving human baby soup in its restaurants.
Explanation: The image is of an art installation to raise awareness about the rampant killing of sharks.

Claim: False: Coronavirus discovered In broiler chicken.
Explanation: Unrelated images of ailing chickens claim coronavirus has been discovered in broiler chicken.

Claim: False: Tabligi Jamat members in India are licking plates to spread COVID-19.
Explanation: This is an old and unrelated video. People shown in the video are of Dawoodi Bohra religion who do not waste food. That is why after eating, they lick all the utensils such as plates, spoons and bowls to ensure no food is wasted, and then they wash the vessels.

Claim: FALSE: Students hospitalised after receiving the COVID-19 vaccine
Explanation: A 2018 news clipping of students admitted to a hospital after receiving the measles- rubella vaccine shared as COVID-19 vaccination

Claim: misleading: A video of a group of men leaving a mosque has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter published in April 2020 alongside a claim it shows Muslims who gathered to pray in the Indian state of Gujarat in defiance of a nationwide COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: The claim is misleading; the video has circulated in reports about a mosque gathering in the Indian state of Maharashtra one day before India announced a national lockdown.

Claim: FALSE: A police personnel has been infected with coronavirus in Bihar’s Hajipur
Explanation: The video shows a mock drill on how to handle coronavirus patients, conducted by Jail officials.

Claim: FALSE: Popular Indian film actor John Abraham was caught violating lockdown while roaming in his Lamborghini.
Explanation: The images of John Abraham driving his Lamborghini date back from 2013.

Claim: False: According to a report by the WHO, coronavirus lives the longest in the cabbage layer. Elsewhere the virus lives for 9-12 hours, whereas in cabbage, this virus lives for more than 30 hours. People of all cities are requested not to eat cabbage.
Explanation: The WHO has not said cabbage is dangerous because the coronavirus can live longer on it than on any other surface.

Claim: FALSE: Video of a delivery boy spitting on the slices of bread by opening the packets in the truck and resealing them for sale to spread coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is six months old and is from the Philippines. In it, the delivery boy took bread slices for his personal use for the packets that were meant for disposal by the company.

Claim: False: Video of a man belonging to Tabligi Jamaat stripped naked and vandalizing the hospital where he’s put under quarantine.
Explanation: The video is old and not associated with Tabligi Jamaat or COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Home Ministry Orders To Close Schools, Colleges due to Covid
Explanation: The Ministry of Home Affairs has not ordered the closure of schools and colleges. A fake graphic plate in the name of Aaj Tak is going viral.

Claim: Misleading: The viral video claims to show the visuals of China police personnel trying to control the patients allegedly suffering from the pandemic.
Explanation: The viral video has nothing to do with the coronavirus outbreak and is related to police storming the metro in the wake of Hong Kong protests.

Claim: MISLEADING: Unmarried women, children, people with breathing issue should not take the vaccine.
Explanation: The claims made by the doctors were contrary to the the guidelines issued by the health ministry.

Claim: Mostly false: Dr. Charles Lieber, a Harvard professor, was arrested for creating coronavirus and selling it to China.
Explanation: Dr Charles Lieber was arrested by U.S. authorities for concealing Chinese funding. This arrest has no connection to the coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Vladimir Putin released 500+ lions on the streets of Russia to ensure that people stay indoors during the coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The picture of a lion roaming in the streets was taken in 2016 in South African city Johannesburg. The viral post with text about Russia was edited with a mobile app.

Claim: False: Video of whales spotted near Bombay High.
Explanation: The video is a part of a BBC documentary shot in Indonesia.

Claim: FALSE: Drinking pigeon membrane slurry can cure COVID-19.
Explanation: Drinking pigeon membrane slurry won’t cure coronavirus. The viral post is fake.

Claim: FALSE: Agarbatti Incense sticks can cure coronavirus
Explanation: Agarbatti (Incense Sticks) do not prevent coronavirus; the viral post is fake.

Claim: FALSE: Indian actor Aamir Khan is donating 15000 rupees to the poor by hiding them in aata in Mumbai.
Explanation: Aamir Khan took to Twitter to deny the claim that he was distributing money.

Claim: FALSE: Indian Prime minister Narendra Modi said 10 million COVID-19 patients have been treated for free in India.
Explanation: The news channel misquoted the Prime Minister Modi. He said that 10 million people have been benefited under India's Universal Health scheme over the past one-and-half year.

Claim: MISLEADING: This video shows workmen uncovering a bat-infested roof in the US state of Florida in 2011.
Explanation: A video shows bats nesting in the roof; however, the claim is misleading because it has been circulating the internet since July 2011 and actually shows repairs being made to the roof because of a bat-infested house in Miami

Claim: False: An image of a doctor goes viral with the claim that Dr. Usman Riyaz died while treating coronavirus patients in Delhi, India.
Explanation: The photo is of Dr. Riyaz Usman from Dubai. He is alive and healthy. He does not work in Delhi. He has put out a Facebook post dismissing rumors of his death. We also found that one Dr. Osman Riyaz has died in Pakistan due to COVID-19. We confirmed with the Delhi Health Department that no doctor has died due to coronavirus in Delhi.

Claim: FALSE: Kerala government is providing free quarantine service only to religious minorities.
Explanation: The claims are baseless and were made by using edited screenshots of Janam TV's broadcast. We have confirmed with government officials about the scheme who have refuted it. We contacted Janam TV, who informed us that their graphics have been used for fake propaganda and they haven't published any such news.

Claim: False: The Disaster Management Act 2005 is going to be implemented in India; no citizen is allowed to post any update or share any forward related to COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no such restriction on citizens to share any news or updates about the COVID-19 situation, as long as it is not false information.

Claim: PARTLY TRUE: Coronavirus is also spread through newspapers.
Explanation: When a person with COVID-19 disease touches the newspaper coronavirus can be on the newspaper for some time, but the risk of coronavirus infection due to newspapers is very low, according to the World Health Organization (WHO).

Claim: FALSE: The fifth phase of lockdown will be more harsh and strict in the state of Gujrat, India.
Explanation: Gujarat Chief Minister Vijay Rupani himself ruled out such messages as baseless and untrue.

Claim: FALSE: Image of a 93 year-old man recovered fom COVID-19 in Italy.
Explanation: This image actually shows the emotional moment of a war veteran who reads a long lost love letter.

Claim: FALSE: A claim that the novel coronavirus was never detected in the major Chinese cities of Beijing and Shanghai has been shared repeatedly on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.
Explanation: The claim is false; both Beijing and Shanghai, China’s two most populous cities, have reported confirmed COVID-19 cases and deaths since January 2020.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows that social distancing is not being followed in Delhi.
Explanation: The video is from Surat, Gujarat where social distancing norms during the lockdown were not followed and is not from Delhi.

Claim: False: The current coronavirus outbreak is due to the movement toward 5G.
Explanation: The 5G connection has no scientific evidence to the outbreak of coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Masks Can Be Sanitized In Microwave
Explanation: Fabric masks should not be sanitized by microwaving it for 2-3 minutes. Instead, they should be washed properly using soap and water. This viral post is fake.

Claim: FALSE: An image of people sleeping in a lobby is being shared with a claim that this image is from Gujarat where the lockdown is not being followed.
Explanation: After closely studying the claim that has gone viral on social media platforms, we found that the picture of workers sleeping in the lobby is being shared with misleading claims. Our investigation revealed that the old picture of Malaysia is being shared as Gujarat.

Claim: False: Avoid ice-creams, cold drinks, and sweets for 90 days to prevent coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence to support that the virus spreads through food items like ice creams and cold drinks.

Claim: FALSE: Viral video Suggesting Self-Check for COVID-19 By Holding Your Breath
Explanation: Viral video Suggesting Self-Check for COVID-19 By Holding Your Breath Is Fake.

Claim: False: A video shows bats, the main source of the coronavirus, on many roofs in Hubei district.
Explanation: The 8-year-old video from Miami, Florida, is not linked to the coronavirus.

Claim: False: “WORLD HEALTH ORGANISATION PROTOCOL & PROCEDURE OF LOCKDOWN PERIODS FOR CONTROLLING  ON MOST DANGEROUS VIRUS: STEP 1-1 DAY. STEP 2-21 DAYS. AFTER 5 DAYS. STEP 3-28 DAYS. AFTER 5 DAYS. STEP 4-15 DAYS.”
Explanation: Nowhere has the WHO spoken of the process of phased lockdown to fight the coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: A group of muslims pray together in roofs breaking the state of alarm in Spain.
Explanation: The image was taken in Kuwait, not Spain.

Claim: FALSE: Asia’s richest man Mukesh Ambani’s wife Nita Ambani received Rs.500 as welfare fund from Central Government.
Explanation: A tweet from a parody account of Nita Ambani claiming she received Rs.500 from the central government, was mistaken to be true.

Claim: False: Indian State of Gujarat’s government constructed hospital for COVID-19 patients with 2,200 beds in just 6 days.
Explanation: Gujarat government has set up 2,200 beds in 4 different hospitals in 4 cities as opposed to the claim. The Gujarat state government has not constructed one hospital with a capacity of 2,200 beds in 6 days.

Claim: False: Schedules for the sale of milk, newspapers, grocery and medical stores have been issued by the Mumbai Police commissioner.
Explanation: This is a hoax. The Mumbai Police commissioner has not issued any such order.

Claim: False: Chinese President Xi Jinping visited a mosque amid the coronavirus outbreak and asked the people of the Muslim community to pray about present crisis.
Explanation: Chinese President Xi Jinping’s visit to the mosque is not related to coronavirus. The video is nearly four years old.

Claim: False: Indian President Ramnath Kovind pouring gaumutra (cow urine) on globe to prevent coronavirus.
Explanation: The 2017 image is false.

Claim: FALSE: WHO report claims that ‘No vegetarian in the world was found to have been infected with COVID-19’.
Explanation: No such statement was made by any WHO representative or report. Also, WHO has advised people that they can consume meat products if they are cooked thoroughly and properly handled during food preparation.

Claim: FALSE: French Astrologer Nostradamus had predicted in 1551 that there would be an outbreak of coronavirus in China in 2020.
Explanation: No such prediction was ever made by Nostradamus. The prediction is being circulated only recently after the COVID-19 outbreak.

Claim: : India’s National Security Council, Prime Minister’s Office has released a list of restricted activities after the Coronavirus outbreak.
False: Image of a mother unable to feed her suckling as she battles COVID-19.
Explanation: The image is of a 35-year-old woman comforting her daughter at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center in Seattle, Washington.

Claim: Mostly false: Coronavirus-infected chicken has been found in Bengaluru, India.
Explanation: The image is outdated and not related to coronavirus.

Claim: False: Image of Indian police officer beating street children for not abiding the lockdown.
Explanation: The image is an old image from Bangladesh.

Claim: False: An audio clip suggests that the WHO has advised a lockdown.
Explanation: A source from the WHO confirmed that the organization has not put out any such information as heard on the viral audio clip.

Claim: False: India has decided to extend its financial year to July 1 due to the current COVID-19 outbreak.
Explanation: The Income Tax Department tweeted that the financial year has not been extended and that this gazette was for the collection of stamp duty on security market instruments through stock exchanges and clearing corporations.

Claim: FALSE: Johns Hopkins University published a list of precautionary measures against COVID-19.
Explanation: Johns Hopkins University took to social media to refuse that they had come up with any such lists

Claim: FALSE: UK’s Covid-19 vaccine trial volunteer Dr Elisa Granato is dead.
Explanation: Dr Elisa Granato, volunteer for COVID-19 vaccine is alive.

Claim: MISLEADING: Indian Prime Minister said world will be free from coronavirus in a month.
Explanation: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi told the people that with restraint and vigilance, there is 'hope' that the world will come out of the danger of coronavirus before Eid. PM Modi did not say anywhere that the world would be freed from Coronavius in a month. It became clear in our investigation that Dainik Jagran has published the news with a misleading title.

Claim: FALSE: A Twitter user shared an image of a map of India.The caption reads, “This is a map of India redesigned by an American CEO where he tried to explain that India is indirectly handling the COVID-19 situation of so many countries, owing to its large population”.
Explanation: Erik Solheim, who is a former Norwegian diplomat, posted this image in 2016. the tweet reads “India population now at 1250 million, Look at this map - India is not just another country - it’s enormous”.

Claim: FALSE: Industrialist Ratan Tata’s view on economic downfall due to COVID-19.
Explanation: The quote on economical downfall due to COVID-19 is falsely attributed to Ratan Tata.

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 Means ‘Certificate Of Identification Of Vaccination With Artificial Intelligence’
Explanation: No, COVID-19 Doesn’t Mean ‘Certificate Of Identification Of Vaccination With Artificial Intelligence’, Viral Post Is Fake

Claim: False: Images of money thrown on streets by helpless Italians.
Explanation: Old image from Venezuela shared with false context.

Claim: FALSE: Old Dalit woman beaten up by Christian missionaries in Kerala.
Explanation: The image is from Bangladesh and the woman had sustained injuries in a domestic fight.

Claim: FALSE: People living in quarantine centre refuse to eat food as it was cooked by lower caste women.
Explanation: The video doing rounds on social media claiming that persons seen in the video refused to eat food cooked by a lower caste woman at a quarantine center is misleading. The Bihar police have ruled out any casteist angle to the incident.

Claim: FALSE: Picture shows Bill Gates and White House health advisor Dr Anthony Fauci violating social distancing norms and not wearing masks.
Explanation: The picture was taken in December 2018 and has nothing to do with the coronavirus pandemic.

Claim: FALSE: Muslim men are being beaten during the lockdown in India.
Explanation: Madhya Pradesh worker beaten up by villagers; the men shown the post are not Muslim.

Claim: FALSE: Muslim women are misbehaving with doctors in India.
Explanation: The video is actually from Pakistan, and the location in the video is the Sukkur quarantine facility in the country.

Claim: FALSE: Kenya Government hired the warriors of Maasai tribe to enforce lockdown.
Explanation: The government of Kenya did not hire the warriors of Masai tribes to enforce lock down in the country.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows Muslim man spitting on bread to spread coronavirus.
Explanation: Video has been shot in the Philippines, in September 2019 and shows a deliveryman removing slices of bread meant for disposal.

Claim: FALSE: Dr Devi Shetty has recommended these 22 steps to avoid coronavirus.
Explanation: The message has been falsely attributed to Dr Devi Shetty.

Claim: FALSE: After testing negative for COVID-19, home minister Amit Shah went to a place of worship in Gujarat.
Explanation: There are no reports of Amit Shah visiting a temple in Gujarat after being tested negative for COVID-19. The image used in the viral claim is around 7 years old.

Claim: FALSE: The men of India’s railway minister demanding money from helpless workers for walking on the tracks.
Explanation: The video is originally from 2019 where a police officer was seen taking bribes from passengers and is not related to COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Video of recent Ram Navami Celebrations in Akbarpur block (Uttar Pradesh, India) despite the lockdown in the country due to COVID-19.
Explanation: The same video was posted by a Facebook page on 14 April 2019. So, the event in the video happened much before the coronavirus outbreak and the imposition of lockdown in the country.

Claim: False: A video has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter in April 2020 alongside a claim it shows the arrest of Indian activist Trupti Desai after she attempted to buy alcohol during a government-imposed lockdown triggered by the COVID-19 pandemic.
Explanation: The claim is false; this video has circulated in reports about Desai's arrest during a protest against the sale of alcohol in Maharashtra state in September 2019; the reports circulated months before the novel coronavirus was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

Claim: FALSE: Congress MP Dr. Shashi Tharoor praised LDF government in Kerala, India for their COVID-19 relief work.
Explanation: The statement being attributed to Dr. Tharoor, was never made by him.

Claim: FALSE: God has been quarantined due to coronavirus season as shown in the viral photo.
Explanation: An old picture of a religious event in Russia is viral with misleading claims linked to coronavirus. This picture has nothing related to the corona and is a much older picture than the first case of corona infection in the world.

Claim: FALSE: Viral video Suggesting Self-Check for COVID-19 By Holding Your Breath
Explanation: Viral video Suggesting Self-Check for COVID-19 By Holding Your Breath Is Fake.

Claim: FALSE: Two Indian politicians Rahul Gandhi and Priyanka Gandhi broke lockdown orders and went to meet their friends.
Explanation: The video is four months old when the two politicians were caught by police officials on their way to a city Meerut. They were going there to meet the families where deaths had occured in protests.

Claim: FALSE: Waris Pathan misbehaving with Maharashtra police (India) during lockdown.
Explanation: The old video of Waris Pathan is shared as recent, but it is not related to lockdown.

Claim: Misleading: Areas Of Lucknow Sealed To Check Outbreak Of New Covid Strain
Explanation: Vishvas News investigated and found the viral post to be misleading. Sant Vihar and Mansarovar areas that have been declared as COVID-19 containment zones and have been mentioned in the video are in Meerut, not Lucknow. ant Vihar and Mansarovar areas of Meerut have been sealed to check the outbreak of New Covid Strain.

Claim: False: Muslim People in China seeking refuge in Islam by reading Quran to save themselves from COVID-19.
Explanation: The video has existed since 2013, long before the outbreak of COVID-19.

Claim: False: COVID-19 Breeds Rapidly In Toilet Paper.
Explanation: The post is fake and is from an unauthentic website.

Claim: False: Janta curfew or nationwide for 14 hours will break the chain of coronavirus spread and see a reduction of 40% of cases.
Explanation: There is no scientific proof to the claim.

Claim: False: Turmeric And Lemon Help Fight Against coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no evidence proving this claim.

Claim: FALSE: PM Modi dressed “like a marriage reception” on his visit to a hospital recently despite the COVID-19 pandemic in the country.
Explanation: The posted photo is two years old. It was taken in 2017 when PM inaugurated Dickoya Glengairan Hospital in the central province of Sri Lanka.

Claim: False: People shouting “Allahu Akbar” in Europe after the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The video is not related to the COVID-19 outbreak in Europe. It was found on the internet since 1/13/20, and the first COVID-19 case in Europe was reported on 1/24/20. The video was taken in Germany, where the first COVID-19 case was reported on 1/28/20.

Claim: FALSE: Indian state of uttar Pradesh waives of electricity bills of its consumers amid COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: It is fake news, the UP government has not made any such announcement.

Claim: FALSE: Telangana celebrity, lyricist Suddala Ashok Teja died due to a coronavirus infection.
Explanation: Telangana celebrity, folk singer, poet and activist Mohammed Nissar was mistook for Suddala Ashok Teja.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows a group of Muslim devotees spitting deliberately to spread coronavirus.
Explanation: People in the video are performing a Sufi ritual called Zikr. It involves heavy breathing with a meditative chant. It has nothing to do it with coronavirus.

Claim: False: A video of a man committing suicide by jumping from a hotel in Italy after his entire family died because of the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video has been on the internet since December 2019. The first death due to COVID-19 was reported in January 2020. So there is no relation between the video and COVID-19. Also, the hotel in the video is in Spain.

Claim: False: Video of Muslims being trained to sneeze purposefully to spread coronavirus.
Explanation: It is an old video. While the first COVID-19 positive case in India was reported on 1/30/20 in Kerala, the video was found on the internet at least since 1/29/20 and is being shared as that from Pakistan. Also, the people in the video were not being trained to spread coronavirus. They are doing a type of Zikr, a Sufi ritual, which involves body movement and heavy breathing.

Claim: FALSE: Image of a Muslim boy, Rizwan, who had died after being beaten up by Tanda (UP) Police for violating the lockdown restrictions mandated due to COVID-19 spread.
Explanation: Ambedkarnagar district Police clarified that, in their investigation, they have found that Rizwan was not beaten by the Police. Also, the Police has said that, in the postmortem report, it was mentioned that the deceased had an infection in lungs & heart and injuries due to falling from a motorcycle, which was confirmed by a local doctor

Claim: Misleading: Indian businessman, WIPRO chairman and philanthropist Azim Prem donated 50,000 Crore to fight the COVID-19 outbreak in India.
Explanation: Several media outlets used an old statement by Azim Premji to back their claim that Premji has donated INR 50,000 crore to fight COVID-19 outbreak in India. The same media reports were amplified by several verified Twitter handles including journalists, media personalities and politicians.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows a large crowd in the marketplace at Muhammad Ali road, Mumbai violating current COVID-19 lockdown in India.
Explanation: The video is, in fact, from Pakistan. It is being falsely shared in the name of various cities in India.

Claim: FALSE: The chief minister of the state of Madhya Pradesh said that since the lockdown restrictions were not being adhered to effectively, all the houses will be locked from outside starting April 1, 2020.
Explanation: No such appeal has been circulated from the state's chief minister. The message is fake.

Claim: False: Recording of a conversation where one claims to be a friend of the WHO India Director’s brother, Saurabh, who gave him information that India will go into a complete lockdown mode from 4/15/20April to 6/15/20.
Explanation: WHO’s official in SEARO confirmed the viral audio on social media is "fake."

Claim: FALSE: This is a map of India redesigned by an American CEO where he marked the Indian states population which is almost equal to population of some of the countries. He tried to explain to his employees that India is indirectly handling COVID-19 situation of so many countries.
Explanation: While the map exists, it is old and has nothing to do with the current outbreak of coronavirus and PM Modi’s handling of the situation. It was made simply as a population comparison four years ago.

Claim: False: Photos show coronavirus is found in broiler chicken.
Explanation: The photos are outdated and have nothing to do with the coronavirus. They are about sick chickens.

Claim: FALSE: A Muslim man was caught spreading coronavirus, and beaten up. The man was caught spitting in fruits.
Explanation: It is true that the man beaten up in the video is a Muslim. He was beaten on suspicion that he is spreading coronavirus since he had returned from Tablighi Jamaat. There is no evidence that he was injecting fruits with his spit.

Claim: Misleading: Sanitizer manufacturer Dettol knew about the new coronavirus before it was reported.
Explanation: Dettol label mentions it kills coronavirus, but does not refer to the current strain. The products have not been tested for the new strain.

Claim: False: The Netflix Korean drama “My Secret Terrius” predicted the coronavirus outbreak in 2018.
Explanation: The show discusses coronavirus, a family of viruses causing flu like symptoms. The symptoms mentioned are very different from COVID-19 and the fatality rate is much higher.

Claim: FALSE: Consuming alcohol beverages or vodka will reduce risk of COVID-19 infection.
Explanation: Consuming alcohol beverages or vodka will not reduce the risk of COVID-19 infection. The viral post is fake.

Claim: FALSE: A migrant travelling home amidst the coronavirus lockdown was eating food thrown on railway tracks because the ruling party BJP had not made arrangments for the hungry migrants walking their way to their homes.
Explanation: The video of a man eating food thrown on railway tracks was uploaded on the internet in August 2019, and has no relation to the lockdown or migrants.
Originated from: Main opposition part Congress on its Facebook & Twitter handles.

Claim: FALSE: G-7 countries have asked Modi to lead them in preventing coronavirus.
Explanation: UK Prime Minister, US President and Australian Prime Minister have not asked Modi to lead the G-7 countries in preventing coronavirus disease as stated in the video.

Claim: FALSE: News and media outlet ABP Majha, on the basis of an internal memo of South Central Railway, reported that a special train has been announced to take the stranded migrant workers home.
Explanation: Indian Railways did not issue any circular that led to the gathering of stranded migrant workers in the state of Maharashtra but was just a proposal by the South Central Railway. Hence, it can be concluded that ABP Majha misrepresented the internal letter from the South Central Railway and reported the announcement of a special train for stranded migrant workers while Indian Railways did not make any such announcement but The New Indian Express journalist Sudhir Suryavanshi falsely accused the Indian Railways of issuing a circular regarding the announcement of a special train.

Claim: FALSE: This image shows a mother suffering from COVID-19 holding her baby.
Explanation: It's an old image from 1985. It was taken at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Centre in Washington.

Claim: FALSE: Images of gathering of BJP members in Madhya Pradesh on 23 March 2020 despite the existing lockdown in the State.
Explanation: The images show a gathering of BJP members at their party office in Bhopal (MP) on 20 March 2020. But the lock down was introduced in the State on 23 March 2020. So, the images are from an event prior to the introduction of lock down in the State.

Claim: FALSE: The image shows COVID-19 patients and the state of coronavirus isolation ward in Pakistan.
Explanation: The image showing two people lying on one bed is from Pakistan but is doing the rounds of internet since 2018 i.e. before the coronavirus outbreak.

Claim: FALSE: Television anchor Omkaar infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: TV anchor Omkaar is not infected with COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Migrants in isolation in India threw away food because it was cooked by a Dalit cook.
Explanation: The claim is false, the migrants in isolation wanted to be served properly in sitting position but the cook denied to follow social distancing.

Claim: FALSE: Coronavirus can be sexually transmitted.
Explanation: According to WHO, there is no evidence that COVID-19 is transmitted through semen or vaginal fluids. But it is too soon to know. However, it can be passed on through kissing and close contact.

Claim: False: President Donald Trump attending the recital of Quran verses to fight coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is from 2017, when Trump and his wife Melania attended the inaugural prayer service after taking the oath as the 45th president of the United States. Imam Mohammad Majid, executive director of the All Dulles Area Muslim Society, recited verses from the Quran.

Claim: False: Coronavirus patient arrested in Punjab
Explanation: This is a mock drill video from Mansa, Punjab.

Claim: False: Bombay High Court is extending Maharashtra’s lockdown to April 31.
Explanation: The High Court had only extended its interim orders and not the lockdown.

Claim: FALSE: A police officer in Bihar’s Hajipur (India) station contracted coronavirus.
Explanation: This is a mock drill video for training in emergency situation inside Hajipur prison.

Claim: FALSE: Fenugreek Seed Tape Is COVID-19 Cure
Explanation: No it's not. Health experts refute this viral claim

Claim: FALSE: Hindu man in Rajasthan killed by Muslims amidst lockdown.
Explanation: The video is originally from Pakistan where a man was maimed by his wife's relatives.

Claim: False: A website claiming that China has confirmed that patient zero had sex with a bat.
Explanation: World News Daily is a website generating fake news and it is scientifically seen that the virus has emerged from an animal source.

Claim: Misleading: Many media outlets, through unnamed sources, published reports that Indian Railways has announced a new set of rules and guidelines for traveling after the lockdown ends.
Explanation: Indian Railway has denied this stating that Ministry of Railways has not issued any protocol regarding passenger travel during post lockdown period, as has been incorrectly reported in some media reports. As and when a decision is taken, all stakeholders would be intimated. Please do not be guided by any misleading report.

Claim: FALSE: A post has been shared multiple times on Facebook, WhatsApp and Twitter by India-based users alongside a claim that the World Health Organization (WHO) has issued guidelines on COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: Both the WHO and Indian officials clarified that the "protocol" is fake.

Claim: False: Consuming onion and salt followed by a glass of water can cure coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence to prove that onion, salt and water can be used to cure COVID-19. There is no cure for coronavirus.

Claim: False: Police warn Whatsapp group admins regarding punishment on posting fake content, hate messages against religious and social groups.
Explanation: The government has clarified that the messages are fake.

Claim: False: A Chinese SWAT Team takes down a coronavirus suspect
Explanation: A mock drill video was shared as China committing atrocities on its patients.

Claim: False: 5,000 million Rupees fund allocated by Telangana CM KCR for coronavirus prevention is entirely funded by Central Government.
Explanation: The entire fund is not provided by the Central Government.

Claim: False: India asked for restriction of movement.
Explanation: The notification is from Malaysia and not India.

Claim: Fake: WHO issued proposal for extending lockdowns to control COVID-19.
Explanation: WHO issued proposal for extending lockdowns to control COVID-19.
Originated from: FB Page: श्री राधा विजयते नमः

Claim: FALSE: A sadhu in Jaipur was affected with coronavirus, as a result 300 sadhus and 700 citizens have been quarantined.
Explanation: PIB (Press Information Bureau) of Rajasthan has clarified by tweeting that it's a fake news. The tweet included a statement from Jaipur district collector who clarified that no such incident took place in Jaipur.

Claim: Misleading: An Indian politician claimed that the strain of coronavirus in India is a less virulent mutation.
Explanation: Experts and doctors have denied this claim and said that there is no such study which corroborates the information provided by the politician in his tweet.

Claim: FALSE: Japanese Nobel laureate Dr. Tasuku Honjo has said China manufactured coronavirus and he once worked at the Wuhan lab which later produced it.
Explanation: Dr. Honjo refuted the viral message as "false accusation" and "misinformation". He neither said China manufactured coronavirus nor did he work in any lab in Wuhan.

Claim: False: Saddam Hussein talked about coronavirus to his cabinet and army in the nineties. He said that America has threatened him to spread this virus if he doesn’t follow their command.
Explanation: The viral video is a doctored version of the original video shared by Associated Press in 2015. The audios of both the videos are different not only in terms of their content but voice as well. In the original AP video, Saddam Hussein does not mention the word ‘virus’ or ‘coronavirus.’

Claim: FALSE: Video of migrant labourers coming onto the streets in Ahmedabad, India due to lack of rations provided to then during the COVID-19 crisis and lockdown regulations.
Explanation: The video is not related to Ahmedabad. It was taken in Tolichowki (Hyderabad) when migrant workers stuck in Telangana, due to lockdown, have come onto the streets asking the State government to send them to their native places.

Claim: FALSE: A video of a young man from Gujarat claiming he has found a medicine that cures COVID-19.
Explanation: Gujarat Police has arrested the young man for misleading the public with a false claim about the medicine on COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows women queuing up outside a wine shop in the city of Pune, Maharashtra (India) amid COVID-19 Lockdown.
Explanation: The video is not from Maharashtra. The video is actually from Bengaluru, Karnataka.

Claim: False: Saddam Hussein predicted the coronavirus outbreak 40 years ago.
Explanation: The video is edited and was shot before the Iraq war. In the video Saddam Hussein can be seen discussing prospects of war with his military advisors and son Qusay. There's no mention of coronavirus in the actual video.

Claim: Mostly false: Viral post along with a pictures claims civilian thrashing a policeman during lockdown.
Explanation: The viral photos are three years old and have nothing to do with the coronavirus lockdown.

Claim: PARTLY TRUE: Image of police punishing people in Indian state of Assam for violating the curfew.
Explanation: While there are reports which suggest that the police is taking action against people in India for violating the orders, this picture is from Pakistan and not Assam.

Claim: FALSE: A text claiming COVID-19 can be transmitted by mosquitoes.
Explanation: No, COVID-19 cannot be transmitted by mosquitoes. Experts and WHO dismiss the viral claim.

Claim: FALSE: Queen Elizabeth thanked Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi for sending vaccines to UK
Explanation: Our research makes it clear that the image of Queen Elizabeth thanking PM Modi for the supply of COVID-19 vaccine doses to the United Kingdom is edited. A message by the Queen from early in the pandemic was edited to mislead users.

Claim: False: Photo of a vaccine developed by U.S. scientists for COVID-19.
Explanation: The photo shows a COVID-19 diagnostic test kit developed by Sugentech, a South Korean based company. It is not a vaccine. As of 3/23/20, there is no vaccine for COVID-19. Also, President Trump announced the FDA’s approval of a coronavirus test, not a vaccine, developed by the Roche company to increase and accelerate the country’s capacity to test for the virus.

Claim: FALSE: An article published by Madison Area Lyme Support Group lists a variety of claims related to COVID-19 claiming it’s “proof that the pandemic was planned and with purpose.”
Explanation: An article published by Madison Area Lyme Support Group lists a variety of false and misleading claims related to COVID-19 claiming its “proof that the pandemic was planned and with purpose.”

Claim: FALSE: Indian News wire agency IANS claims that Pakistani PM Imran Khan read an overturned graph and claimed that Pakistan was flattening its curve.
Explanation: The article that IANS picked up was a satire article from a Pakistani website called 'The Dependent'.

Claim: False: There is now a COVID-19 cure from the USA.
Explanation: It was a test kit from South Korea that was shared as an American-made vaccine for COVID-19.

Claim: False: A photo of people lying in the street is accompanied by a caption implying they are coronavirus victims in China.
Explanation: The photo taken in 2014 shows people lying down in a pedestrian zone in Frankfurt, Germany, as part of an art project remembering victims of the Katzbach concentration camp.

Claim: False: News graphic saying Indian prime minister has asked for the internet to be shut down in the country.
Explanation: The news graphic is photoshopped and fake. The prime minister did not make this statement.

Claim: Misleading: Coronavirus life span in a single place is 8 hours, and the Janata Curfew in India is for 14 hours. Thanks to 12 hours of Janata Curfew, the virus will be killed.
Explanation: Social distancing is important, but the viral post claiming a 14-hour break will kill COVID-19 Is misleading.

Claim: FALSE: Photo of Muslims offering prayers on the rooftops in India.
Explanation: The photo is not taken in India. The buildings in the photo are located in Dubai.

Claim: FALSE: Wearing a mask can cause a fungal infection.
Explanation: Wearing a mask doesn't cause fungal lung infection.

Claim: FALSE: Video of birds flocking together on Chandigarh’s Kalka Road, India, during the lockdown.
Explanation: The video shows birds flocking together at a river front in Ahmedabad (Gujarat). Also, it is of an incident prior to the announcement of nation wide lockdown which came into effect from 25 March 2020.

Claim: False: Video of police roughing up civilians claimed to be police in Spain enforcing a lockdown.
Explanation: The video is originally from Baku, Azerbaijan, from a protest in October 2019.

Claim: False: Banglore Municipal body (BBMP) will be spraying medicine in the air to kill coronavirus.
Explanation: The BBMP Commissioner, the mayor and PIB Fact Check India have clarified that the viral message is a rumor and the BBMP has no such plans to spray medicine for COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: High temperatures kill the novel Corona virus.
Explanation: High temperatures cannot kill coronavirus infection.

Claim: FALSE: China Seeks courts approval to kill 20000 people
Explanation: No, China didnt Seek courts approval to kill 20000 people. Fake post has resurfaced on social media.

Claim: FALSE: Single source’ Muslims are spreading coronavirus by leaving money strewn on the streets.
Explanation: The money had fallen off from the pocket of a man delivering cooking gas in the vicinity and was not planted by Muslims

Claim: FALSE: Dawood Ibrahim died of Covid-19.
Explanation: Dawood Ibrahim did not die due to COVID-19. His brother clarified the rumours.

Claim: MIsleading: Drinking hot lemon water kills coronavirus: PMCH
Explanation: No, drinking hot lemon water wont kill coronavirus, viral post is falsely attributed to PMCH

Claim: FALSE: Two Muslims boys were brutally beaten and forcefully fed alcohol by Hindu boys in India.
Explanation: The brawl started due to personal differences among the boys. No incident of foceful spitting inside the victim's mouth. He was not forcefed alcohol as well.

Claim: False: An image of a couple claimed to be doctors who have lost their lives to the coronavirus.
Explanation: The image is an AFP photo of a couple at the Barcelona airport after U.S. President Donald Trump announced that the U.S. was banning travel from the EU.

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 hospital flooded in Bihar
Explanation: Image of flooded hospital in Hyderbad is being shared as a COVID-19 centre in Bihar

Claim: FALSE: Americans singing Indian National Anthem thanking India for sending hydroxychloroquine tablets.
Explanation: This is an old and unrelated video where a YouTuber named Rickshawali paid tribute to Indian on Independence Day.

Claim: False: Photo of a vaccine developed by U.S. scientists for COVID-19.
Explanation: The photo shows a COVID-19 diagnostic test kit developed by Sugentech, a South Korean based company. It is not a vaccine. As of 23 March 2020, there is no vaccine for COVID-19. Also, Trump announced the FDA’s approval of a coronavirus test, not a vaccine, developed by Roche to increase and accelerate the country’s capacity to test for the virus.

Claim: FALSE: Elisa Granato (32-year-old), the first woman to get vaccine for COVID-19, died.
Explanation: Elisa Granato (32-year-old), the first woman to get vaccine for COVID-19 has not died. A BBC journalist tweeted saying that Elisa Granato is alive and healthy. Furthermore, in his tweet he has also included the video of Elisa Granato saying that she is alive.

Claim: FALSE: HOSPITALS ON LOCKDOWN AS FIRST COVID VACCINE PATIENTS START EATING OTHER PATIENTS
Explanation: The photo showing violence in hospital is old and unrelated to COVID vaccination. The viral post is fake.

Claim: False: Indian Home Minister Amit Shah claimed to be infected with COVID-19.
Explanation: The news graphic was created from a news generator and the news that the Home Minister has COVID-19 is not true.
