Claim: FALSE: According to Alibaba Group co-founder Jack Ma, 2020 is the year of staying alive and not a time to dream or plan.
Explanation: The Alibaba Group has officially denied that Jack Ma issued such a statement. There is no record of Ma saying something like that.

Claim: False: Australian researchers have found that bananas can help prevent infection of COVID-19.
Explanation: The post is false. There is no proof that bananas can boost one’s immune system and prevent the disease caused by coronavirus. At present there are no medicines to cure COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: A video shows Delhi police apprehending a COVID-19 patient who was fleeing.
Explanation: The video is, in fact, of a mock drill conducted in the city of Barabanki. It is being falsely shared as a real incident.

Claim: Partially false: The coronavirus is patented by Pirbright University.
Explanation: Coronaviruses are a group of similar looking viruses. The patent by Pirbright University is for the Avian Infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) which is found in fowls, pheasants and turkeys. This patent is not linked to the current 2019-novel coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Images show hands burnt after the use of hand sanitiser.
Explanation: The injuries seen are caused by the use of hazardous chemicals, not due to work in the kitchen after using hand sanitiser.

Claim: FALSE: TikTok has been completely banned in the United States.
Explanation: Several US security agencies have banned TikTok from government-issued mobile devices. However, there is not any blanket ban on it nationwide.

Claim: FALSE: The fire incident at Rohini flyover in Delhi, India is caused by hand sanitiser.
Explanation: Fire incident was not caused by hand sanitiser in the car.

Claim: FALSE: Video showing a Muslim man throwing notes to spread coronavirus
Explanation: Police have clarified that the man has dropped notes by mistake without any reason, this person has partial paralysis in the one hand. The Muslim man does not have coronavirus, the medical tests revealed.

Claim: FALSE: BJP leader shares fake ads of Japanese novelist saying COVID-19 is man-made
Explanation: The statement was falsely attributed to a Japanese scientist.

Claim: Misleading: Cattle vaccine is related to COVID-19, the current panic overblown by media.
Explanation: The viral post claims that the world has been using a coronavirus vaccine on cattle for years and the current panic about novel coronavirus (COVID-19) has been overblown by the media. When we investigated, we found that the vaccine being referred to is for cattle; it is not related to humans, and not to COVID-19. The viral post is misleading.

Claim: FALSE: Leopard is seen roaming in Delhi’s dwarka during the lockdown period.
Explanation: Video is not from Delhi, it is from Hyderabad where the lion was spotted.

Claim: FALSE: Nokia distributing free phones to students amidst coronavirus pandemic
Explanation: No, Nokia is not distributing free phones. This viral message is a scam.

Claim: False: Coronavirus has an effect on a person’s lips.
Explanation: The video shared a effect of coronavirus on a patient lip is found to be on the internet at least since November-2019, before the recent epidemic broke out. So, it is not related to the recent coronavirus epidemic.

Claim: False: Students from the USA sang the Indian National Anthem to thank the Indian government for providing hydroxychloroquine.
Explanation: This video is from 2017 created by a Youtuber and is not linked to coronavirus

Claim: False: It is predicted that using Turmeric can cure coronavirus in India in a newborn baby suffering from birth defects.
Explanation: The baby was suffering from Anencephaly and was stillborn with no connection to COVID-19.

Claim: False: A video shows a man spitting inside food packets during the coronavirus crisis.
Explanation: The video is old and out of context; the man in the video blew on the plastic bag to open it up..

Claim: False: Image of a herd of deer sitting on a street interpreted as different locations in Sri Lanka and India.
Explanation: Original image of the herd of deer on the streets is of an old incident in Nara, Japan.

Claim: FALSE: The video shows the dead bodies of patients of COVID-19 dumped into the sea.
Explanation: This is an old video from Libya. Due to a shipwreck, bodies of migrants have been washed ashore. It has nothing to do with coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Video of leopard roaming on road during lockdown is from Delhi, India.
Explanation: Video of leopard roaming on road is from Hyderabad, not Delhi.

Claim: Mostly false: Saint Luke’s Hospital of the USA says consuming alcohol can reduce the risk of COVID-19.
Explanation: Saint Luke's Hospital has not issued this advisory.

Claim: MISLEADING: Photo representing the suffering of a migrant worker during the current lockdown in India.
Explanation: While it is true that the migrant workers are facing a lot of problems due to the current lockdown in the country, the photo is not related to India. The photo is an old one. It shows Rohingya man walking into Bangladesh.

Claim: FALSE: Pune-based doctor Megha Vyas died of COVID-19 while treating patients infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: The woman in the viral photo is Megha Sharma who died due to pneumonia and not coronavirus. She was not a doctor.

Claim: FALSE: Home Ministry Orders To Close Schools, Colleges due to Covid
Explanation: The Ministry of Home Affairs has not ordered the closure of schools and colleges. A fake graphic plate in the name of Aaj Tak is going viral.

Claim: FALSE: Adding pepper to your food will cure coronavirus
Explanation: No, Adding pepper to your food wont cure coronavirus

Claim: False: Army deployed in Telangana, India, amid the COVID-19 outbreak.
Explanation: The post is fake and refuted by the Hyderabad Police Commissioner Anjani Kumar and Indian Army.

Claim: FALSE: A school in Delhi is selling Facemasks for 400 rupees to students
Explanation: The school refuted the claim that they are selling these masks and somebody used their logo as it is readily available online

Claim: Misleading: Social distancing is not being followed in Mumbai’s quarantine centers as quarantined patients are closely dancing with each other
Explanation: The video was shot in Tripura, in India, and not in the financial capital, Mumbai

Claim: FALSE: Old claim resurfaced that Bill Gates-funded Pirbright Institute patented coronavirus before the outbreak
Explanation: Old claim revived that the Pirbright institute's patent was Covid-19 virus which was false

Claim: FALSE: Muslim League flag hoisted on UN HQ.
Explanation: The flag of Guyana on UNHQ was mistaken as flag of Muslim League which led to the misunderstanding.

Claim: FALSE: Muslims without masks in the Paris Metro station are arrested by the France police
Explanation: This incident took place in Romania, not in France. Romanian police arrested a group of violent football team supporters on charges of assaulting the police personnel

Claim: FALSE: Muslim women were caught shopping in lockdown.
Explanation: After closely studying the claim that is going viral on social media, we found that this video is from Karachi, Pakistan. The building that shows men and women jumping from the balcony is a 2015 video. The viral video has nothing to do with the coronavirus or India.

Claim: FALSE: An officer on Special Day for the Government of Maharashtra is grieving about the current COVID-19 status in the state and that it is not being handled properly
Explanation: The man was a special officer for the previous government and is not a part of the current government

Claim: False: Cuba sent 200.000 doctors across the world to help nations fighting against the COVID-19 pandemic.
Explanation: According to the WHO and Cuban State Media, of nearly 400,000 Cuban healthcare professionals working in 164 countries, there are only 50,000 doctors. Cuban government made this achievement in the past 50 years, not in a single year.

Claim: Misleading: The white side of a surgical mask should be worn on the outside, with the colored side on the inside.
Explanation: The colored side of the surgical mask should be worn on the outside. N95 masks are better than normal surgical masks.

Claim: Misleading: Tencent claims that over 24,000 patients have died in China.
Explanation: Screenshots can be manipulated; the number is not confirmed by the government.

Claim: FALSE: Indian Government has a roadmap to ease lockdown restrictions in 5 weeks.
Explanation: The circulating message has been picked from Ireland's official government website and is being passed off as being from India.

Claim: Mostly false: Italian PM said that the country has surrendered to the COVID-19 pandemic
Explanation: The quote attributed to the Italian PM is fabricated.

Claim: FALSE: The video of terrible conditions of a COVID-19 ward is from Delhi’s hospital.
Explanation: The video of the terrible conditions of the COVID-19 ward is from Mumbai city's hospital.

Claim: FALSE: WHO said that the novel coronavirus is losing potency.
Explanation: World Health Organization (WHO) didn’t say coronavirus is losing potency. The viral post was attributed to World Health Organization (WHO) but is fake.

Claim: FALSE: Gujarat Police in India has called for civil volunteers in Surat for helping the local force in enforcing lockdown in the city.
Explanation: This is a fake message. Gujarat police have arrested three people for spreading this piece of disinformation.

Claim: FALSE: Dead bodies wrapped in these white cloths are those of the people who died of COVID-19 in Osmania Hospital, in the city of Hyderabad, India.
Explanation: The video showing dead bodies is from Osmania Hospital in Hyderabad, but it was recorded in 2013.

Claim: FALSE: An Indian news channel claimed that coronavirus pandemic would affect 1.6 billion laborers in India.
Explanation: The screenshot of the news is being taken out of context. The news report, in reality, was talking about the 1.6 billion laborers of the World, not just India.

Claim: FALSE: A hospital with 2200 beds was constructed in Gujarat, India, in just 6 days.
Explanation: A hospital with 2200 beds is not newly constructed in Gujarat for coronavirus patients. In four cities, government has arranged 2200 beds for coronavirus patients in hospitals that were already constructed

Claim: FALSE: Maharashtra and Delhi have not adequately spent centrally allotted PM CARES funds to create oxygen plants and are complaining about the lack of oxygen
Explanation: The PM Cares Fund did not allocate money directly to the states but started a committee that would look after the funds as well as the construction of the necessary oxygen facilities

Claim: FALSE: Muslims in Tamil Nadu, India are flouting lockdown rules to offer namaz prayers at night.
Explanation: A two-year old Namaaz picture from Uttar Pradesh has been falsely shared as related to COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Photo of Pakistani people holding a banner with the text – ‘We don’t want Kashmir. Give us Hydroxychloroquine’ asking India to help them handle the COVID-19
Explanation: The posted image is an edited one. In the original picture, the banner has the following text - 'We want Azadi'. It is an old photo and the photo was taken in Kashmir.

Claim: False: A video of an Indonesian traditional market is being used to depict Wuhan, China.
Explanation: A video shot in July 2019 in Indonesia is being used to falsely depict a market in Wuhan, China, where the coronavirus originated.

Claim: False: Gargling with bleach can cure coronavirus caused by eating Chinese food.
Explanation: Post claiming gargling with bleach can cure coronavirus is fake. Neither Chinese food causes coronavirus nor gargling with bleach can cure it.

Claim: False: Bus driver in China vomits blood after becoming unconscious behind the wheel.
Explanation: The video dates back to 2015 when a driver in Xiamen, China, was suffering from gastrointestinal bleeding.

Claim: MISLEADING: Germany sends China £130 billion bill for ‘coronavirus damages’.
Explanation: A German newspaper ‘Bild’ mocked up a bill and assessed the damage which the coronavirus pandemic has caused to the economy. However, the headline of Express UK is misleading to the effect that it insinuates that the German government has made the move.

Claim: FALSE: Multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter claim the World Health Organization (WHO) has warned against eating cabbage during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The claim is false; the WHO said it did not issue any such advisory against consuming cabbage; the US-based Centre of Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says there is "no evidence to support transmission of COVID-19 associated with food".

Claim: FALSE: Muslims are violating the lockdown in India by praying in the open.
Explanation: The video is from March 20, 2020, days before the lockdown was in place in India.

Claim: FALSE: Image of swollen feet of starving children who walked miles for food in Uttar Pradesh amid COVID-19 Lockdown.
Explanation: The image shows kids suffering from a rare skin disease in Pakistan.

Claim: Misleading: Bloomberg headline incorrectly claims that Malaysia has discovered a new strain of COVID-19
Explanation: The D614G variant was first found in Europe where one gene in the strain has mutated, it was not discovered in Malaysia

Claim: False: The Indian Army has been called to control seven areas in Mumbai that are not following the 21 day lockdown and are out of the Mumbai police’s control.
Explanation: The Mumbai police have not called in the army and the seven areas are following the lockdown prescribed by the government.

Claim: False: India announced holidays for four states.
Explanation: No such letter was issued by the government.

Claim: FALSE: As part of vaccine trials, Dr. V.K. Srinivasan of Bharath Biotech took the COVID-19 vaccine
Explanation: Image shows a blood drawing procedure, and is mistakenly characterized as vaccination.

Claim: MISLEADING: A family in Gujarat, India killed itself due to hunger and poverty during the COVID lockdown.
Explanation: The mother hanged herself after strangling her two daughters on 2 May in Gujarat’s Morbi on the suspicion that her husband was cheating on her.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) members paying respect to doctors in Aurangabad, Maharashtra, India.
Explanation: The video is, in fact, from Surat, Gujarat. It is being falsely shared with the wrong claim.

Claim: False: The viral text message claims that the chemical substances (methylxanthines) required to cure COVID-19 can be found in tea. Dr. Li Wenliang had found this cure while researching about coronavirus before his death.
Explanation: A veteran microbiologist in India, Dr. Sharad Kale, dismissed such reports saying, though methylxanthines are found in tea, there is no scientific evidence it cures coronavirus. He called it a hoax. The WHO also states there is no evidence that current medicine can prevent or cure the disease.

Claim: False: A claim that India’s Ministry of Home Affairs has made it a “punishable offense” for citizens to publish posts on social media about the novel coronavirus has been shared repeatedly on Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp.
Explanation: The claim is false. India’s official Press Information Bureau said it had made no such law. An online search for the purported government minister who issued the alleged ban yielded no results.

Claim: FALSE: Mustard oil can kill coronavirus.
Explanation: No, Mustard oil cannot cure coronavirus; however, it has certain health benefits. The viral post claiming that mustard oil can kill coronavirus is fake.

Claim: : A large Muslim crowd in the indian city of Haldwani stone pelted doctors when they tried to quarantine the Imam.
FALSE: Video of a Muslim man spitting into the food packages to spread coronavirus.
Explanation: It’s an old video. While the first coronavirus outbreak was reported in China in December 2019, the posted video has been shared on the internet since April 2019. Also, the video is not related to India.

Claim: Misleading: Russia announces the closure of airspace and suspends all incoming and outgoing flights to China.
Explanation: The Russian government had imposed a temporary and partial ban on the movement of Chinese nationals. All Russian airlines, with the exception of national airline Aeroflot, stopped flying to China on 1/31/20. Ikar airline will continue flights between Moscow and China. All planes arriving from China will be sent to a separate terminal in the Moscow Sheremetyevo airport. Aeroflot reduced the frequency of flights to Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangzhou until 2/29/20.

Claim: False: As per the news of Aajtak, Home Minister Amit Shah tested postive for COVID-19.
Explanation: Aajtak did not telecast such news.

Claim: False: To defeat the coronavirus, China built a thousand-bed hospital in 10 days, while India has prepared a modern hospital of 6,370 beds overnight, at a very low cost.
Explanation: A close study on the viral claim revealed that a 6,370-bed hospital has not been constructed overnight in the country. Isolation wards have been made in some bogies of the country's first medical train Jeevan Rekha, which was run in 1991.

Claim: FALSE: Drinking different types of tea can cure coronavirus, that were prescribed in Wuhan by Li Wenliang
Explanation: Li Wenliang didn't mention anything related to tea and cures of COVID-19 and the chemical composition of Tea being made of these various compounds aren't backed by scientific research.

Claim: FALSE: Video showing policemen picking banknotes with sticks, linking it with coronavirus.
Explanation: An LPG gas-cylinder delivery person had accidentally dropped the money. Police have clarified that there was no malicious intent of spreading coronavirus behind it.

Claim: FALSE: Covid 19 : ‘Achha Chalta Hu’ Boy breathed his hast after singing a Hindi song.
Explanation: The boy died battling aplastic anaemia. He tested negative for COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: A lab in Thane was closed for reporting false positive cases of COVID-19
Explanation: The lab was not closed, but did stop collecting samples in that period.

Claim: FALSE: Indian Covid-19 kit can eradicate Covid-19 in 48 hours
Explanation: Covid kits are only distributed in one Indian state and they are not a cause of national decline in cases

Claim: FALSE: Mumbai police issued a warning message about the possibility of an increase in crimes post lockdown.
Explanation: Mumbai police have clarified that the viral message is fake and they have not issued any such message.

Claim: False: Videos show pigs being buried in China due to the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The videos are old and not related to the recent coronavirus outbreak.

Claim: FALSE: Nebuliser can be used to improve the levels of blood oxygen level.
Explanation: Nebulizers cannot be used as an oxygen substitute. This can be dangerous. Nebulizers are used to deliver medicines to the lungs in minutes for patients suffering from respiratory desease like Asthama.

Claim: False: Viral video shows a man having great difficulty breathing. Even the medical team keeps a safe distance from this man. These videos are shared as a patient suffering from COVID-19.
Explanation: Upon investigation, we found out that all three clips are from Indian State of Gujrat. The man seen in the clips is mentally unstable. Health Authorities from the state confirmed that the man does not have a coronavirus infection.

Claim: FALSE: 48 COVID-19 positive patients from Jaamat found in Delhi’s Sultanpuri area, in India.
Explanation: The claim of 48 Jamaatis found positive for COVID-19 is false.

Claim: FALSE: An image shows groups of Muslims gather to pray on various rooftops, thus failing to comply with the social distancing ordered by the Spanish Government to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.
Explanation: The photograph was not taken in Spain during the confinement, but in Dubai.

Claim: FALSE: In Madhya Pradesh the tenure of Sarpanchs (Decision makers of the villages) has been extended by five years in the wake of the COVID-19 outbreak in the state.
Explanation: An official of the ‘General Administration Department’ of the Madhya Pradesh government who informed that no such press note has been issued by the government. The signature on the press note is forged and is intended to create rumour.

Claim: FALSE: A gathering of thousands of muslims before a masid in Bandra, Mumbai druring the current lockdown.
Explanation: The people in the video are migrant labourers from various religions who got struck in Mumbai due to the current lockdown. They congregated before a Masid that is present beside Bandra railway station asking to give them permission to go to their native place. Police said that those people have come to the railway station following some rumors that the trains will resume.

Claim: False: Coronavirus outbreak attributed to an advisory from India’s Health Ministry.
Explanation: The notification is falsely attributed to India's Health Ministry.

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 is a bacteria and not a virus according to a study by Italian doctors.
Explanation: The claims are baseless and were made by an unreliable Nigerian gossip website. The claims are medically inaccurate and misleading.

Claim: FALSE: Some 150 foreigners attended Sadhguru’s event in March, which has led to over 1,000 coronavirus cases in Tamil Nadu, India. The foreigners are quarantined at Isha Yoga Center.
Explanation: The last Sadhguru event was on February 21. No one at Isha Yoga Center has been found with COVID-19 symptoms or is quarantined there.

Claim: FALSE: Assam Minister claims that there are no COVID cases in Assam
Explanation: At the time of his statement, Assam had close to two thousand active COVID cases

Claim: False: A group of Muslim boys licking utensils to spread coronavirus.
Explanation: The people seen in the video are Dawoodi Bohras, who are licking the utensils in an attempt to follow their belief of zero wastage of food.

Claim: FALSE: Sanitiser bottles inside a parked car triggered fire due to heat wave in Bhopal.
Explanation: The video claimed sanitisers are dangerous to keep inside a car and attributed the cause of fire to its alcoholic content. Citing scientific studies, it was disproved since summer heat peaks at 160 F (71.11 C) but a car would need to reach an internal temperature above 300 degrees Celsius (572 degrees Fahrenheit) to cause hand sanitizer to combust.

Claim: False: People in Italy have thrown all of their money on the roads outside saying that this money is useless to save them from death.
Explanation: The images doing rounds on social media are not from Italy but from Venezuela when the country was facing economic collapse in 2018.

Claim: FALSE: Video of recent Ram Navami Celebrations in Akbarpur block (UP) despite the lockdown in the country to handle COVID-19 spread.
Explanation: The same video was posted by a Facebook page on 14 April 2019. So, the event in the video happened much before the coronavirus outbreak and the imposition of lockdown in the country.

Claim: False: The novel coronavirus can be cured by one bowl of freshly boiled garlic.
Explanation: The WHO has issued a clarification that garlic may have some antimicrobial properties but there is no evidence it can protect people from the novel coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: An image showing a vegetable market where vendors are properly following the social distancing is from India.
Explanation: The viral image is from Myanmar. It is not from India.

Claim: False: Photo taken by NASA on 4/5/20 when candles and diyas were lit at 9 p.m. for nine minutes.
Explanation: The photo in the post is not real; it's a 3D rendering. It was not taken by NASA. Also, the photo was present on the internet even before this incident.

Claim: FALSE: A 28-year-old doctor from Maharashtra, Dr. Maneesha Patil, died of COVID-19 while treating patients infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: The viral photo is of Dr. Richa Rajpoot from Kanpur, UP. Richa has confirmed that she is doing fine and she is not treating coronavirus patients.

Claim: FALSE: COVID-19 is transmitted from smoke released during cremation of victims
Explanation: COVID-19 cannot be transmitted from smoke released during cremation of victims

Claim: Misleading: People from the Muslim community have now started throwing infected notes on the road to spread coronavirus. This new method will make it even more difficult for the police to catch the spread of the virus.
Explanation: It is clear from our fact check that the video of police officials picking up the currency lying on the road claiming that the Muslim community has found another innovative idea to spread COVID-19 is misleading. There is no communal angle in the incident, which happened in Indore.

Claim: False: An audio clip suggests that the WHO has advised a lockdown.
Explanation: A source from the WHO confirmed that the organization has not put out any such information as heard on the viral audio clip.

Claim: False: A video shows man claiming to be of Tablighi Jamaat (a Muslim group) spitting on police when they were putting him into quarantine.
Explanation: The viral video is old and has nothing to with the recent coronavirus pandemic. The alleged man was not a member of Tablighi Jamaat. It was being shared out of context to create communal disharmony.

Claim: Misleading: Video of COVID-19 bodies lying in a morgue in India and being treated ruthlessly
Explanation: The video is from Russia and not India

Claim: False: The video shows Italians praying to get rid of the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is from Peru and was shot in December 2017 ahead of Peru parliamentary elections.

Claim: FALSE: MHA has declared Guwahati as ‘Red Zone.’
Explanation: The headline of the article is false as MHA has not declared Guwahati as Red Zone.

Claim: FALSE: India’s National Security Council, Prime Minister’s Office has released a list of restricted activities after the Coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The press release with the list of restrictions on activities is issued by the government of Malaysia, and not by the Indian government.

Claim: FALSE: Kerala (India) temple offers special Puja for curing COVID-19 and a rate card for the specific COVID-19 prayer (rituals) has been created by the temple.
Explanation: The image used to make the claim is a photoshopped rate list of rituals performed by the temple. We have found the original photo and also spoken to the temple authorities.

Claim: False: India’s Minister of State for AYUSH Shripad Naik held a press conference claiming that Prince Charles followed the rules of Ayurveda, which is why he is recovering so soon.
Explanation: Ella Lynch, a spokesperson for the Royal House of England, told The India Express via gmail that false claims were being made in the media about Prince Charles recovering from a coronavirus infection.

Claim: FALSE: Japanese Nobel laureate Tasuku Honjo declared that coronavirus is man-made and is created by China.
Explanation: Tasuku Honjo has made no statement about coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: There are no COVID-19 deaths in Israel as they found a cure for COVID-19 – a mixture of lemon and baking soda.
Explanation: As on 16 April 2020, Israel reported 126 deaths due to COVID-19. Also, there is no scientific evidence to suggest that the mixture of lemon and baking soda can kill SARS-CoV-2 virus. As of today, there is no mixture/medicine to prevent or cure COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Video showing coronavirus patient telling her ordeal shared with the claim that she is from India.
Explanation: The woman in the viral video is a British woman, Tara Jane Langston. She is not from India.

Claim: FALSE: Migrant family walking from Surat due to the lockdown committed suicide due to starvation.
Explanation: The incident is from 2018 in Wardha, Nagpur where a family committed suicide due to financial problems and is not linked to coronavirus

Claim: FALSE: A Rohingya Muslim was terrified thinking a doctor had placed a gun on his head when the doctor was actually doing a thermal scan using a machine.
Explanation: The video is part of a longer clip made by Kenyan comedian Hussein Yussuf a.k.a Wariah Bahali Yake, for COVID-19 awareness.

Claim: FALSE: Pfizer vaccine will cause sterilization in women
Explanation: We found no such mention in any studies published on the vaccine.

Claim: FALSE: A graphic of Zee News TV channels claims that the Home Ministry of India has hinted at a complete lockdown in the country after 15 June. Railway and airway will come to a halt.
Explanation: The grpahic is morphed. The Home Ministry has not hinted at a complete lockdown and TV channel Zee News has not show any such news.

Claim: FALSE: People in Kolkata, India, breaking lockdown and pelting stones on police.
Explanation: This is an old video from Gujarat. The video has nothing to do with coronavirus.

Claim: : If masks work, then let family back into hospitals and nursing homes to be with their loved ones. If they don’t work, get them off our children. Someone is lying…
False: Images of the medical facility shared with the claim that the Indian Army set up a 1,000-bed hospital in Rajasthan during the coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: Upon investigation, we found that all the images were old and two of them were not even from India. One is from the U.S. and another is from Germany. Even the Indian Army clarified on Twitter that such claims are baseless.

Claim: FALSE: Viral message shares the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) latest guidelines on COVID-19.
Explanation: The message has been falsely attributed to Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) and the institution has denied any association with the message.

Claim: FALSE: People in Jama Masjid market breaking Indian COVID-19 lockdown due to Eid.
Explanation: Video is from Pakistan and not from Delhi.

Claim: FALSE: To talk to India’s main opposition party (Congress) former president Rahul Gandhi, the Congress had hired people dressed as migrants who are facing trouble to travel to their homes amidst the coronavirus lockdown.
Explanation: India's opposition party's former president Rahul Gandhi had stepped out to talk to migrants who are facing trouble to travel to their homes amidst the coronavirus lockdown.

Claim: FALSE: Actress Deepika Padukone was seen buying alcohol during the lockdown in India.
Explanation: The video is of another actress Rakul Preet Singh who had stepped out to buy medicines.

Claim: Misleading: Coronil drops can help cure coronavirus.
Explanation: Leading homeopaths say little is known about the composition of this medicine and it is careless to recommend it for coronavirus

Claim: FALSE: Eating alkaline foods of pH level above 8.5 can kill the SARS-CoV-2 virus.
Explanation: The research paper published in 1991 talks about the MHV4 virus, not about the SARS-CoV-2 virus. Some of the pH levels given in the post are not correct. Also, there is no scientific evidence to prove that eating alkaline foods can kill the SARS-CoV-2 virus.

Claim: FALSE: Palm oil is a simple solution for coronavirus
Explanation: The post claiming palm oil is a simple solution for coronavirus is fake. There is no evidence to prove this. This has been falsely attributed to WHO.

Claim: False: Video of passengers infected with coronavirus on an Ethiopian Airlines flight from Italy that reached Addis Ababa airport.
Explanation: The video is of an ‘Emergency Exercise’ at Blaise Diagne International Airport (Senegal) in November 2019. So, the video is of a drill that was conducted a month earlier before the first coronavirus case was detected in China.

Claim: False: Runny nose and coughing sputum are not symptoms of COVID-19.
Explanation: In advisories issued by WHO, "runny nose" and "sputum production" are symptoms of COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Prince Charles recovered from COVID-19 with the help of Ayurvedic treatment.
Explanation: The spokesperson of Prince Charles denied this claim. He clarified that the Prince was treated by the NHS.

Claim: FALSE: Amid lockdown, Karnataka (India) chief minister Yeddyurappa attended the wedding of Kumaraswamy’s son, ignoring social distancing.
Explanation: The picture was taken two months back at the engagement ceremony of Kumaraswamy’s son. Yeddyurappa did not attend the wedding of HDK’s son on Friday.

Claim: FALSE: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has been selected as the leader of International COVID-19 task force.
Explanation: The news report has been misinterpreted and misrepresented with a false claim. There is no such task force has been set up.

Claim:
False: Whales are spotted at Bombay High, the offshore rig for the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation
in India. Nature is reclaiming its space.
Explanation: The viral video was uploaded by BBC News Indonesia in August 2019 on their Twitter handle. According to the caption, a group of humpback whales can be seen crossing the Karimunjawa Sea, which is an Indonesian archipelago in the Java Sea.

Claim: False: A video accompanying a claim shows bodies being removed from a hospital in Iran during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The claim is false. The video has circulated since August 2019 and depicts a funeral procession for pilgrims who died during the annual Islamic pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia's Grand Mosque.

Claim: False: CDC recommends that people shave their facial hair to prevent coronavirus.
Explanation: No such recommendations have been made by the CDC so far.

Claim: FALSE: Footage of a large crowd has been shared in multiple Facebook posts claiming to show migrant workers who were stopped at the Delhi-Uttar Pradesh state border during India’s nationwide COVID-19 lockdown in May 2020.
Explanation: However, the claim is false; the video has circulated online since at least October 2019 and is linked to local news reports about an Indian Army recruitment drive in Faizabad, Uttar Pradesh.

Claim: FALSE: A year ago, 14-year-old astrologer Abhigyan Anand had made a prediction about thecoronavirus.
Explanation: We listened to the said video which was uploaded on 22 august 2019 but the name of coronavirus was not mentioned anywhere in the 15 min long video.
Originated from: Many media outlets, Facebook, WhatsApp, Twitter

Claim: Misleading: Turmeric and lemon can cure the coronavirus.
Explanation: Medical practitioners and the WHO say this claim is false.

Claim: False: China is seeking court’s approval to kill 20,000 people positive with coronavirus
Explanation: There is no evidence for the claim that the Chinese court had ordered to kill the 20,000 patients affected with coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Indian Industrialist Ratan Tata says that the country’s economy will bounce back after coronavirus.
Explanation: The quote was falsely attributed to Ratan Tata. The industrialist took to Twitter and Instagram to clarify that he has “never said, nor written this.”

Claim: False: Italian president breaks down and surrenders because of the COVID-19 epidemic.
Explanation: An old image of Brazilian President Jair Messias Bolsonaro has been used to make the false claim.

Claim: FALSE: Kozhikode District Magistrate audio clip claiming steam, saltwater gargling and drinking herbal tea can cure/resist COVID-19.
Explanation: We spoke to the DM's PA and he said the message circulating in DM's name is fake and they have reported it to Kerala Police Cyber cell. Besides the remedies suggested in the audio clip are not scientifically proven to cure or resist COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: The danger of coronavirus is exaggerated. Look at the case of Mumbai slums.
Explanation: The number of new cases in Mumbai slums is growing. The situation is getting worse every day.

Claim: FALSE: A woman in Uttar Pradesh threw her five children into the river as they had no food to eat during the current lockdown.
Explanation: While it is true that a woman in Uttar Pradesh had thrown her five children into the river, it is not due to the unavailability of food. The Bhadohi Police has clarified that the woman took such a drastic step after she quarrelled with her husband, not because of hunger.

Claim: False: A video showing a playful deer on the beach is claimed to be from an Indian village during a lockdown.
Explanation: Our investigation revealed that the video is 5 years old and was made in France.

Claim: False: Pakistan’s Dr. Usama Riaz, who contracted coronavirus while treating patients, had left a video message before he died.
Explanation: The various social media posts claiming that the person in the video is Dr. Usama Riaz are misleading. The man in the recording is Mubhasir Ahmed, who has been living in the United Kingdom.

Claim: FALSE: The image shows the picture of the coronavirus-infected patient’s throat
Explanation: Fake post claiming to be a picture of the coronavirus-infected patient has resurfaced on social media.

Claim: FALSE: People are offering prayers in groups on rooftops despite lockdown. That too when cases of coronavirus in India are continuously increasing.
Explanation: The picture being shared is not of India but of Dubai. People in Arab countries have been called to follow the lockdown and offer prayers in their homes.

Claim: FALSE: Mass disinfection of people using a chemical solution will eradicate COVID-19 .
Explanation: Mass disinfection of people using chemical solution does not eradicate COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Men in Vellore, Tamil Nadu are violating lockdown by offering namaaz in a Mosque.
Explanation: This image is from Allahabad, Uttar Pradeshi which dates back to 2018 during the month of Ramadan.

Claim: FALSE: The Delhi Public School is selling face masks at Rs.400 and students have to buy these.
Explanation: The claim is fake. Delhi Public School said that they are not selling masks.

Claim: False: Turmeric And Lemon Help Fight Against coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no evidence proving this claim.

Claim: FALSE: Video of Muslim leader being accidentally shot dead during a celebratory firing after he recovered from COVID-19 in Pakistan.
Explanation: The video claimed to be from Pakistan is actually related to an incident in Jordan. In Amrawah town of Jordan, Sari Salem Wardat, a person who was set free from jail due to the measures taken by authorities over containing COVID-19 spread, has died in celebratory gunfire by his cousin.

Claim: FALSE: A photo has been shared repeatedly in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter which claims to show gift bags distributed to Muslims during the holy month of Ramadan by India’s Telangana state government during the coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The claim is false, this photo has circulated online since at least 2015; Telangana’s chief minister has announced it will not distribute Ramadan gifts this year due to the COVID-19 outbreak.

Claim: False: Janta curfew in India will help break the chain of transmission.
Explanation: The WHO has maintained that it is not certain how long the virus that causes COVID-19 survives on surfaces, but it seems to behave like other coronaviruses.

Claim: FALSE: US has developed miracle drug Remedesivir against COVID-19.
Explanation: Remedesivir is an antiviral drug which is being sold in the market for the last 10 years. It is being administered toCOVID-19patients on an experimental basis.

Claim: False: News about COVID-19 can only be shared after seeking the government’s permission.
Explanation: The Indian government had reached out to the Supreme Court that had turned down the government's appeal stating that media and news houses should be more focused and spread verified news about the virus.

Claim: Mostly false: Due to the fear of coronavirus, Muslims in China are offering Namaz in the open street.
Explanation: The viral video is four years old and has no relation to coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: As per ICMR study there’s been not a single case of COVID-19 among indigenous Assamese communities in India.
Explanation: ICMR has denied conducting such study as per the Indian Press Information Bureau.

Claim: False: No deaths have been reported in Israel due to COVID-19 because they have found a cure for the disease. A solution of hot water, baking soda and lemon is the cure for COVID-19.
Explanation: As of 3/31/20, there have been 15 deaths in Israel due to COVID-19. The solution of lemon, hot water and bicarbonate is not proven to cure COVID-19.

Claim: Misleading: Tata Digital Health is issuing a COVID-19 health kit that should be available in every household
Explanation: Tata digital health did not issue any notification regarding a COVID-19 kit.

Claim: False: A video showing a pile of corpses in Italy.
Explanation: The video in the post is not real. It was a movie clip from a 2007 mini-series called "Pandemic."

Claim: FALSE: Orangutan learns to wash hands during lockdown.
Explanation: Sandra, the orangutan has habit of cleaning things. The video was taken in 2019.

Claim: False: Photo of deer on Ooty-Coimbatore road during the current coronavirus lockdown.
Explanation: It is an old photo, on the internet at least since 2014. It was taken in Japan, not in India.

Claim: FALSE: A picture shows an eight-year-old boy infected with coronavirus. Prayers and shares on Facebook will help him.
Explanation: The viral picture has been circulating on the Internet for over one year. It has nothing to do with coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: In Italy, the cure for Coronavirus is finally found.
Explanation: Italy has not found the cure for the novel coronavirus. COVID-19 is caused by a virus, not bacteria. While the symptoms of COVID-19 can be treated with anticoagulants and anti-inflammatories, they are not a cure for the disease itself.

Claim: FALSE: CDC Recommends people shave their facial hair to prevent coronavirus.
Explanation: No, CDC Didn’t Issue Facial Hair Guide To Prevent Novel Coronavirus. Viral graphics is old and unrelated to COVID-19.

Claim: False: Videos of a patient gasping for breath is shown as a patient from India.
Explanation: The video is not from India but Ecuador where the person was suffering from acute respiratory distress syndrome.

Claim: False: Coronavirus will be cured within 2 hours by drinking bitter gourd juice.
Explanation: Neither the WHO nor the Indian Ministry of Health has mentioned any such remedy for coronavirus. The Press Information Bureau of India has also marked it fake.

Claim: FALSE: Internet sensation and the world’s cutest baby Anahita Hashemzadeh is suffering COVID-19.
Explanation: Anahita's mother has denied the rumors and informed that Anahita is healthy and she isnt the girl in the viral video.

Claim: False: Man critical with novel coronavirus in Barhalganj, India.
Explanation: There is no confirmed case of the novel coronavirus in Barhalganj, a town in Gorakhpur, Uttar Pradesh.The man did not get infected with coronavirus in Barhalganj by consuming chicken.

Claim: FALSE: Mustard oil can kill coronavirus.
Explanation: No, Mustard oil cannot cure coronavirus; however, it has certain health benefits. The viral post claiming that mustard oil can kill coronavirus is fake.

Claim: FALSE: Video of a Muslim leader being accidentally shot dead during a celebratory firing after he recovered from COVID-19 in Pakistan.
Explanation: The video claimed to be from Pakistan is actually related to an incident in Jordan. In Amrawah town of Jordan, Sari Salem Wardat, a person who was set free from jail due to the measures taken by authorities over containing COVID-19 spread, has died in celebratory gunfire by his cousin.

Claim:
False: Whales are spotted at Bombay High, the offshore rig for the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation
in India. Nature is reclaiming its space.
Explanation: The viral video was uploaded by BBC News Indonesia in August 2019 on their Twitter handle. According to the caption, a group of humpback whales can be seen crossing the Karimunjawa Sea, which is an Indonesian archipelago in the Java Sea.

Claim: FALSE: A woman infected with COVID-19 has been spitting and roaming inside a departmental store at Reliance Mall in Rani Bagh, Delhi.
Explanation: The woman in the video is mentally unstable and has been admitted to a mental asylum. She is not a positive COVID- 19 patient.

Claim: FALSE: Actress Hema Malini has been admitted to the hospital because she is having breathing problems.
Explanation: Hema Malini's photo from the hospital is not recent, but from 2015.

Claim: FALSE: Nostradamus predicted COVID-19 pandemic, Idukki dam collapse in July 2020 and other events in his book Les Propheties.
Explanation: No such prophecies regarding COVID-19 or Idukki dam have been made in the book.

Claim: FALSE: A photo of dozens of men praying on neighbouring rooftops has been shared hundreds of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim it shows Muslim worshippers in India praying together in defiance of the country’s COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: The claim is false; the photo in fact shows people praying in Dubai.

Claim: FALSE: A video shows a Superintendent of police announcing the extension of Lokckdown in Maharashtra, India till May 30.
Explanation: Police have clarified that the viral video is old and is being misinterpreted. The SP in the video was actually talking about the lockdown between 14-30 April.2020

Claim: FALSE: People come to your house, offer you to try a mask, which is in fact full of chemicals. This gets you asleep and these people rob you.
Explanation: It is an old rumor that spreads worldwide. A previous version of the rumor mentioned bottles of perfume instead of masks. We haven't found any actual situation in which this "technique" was used.
Factchecked on: 2020/04/30 France, United Kingdom, India, United States

Claim: FALSE: Image of Tabligi Jamaat members caught with arms.
Explanation: It is a unrelated four year old image from Gujarat and have no relation to the current nationwide lockdown to stop the spread of COVID-19.

Claim: Misleading: Turmeric and lemon can cure the coronavirus.
Explanation: Medical practitioners and the WHO say this claim is false.

Claim: False: Police in India lashed sticks at filmmaker Sudhir Mishra for not following the rules of lockdown.
Explanation: The viral video has been falsified based on the tweet made by Sudhir Mishra himself on the viral clip.

Claim: FALSE: This Is COVID 5G Chip Diagram.
Explanation: No, This Is Not COVID 5G Chip Diagram, Viral Post Is Fake. It is actually the electric circuit of a guitar pedal.

Claim: False: Streaming apps Netflix and Amazon Prime give free subscriptions during COVID-19 outbreak in India.
Explanation: They were phishing and spamming websites while the streaming apps have not declared any such free plans. A parody account portraying to be Indian news wire agency, ANI shared the sites stating free plans until April 31 while April has only 30 days.

Claim: False: Sri Lankan police made an announcement stating that citizens are not allowed to post any update or share any forward related to coronavirus and it being a punishable offense.
Explanation: These messages are not authentic. Sri Lanka Police Media spokesman and President Media confirmed these claims to be false.

Claim: FALSE: The COVID-19 pandemic was predicted in 1956
Explanation: Avoiding the plague was shot in 2020

Claim: FALSE: Industrialist Ratan Tata stated that 2020 is the year to survive and not to worry about profits and losses.
Explanation: This statement has been falsely attributed to Ratan Tata who took to Twitter to deny the claim itself.

Claim: FALSE: Arnab Goswami wets his pants when called upon by Mumbai Police for interrogation.
Explanation: The image used to make the claim is photoshopped.

Claim: False: New vaccine can help cure coronavirus in three hours.
Explanation: No vaccine has been found yet for the coronavirus. The image is that of a diagnosis kit and not a vaccine.

Claim: False: Football player Cristiano Ronaldo turned all his hotels into hospitals to help coronavirus patients and is paying doctors and the staff.
Explanation: A spokesperson for the hotel denied the claim stating, "We are a hotel. We are not going to be a hospital. It is a day like everyone else, we are and will remain a hotel." The news was also denied by HRT, Gol, Haber, Pogled, Flash and Hayat, while the Sport and Magazine plus portals deleted their articles.

Claim: FALSE: Muslims offering Namaz on road side during the lockdown in India.
Explanation: This is an old video showing Muslim people offering Namaz. It became viral recently with a false caption mentioning the lockdown.

Claim: False: The novel coronavirus can be cured by one bowl of freshly boiled garlic.
Explanation: The WHO has issued a clarification that garlic may have some antimicrobial properties, but there is no evidence that it can protect people from the novel coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: Lockdown in Telangana extended till 3 June 2020.
Explanation: No, the lockdown has not been extended till 3 June 2020 in Telangana. While CM KCR has expressed his wish to extend the lockdown and made an appeal to PM, no such extension has been announced. CM KCR himself has debunked the claim in his press conference.

Claim: False: A video shows a massive explosion in Wuhan, China, to control the spread of coronavirus.
Explanation: The video dates back to 2015 when there were giant explosions at the Chinese port of Tianjin. The video has no connection with coronavirus.

Claim: False: Central government has announced blanket holiday for schools/colleges in 4 states in India.
Explanation: The Ministry of Health issued a clarification on Twitter and called the viral “official memorandum” fake. Further, sources in the Health Ministry also confirmed to The Quint that the circular has not been issued by the ministry.

Claim: FALSE: Bihar’s Health Department has confirmed that poultry chicken is the source of coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no truth to the newspaper clipping. Firstly, the clipping itself is fake and has possibly been created using an online tool. Secondly, the Bihar Health Department has confirmed that no such observation has been made.

Claim: FALSE: A video has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times in posts on Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube that claim it shows a freight train carrying essential commodities for those in COVID-19 lockdown in India.
Explanation: This claim is false; the video has circulated online since at least November 2009 and actually shows a regular goods train service in India.

Claim: False: Photo of deer on Ooty-Coimbatore road during the current lockdown (COVID-19).
Explanation: It is an old photo, on the internet at least since 2014. It was taken in Japan, not in India.

Claim: MOSTLY FALSE: Coronavirus does not affect people with ‘O+’ blood type.
Explanation: The post claiming coronavirus does not affect people with ‘O+’ blood type is misleading.

Claim: False: Recently, Petrol companies reduced Rs. 6.40 on petrol and on Diesel Rs. 6.80.
Explanation: The petrol and diesel price have not reduced by Rs.6:40 and Rs.6.80 respectively. Petrol and diesel prices have come down by about Rs.2 in the last three weeks.

Claim: FALSE: A message on COVID-19 vaccine registrations for the elderly through the Covid Vaccine Intelligence Work app (Co-WIN) is being circulated on Whatsapp. It includes the steps that are involved in registering for the vaccine including PAN and SMS confirmation.
Explanation: The Whatsapp message which claims that the inoculation registration on the Co-WIN App will open in February for citizens aged above 50 is false.

Claim: False: In an Ethiopian Airlines flight from Italy to Addis Ababa airport this evening, most of the passengers are infected with the virus, and there is no strength except in God.
Explanation: The visuals actually pertain to a mock rescue drill that took place at Blaise Diagne Airport near the town of Diass, Senegal. The incident dates back to 28 November 2019 and was a simple simulation aimed at evaluating the capacity to respond to various crises that may arise during airport operations.

Claim: FALSE: Video of passengers complaining about the overcharged tickets and the lack of social distancing measures on an Air India flight run by the Indian government to bring back its citizens stranded in foreign countries during COVID-19 crisis.
Explanation: The incident in the video took place on the Karachi-Toronto flight of Pakistan International Airlines. The video was not shot in an AIr India flight.

Claim: False: President Xi Jinping visits Masjid to pray for coronavirus victims.
Explanation: The video is from 2016 and shows Xi Jinping visiting a mosque.

Claim: FALSE: Every Indian citizen to get Rs.5000 as COVID-19 relief by clicking on this link given in the viral Whatsapp message.
Explanation: The link is a fraudulent link that is being used to collect data of Whatsapp users. The same message is being spread in Kenya only by replacing the amount and currency.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows thousands of migrants gathered near Uttar Pradesh state Border violating social distancing.
Explanation: The video is old and unrelated to the current COVID-19 Lockdown, video dates back to October 2019 and is captured at a recruitment drive by the Territorial Army.

Claim: FALSE: Coronavirus dies in 26-27 degrees temperature, according to UNICEF.
Explanation: The message is falsely attributed to UNICEF. The fake post has resurfaced after a couple of months.

Claim: FALSE: Boris Johnson shopping in England in the time of coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is 7 years old and was taken when Boris Johnson was the Mayor of London.

Claim: FALSE: Telangana Chief Minister is being treated for COVID-19 infection in Yashoda Hospitals
Explanation: The video is from January when K. Chandrasekhar Rao was being treated for a different illness.

Claim: False: As per the video, Bollywood actor Aamir Khan donated 250 crore to fight aganist COVID-19.
Explanation: The video is six years old.

Claim: False: Israel has manufactured the coronavirus vaccine
Explanation: According to Israel, work at the Biological Institute will take time. Fifty of the most senior researchers and scientists are working hard to prepare a vaccine. The image circulated with the claim is a reference image, available on shutterstock.

Claim: FALSE: A ban on Chinese citizens going to markets in Australia.
Explanation: In a supermarket store called Big W in Australia, a dispute over the goods is being presented with a false claim.

Claim: False: Doctors and nurses in Italy are dying and are lying dead on the ground due to the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The image does not depict dead doctors and nurses in Italy. It is a part of a demonstration by youngsters to spread awareness about coronavirus in Bogota.

Claim: FALSE: Claim that government body suggested home isolation and quarantine schedule
Explanation: No such advisory given by the government body as claimed

Claim: False: 2,000 people died of COVID-19 on 3/15/20 in France.
Explanation: According to the WHO, 36 people died of COVID-19 in France on 3/15/20, note 2,000 people.

Claim: FALSE: A video clip of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi admitting that the Covid-19 pandemic is “a soldier of God” and admits that he erred in “assaulting” Muslims in his country.
Explanation: Misbar verified the authenticity of the video and found it to be part of a speech by Modi at the Sufi World Forum in March 2016 praising the Islamic religion, and he did not talk about COVID-19.

Claim: False: Video of police in China taking into custody suspected COVID-19 patients in the country.
Explanation: The video shows police in Hong Kong taking into custody demonstrators who were protesting against a controversial bill that would have allowed extraditions to mainland China.

Claim: False: Girl infected with coronavirus found dead in her apartment in Delhi.
Explanation: The incident in the post does not pertain to a coronavirus case in Delhi but is related to the death of a 22-year-old woman in Tamil Nadu’s Chettipedu.

Claim: False: In a video, the Chinese prime minister offers namaz (prayer) during the coronavirus scare.
Explanation: The 2015 Associated Press video shows the former Malaysian prime minister taking part in Friday prayers in Beijing’s Nan Xia Po Mosque during a five-day trip to China.

Claim: FALSE: More than 100 Nurses in Jhalawar (Rajasthan, India) resigned due to COVID-19 infected Jamaatis mistreating them.
Explanation: The Nurses in Jhalawar resigned due to less salaries paid to them

Claim: FALSE: Video shows migrant going to their home states from Maharashtra, India, throwing food packets on the railway platform.
Explanation: The video is not from Maharashtra. It is from West Bengal. Migrants threw food packets because it was stale.

Claim: False: Video of a man who committed suicide in the U.S. due to COVID-19
Explanation: It's an old video from Ghana and has nothing to do with COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Wearing mask face for long durations can cause lung cancer
Explanation: We found that the study, which was conducted between March 2013 and October 2018, did not involve mask-wearing.

Claim: FALSE: Migrant labourers stuck at the Delhi-Uttar Pradesh border as they try to return home.
Explanation: The video is actually from October 2019 that was taken at the time of a recruitment drive for the Territorial Army held in UP’s Faizabad.

Claim: Misleading: The Chinese prime minister visited a mosque to gain protection for coronavirus.
Explanation: The 2015 video is of the Malaysian Prime minister visiting a mosque in Beijing.

Claim: FALSE: A Covid positive temple priest in the city of Jaipur spread coronavirus to 300 people when he smoked his pipe.
Explanation: No such incident has occured in the city of Jaipur.

Claim: FALSE: Mumbai and Pune is going under military lockdown
Explanation: Post claiming Mumbai and Pune is not going under military lockdown is fake.

Claim: False: Video claiming that it was Vladmir Putin’s daughter receiving a shot of the Russian COVID-19 vaccine.
Explanation: The girl in the video is not Putin's daughter.

Claim: FALSE: Video of migrants in a overcrowded train from Mumbai to West Bengal on 10 May 2020 amid COVID-19 social distancing restrictictions.
Explanation: This video is unrelated and dates back to 2018 from bangladesh, this video was of people travelling to an annual religious gatering called Biswa Ijtema.

Claim: False: The WHO advises against consuming bakery products.
Explanation: The WHO has not issued notification against the consumption of bakery products. The viral post is fake.

Claim: FALSE: In the United Kingdom, the woman who was tried for the coronavrus vaccine has died.
Explanation: Vaccine trials have taken place in the United Kingdom, but the woman who has been tried is alive, not dead.

Claim: FALSE: Inhaling hot water steam can kill coronavirus.
Explanation: While hot water steam inhalation may provide some temporary relief for the symptoms in some cases like common cold and flu, there is no scientific evidence to suggest that it can kill coronavirus. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) has also clarified the same.

Claim: FALSE: Fox News Report on US President Trump testing positive for COVID-19.
Explanation: The Original Fox News Report states that US President Trump's valet has been tested positive for COVID-19. The video is digitally tampered.

Claim: FALSE: A video is doing the rounds on social media which claims that policemen are now being tested positive for the COVID-19.
Explanation: The video is from Bihar's Hajipur jail. An official informed that mock drills are being practiced in almost every jail in Bihar to check the preparations for the fight against the COVID-19. Some social media users are sharing the video of mock drill with the claim that a cop was tested positive for the COVID-19, this is completely false.

Claim: False: Man is spitting on a police officer to spread COVID-19 in India.
Explanation: An older video of an under trial spitting on a cop as he was denied home cooked food was falsely shared as being related to COVID-19.

Claim: FALSE: Indian economist Raghuram Rajan  commented in a webinar for the IMF on India’s situation regarding COVID-19
Explanation: The IMF or Rajan did not hold any such webinar while Rajan refuted these news through his linkedin.

Claim: FALSE: First volunteer for COVID-19 Vaccine in UK, Dr. Elisa Granato, is dead.
Explanation: Dr. Elisa Granato is alive and healthy and gave interviews to debunk the rumor.

Claim: False: Narendra Modi is giving free masks in India.
Explanation: A fake phishing website was set up in the name of Narendra Modi.

Claim: FALSE: Roti with stamp distributed during lockdown in India.
Explanation: These rotis were distributed during 2014's election in Uttar Pradesh state, India

Claim: FALSE: Italy is burying Corona victims in mass graves.
Explanation: The video is a part of Pandemic, a 2016 American science fiction thriller film.

Claim: FALSE: Muslims are hoarding food items being shared by the Indian government.
Explanation: The video is originally from a leprosy clinic where the clinic was storing food to be distributed on April 10.

Claim: Misleading: Men are twice as likely to die from COVID-19 as women.
Explanation: The report overgeneralizes published figures.

Claim: False: A new vaccine to cure coronavirus has been developed by U.S. scientists.
Explanation: The image in the viral post is not a coronavirus vaccine. It is a COVID-19 test kit.

Claim: False: Hot air from hair dryers can kill the coronavirus.
Explanation: Blowing hot air from a hair dryer is not a cure nor a preventive measure against coronavirus. There is no cure for coronavirus as of now.

Claim: FALSE: Video showing dead bodies of coronavirus patients in Osmania Hospital’s mortuary.
Explanation: Old video of Osmania hospital mortuary is shared as being recent.

Claim: False: The bodies of people infected with coronavirus are lying on the road of Italy. No one is carrying them due to the risk of infection.
Explanation: The image is from Germany, where people lied down in a pedestrian zone as part of an art project in remembrance of 528 victims of the Katzbach Nazi concentration camp in Frankfurt.

Claim: FALSE: An image shows a woman in Italy clutching her 18-month-old child tightly to her chest before dying of coronavirus.
Explanation: The photograph was captured before stem cell transplant at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center, Seattle, USA in 1985 by Burt Glinn.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows lockdown and social distancing violation outside a liquor shop in Delhi.
Explanation: This video is an old and unrelated video, the liquor shop shown in the video is closed currently due to the COVID-19 lockdown

Claim: False: Pigs are being burned alive in China to control the coronavirus.
Explanation: A year-old viral video is not about the coronavirus in China.

Claim: FALSE: Workers who worked from 1990 to 2020 have the right to receive the Corona relief of INR120,000 from Ministry of Labour and Employment.
Explanation: The Indian Government's Press Information Bureau's denied such a claim. A similar claim came from South Africa.

Claim: FALSE: Coronavirus dies in 26-27 degrees temperature, according to UNICEF.
Explanation: The message is falsely attributed to UNICEF. The fake post has resurfaced after a couple of months.

Claim: FALSE: Video of a burqa-clad Muslim woman being denied a food kit distributed to help people during the current crisis in India due to COVID-19, for being a Muslim.
Explanation: The woman in the video was not denied a food kit. Rajeev Mishra (the man distributing food rations in the video) has sent another video and photos to FACTLY, where it can be seen that the woman was given the food kit.

Claim: FALSE: Coronavirus can be avoided by eating nigella with honey as it contains 100% hydroxychloroquine. Hydroxychloroquine treats coronavirus.
Explanation: Hydroxychloroquine is not present in the substances found in nigella, but it contains thymoquinone. Hydroxychloroquine is also not yet proven as a cure coronavirus though many countries giving HCQ to COVID-19 patients.

Claim: FALSE: A Rohingya Muslim believes that the thermal scanner for testing COVID-19 is a gun that is being pulled at him.
Explanation: The video was made by a Kenyan comedian.

Claim: Misleading: People of the Muslim community have prohibited visiting Mecca Medina to avoid the outbreak of coronavirus, but people of Sanatan religion are playing Holi at the crematorium of Kashi Vishwanath as a pyre.
Explanation: Mecca Medina of Saudi Arabia was not closed due to fear of coronavirus. There was a ban on the arrival of travelers from several countries. On 3/5/20 people were prevented from going inside because of sanitization.

Claim: FALSE: Huge crowd on the streets of Delhi during Ramzan while there was no crowd during the festival of Navratri.
Explanation: One of the photographs which was used to claim that the streets in Delhi were empty during Navratri was actually from Jammu.

Claim: False: Video shows bats found under the tiles of many roofs in Hubei, China. They were the source of the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was not taken in China. It’s a video from 7/5/11 by a Miami based roofing company, Istueta Roofing. The bats in the video were found under the tiles during the process of replacing a roof for a customer in Miami.

Claim: False: Actor Vijay’s father criticized government for enforcing a curfew to abate COVID-19.
Explanation: The newscard shared to make the claim is fake. The news channel has not published any such news.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows Muslim women spitting in plastic bags and throwing them into the houses to spread coronavirus.
Explanation: When FACTLY contacted Gaurav Yadav (Superintendent of Police, Kota City), he clarified that the women in the video are not Muslims. He said that they belong to Hindu Bawari caste and they are not trying to spread coronavirus.

Claim: FALSE: A message asking people to not get out of their homes tonight from 10pm to next day 5am because the government has made arrangements to spray medicine in the air in order to kill the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The government is not spraying any medicine to kill the novel coronavirus. The message is fake.

Claim: False: Doctored image of President Donald Trump shared claiming he asked people to chant Hare Krishna Hare Rama.
Explanation: The claim is fake and the image is doctored.

Claim: FALSE: People in India are forbidden to share or give news updates about COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no rule prohibiting citizens from sharing any news or updates about the pandemic is passed in India.

Claim: FALSE: A police officer in Bihar’s Bhagalpur Central Jail has tested positive for coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is of a mock drill that was conducted at Bhagalpur Central Jail in Bihar nearly 8-10 days ago. The video in circulation falsely claims that it shows an officer who has tested positive for COVID-19.

Claim: False: News channel graphic stating that the Indian lockdown is to be extended to May 4.
Explanation: The news bulletin was Photoshopped.

Claim: FALSE: Video showing people flouting lockdown rules in West Bengal, India.
Explanation: The video is an old one and is not related to the current lockdown. The same video was found to be on the internet at least since April 2019.

Claim: False: Posting anything on coronavirus will be a punishable offense because the Disaster Management Act has been implemented.
Explanation: As per the Disaster Management Act, there is no provision that mentions that apart from government departments, no other citizen can be allowed to talk, update or share any news related to a disaster.

Claim: False: Russian government has unleashed lions on the streets to impose a public curfew.
Explanation: The viral bulletin is digitally edited and the lion in the image was a part of a movie shoot from South Africa.

Claim: FALSE: By drinking Ayurvedic decoction, 6 thousand corona infected patients were cured.
Explanation: The decoction was given to those who were in the Quarantine Center after coming in contact with coronavirus positive people. It has been told by the Ministry of Ayush that this decoction increases your immunity and not kills the coronavirus.

Claim: False: Coronavirus case in Uttar Pradesh district, India.
Explanation: Authorities deny there is a case.

Claim: FALSE: World Health Organization (WHO) has advised people against eating bakery items amid COVID-19 outbreak.
Explanation: WHO Sri Lanka' has debunked the claim and clarified that WHO hasn't advised people against eating bakery items. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) has also debunked the claim and clarified the same.

Claim: False: Riots in London due to the unavailability of food items. The United Kingdom will be locked down by tonight. Army soldiers take to the UK streets.
Explanation: This video is of riots that happened in Peckham, London. With a Google search, we found several global media reports on the London riots. It was clear from these reports that the video viral on social media shows the 2011 London riots.

Claim: FALSE: Video shows migrants looting food packets at Hyderabad Railway station, in India.
Explanation: The video is, in fact, from Delhi. The incident took place at the old Delhi station, not in Hyderabad.

Claim: FALSE: A post shows a list of people who have donated plasma to help fight COVID-19.
Explanation: Old list of blood donors from different regions of India shared as Plasma donors list

Claim: False: China is planning to kill coronavirus patients.
Explanation: There is no information to prove that China plans to kill over 20,000 patients who have been infected by the coronavirus.

Claim: False: Finally India got its coronavirus Dashboard. This is the official website for coronavirus updates. This website is updated every four hours. Scroll down for more details; you can know more about coronavirus outbreak in your state by placing your finger on your state on the map.
Explanation: The website is not official and the tweet by a Bollywood superstar is misleading.

Claim: False: A video shows police killing COVID-19 affected people in China.
Explanation: The video was edited with three unrelated clips. Yiwu Police have clarified that the armed police in the video were on duty to kill a rabid dog. The last clip is related to an accident.

Claim: False: Tamil Nadu Govt ordered to re-open TASMAC bars.
Explanation: A fake screenshot has been used to make the claim.

Claim: FALSE: Police catches coronavirus positive patient on the road.
Explanation: Mockdrill video in Uttar Pradesh viral in the name of coronavirus.

Claim: False: A video of a girl collapsing in a store because she was affected by coronavirus.
Explanation: The incident took place in Malaysia and the girl has been identified as Nur Izzah Izzati. Malaysia’s Health Ministry also confirmed that the claim attached to the video is fake.

Claim: False: Manir Hossain, a 23-year-old man from India’s Tripura, died in a hospital in Malaysia due to the new coronavirus.
Explanation: Upon our investigation, we this to be false. An Indian citizen from Tripura did not die due to the new coronavirus in Malaysia. The reason for his death was Status Epilepticus Secondary Meningoencephalitis.

Claim: FALSE: A video of young adults singing the Indian national anthem has been shared on Facebook and Twitter during the COVID-19 pandemic alongside claims that it shows American students performing to thank India for supplying the US with hydroxychloroquine, a malaria drug that has been involved in clinical trials for potential COVID-19 treatment.
Explanation: The claim is false; this rendition of the Indian national anthem was produced in August 2017 to mark India’s 71st Independence Day.

Claim: FALSE: Video of foreigners destroying liquor bottles amid COVID-19 lockdown in India.
Explanation: The video is true, but it is an old video from Pakistan and has no connection with COVID-19.

Claim: False: The WHO has issued an alert against buying holy colors from China
Explanation: The WHO hasn't issued an advisory against buying Holi colors from coronavirus-hit China.

Claim: FALSE: Video of a police member in an inebriated state after the Indian government has allowed the opening of liquor shops which were closed earlier due to complete lockdown in the country.
Explanation: The video is of an incident in 2017. It shows Faizabad Police (Uttar Pradesh) taking a drunk police constable with them after receiving information about him from the public.

Claim: False: China seeks court’s approval to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients.
Explanation: The claim is fake.

Claim: FALSE: Image of Muslim people offering prayer on the rooftops is claimed to be from India.
Explanation: Using Google Earth and Google Maps, it has been successfully proved that the image is from Dubai.

Claim: : Indian ministry of Tourism orders closure of hotels, restaurants and resorts till Ocrober 15, 2020.
FALSE: Delhi police released this coronavirus guideline.
Explanation: The viral guideline document is falsely attributed to Delhi police.

Claim: MISLEADING: Masks should only be used by healthcare workers, caretakers, or by people who are sick with symptoms like cough and fever: WHO
Explanation: Outdated Screenshot On Usage Of Masks By WHO Shared As Recent, Viral Post Is Misleading

Claim: FALSE: People living in quarantine centre refuse to eat food as it was cooked by lower caste women.
Explanation: The video doing rounds on social media claiming that persons seen in the video refused to eat food cooked by a lower caste woman at a quarantine center is misleading. The Bihar police have ruled out any casteist angle to the incident.

Claim: False: Coronavirus can be cured by sniffing clove and camphor and by drinking water, the virus will go to the stomach and the acid in the stomach will kill the virus.
Explanation: Dr. Mohammad Imran, an Ayurveda doctor, said, “It is merely a rumor which has gone viral on social media .There is no scientific evidence which backs the claim that sniffing clove and camphor can cure coronavirus. However, natural camphor and clove does have certain health benefits as it can cure fungus and bacteria”.

Claim: FALSE: Indian company Jio offering 25GB of free data daily during the COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: The message claiming Jio offering free 25GB data daily during COVID-19 lockdown is fake. No, Jio and Facebook have not rolled out any such offer for Jio users.

Claim: False: Cocaine cures COVID-19.
Explanation: The claim is false. There is no vaccine or medical treatment available for COVID-19. Cocaine is a stimulant and an addictive drug.

Claim: FALSE: Interview of HDFC Bank Managing Director Aditya Puri about why india will survive COVID-19 and make it big
Explanation: Neeraj Jha, Spokesman for HDFC Bank, dismissed the bulk of the points in the post as being wrongly attributed to Aditya Puri.

Claim: FALSE: The image shows a daughter crying for her coronavirus infected mother who struggling for her life.
Explanation: They are NOT mother-daughter. The image of a woman in a medically-induced coma was taken in 2015. It has nothing to do with COVID-19. The picture of a crying girl is a stock image uploaded in 2018.

Claim: False: Bollywood superstar Aamir Khan donated Rs. 250 crore to tackle the novel coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The image on social media claiming that Bollywood star Aamir Khan has donated Rs 250 crore to fight the novel coronavirus is misleading as the actor has not donated anything yet. British boxer Amir Khan has offered his retail outlet to the NHS to help COVID-19 patients.

Claim: FALSE: A Twitter user shared an image of a map of India.The caption reads, “This is a map of India redesigned by an American CEO where he tried to explain that India is indirectly handling the COVID-19 situation of so many countries, owing to its large population”.
Explanation: Erik Solheim, who is a former Norwegian diplomat, posted this image in 2016. the tweet reads “India population now at 1250 million, Look at this map - India is not just another country - it’s enormous”.

Claim: False: Image of the people who died of coronavirus in Italy.
Explanation: The photo is not related to recent coronavirus deaths in Italy. It was taken in Frankfurt (Germany) in 2014 as part of an art project in remembrance of 528 Katzbach victims of the Nazi concentration camp.

Claim: FALSE: Image of news channel claims Pakistan’s PM Imran Khan’s wife tested COVID-19 positive.
Explanation: This is a doctored image created on online graphic generator.

Claim: FALSE: A vaccine for coronavirus was available since 2001.
Explanation: This is a dog vaccine wrongly claimed as being a vaccine for COVID-19.

Claim: Misleading: Muslim youth is spreading COVID-19 by licking plates in Nizamuddin Markaz in India.
Explanation: The video is 2 years old and the people in it belong to Dawoodi Bohra society. In their tradition, dishes are washed only after eating and licking the utensils. This is done so that no food grains are wasted.

Claim: FALSE: WHO did not say that COVID-19 virus has become deadly and will kill anyone in 3 days
Explanation: The two recent pan India studies conducted by ICMR and D/O Biotechnology suggest that the virus is genetically stable and there is no major mutation in the virus

Claim: FALSE: Government on India’s plan for exiting the lockdown in five phases.
Explanation: The government hasn't released any such plan yet. Secondly, we found that the plan doing the rounds on social media was very similar to that of government of Ireland.

Claim: FALSE: A doctor from Kasturba Hospital suggested to not wear masks all the time because otherwise, it could cause death.
Explanation: The hospital clarified that no such message has been released by any doctor of Kasturba Hospital. Expert of Indian Medical Association denied that the claims regarding the use of masks.

Claim: False: Videos showing police detaining COVID-19 patients in India.
Explanation: These were mock drills conducted by the UP Police to determine the preparedness of the public with regards to COVID-19.

Claim: False: Hold your breath for 10 seconds to check if you have the coronavirus.
Explanation: Most young COVID-19 patients will be able to hold their breath for much longer than 10 seconds, while many elderly without the virus won't be able to do it.

Claim: FALSE: Central indian government likely to reduce the age of retirement of government employees to 50.
Explanation: Government has clarified they are neither making any such move nor even discussing it.

Claim: False: A police commissioner from Mumbai has asked essential services to be available at certain hours.
Explanation: The Mumbai Police did not put out any such notification and all essential services are available in the city.

Claim: FALSE: Fact Check: Neither The Viral Post On Coronavirus (COVID-19) Is From UNICEF Nor It Is Accurate
Explanation: The viral message on Coronavirus (COVID-19) is neither from UNICEF nor accurate.

Claim: False: Indian Government snooping messages over social media and all social media platforms will be monitored for COVID-19 messages
Explanation: The message mentions a fake ministry of internal regulation that does not exist in the country.

Claim: : Recent mob attack on West Bengal police due to the lockdown in Howrah.
FALSE: Viral message on lockdown information attributed to Kozhikode Police, in India.
Explanation: Kozhikode Police has not sent out any such message.
